page.title: Directive on the legal protection of biotechnological inventions

revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "European Union directive in the field of patent law," ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|European Union directive in the field of patent law,}} {{EngvarB|date=July 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox EU legislation |type=Directive |number=98/44/EC |title=Directive on the legal protection of biotechnological inventions |madeby=[[European Parliament]] & [[European Council|Council]] |madeunder=Art. 100a |OJref=L213, 30 July 1998, pp. 13–21 |OJrefurl=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:1998:213:0013:0021:EN:PDF |made=1998-07-06 |commenced=1998-07-30 |implementation=2000-07-30 |CommProp=C296, 1996-10-08, p. 4.
C311, 1997-10-11, p. 12. |ESCOpin=C295, 1996-10-07, p. 11 |ParlOpin=C286, 1997-09-22, p. 87.
C167, 1998-06-01 |Reports=COM(2002) 2
COM(2002) 545
COM(2005) 312 |replaces=— |amends=— |amendedby=— |replacedby=— |status=Current }} '''Directive 98/44/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 July 1998 on the legal protection of biotechnological inventions''' is a [[European Union directive]] in the field of patent law, made under the [[Single European market|internal market]] provisions of the [[Treaty of Rome]]. It was intended to harmonise the laws of Member States regarding the [[patentability]] of [[Biotechnology|biotechnological]] [[invention]]s, including [[Plant variety (law)|plant varieties (as legally defined)]] and [[Human gene|human]] [[Gene patent|genes]]. == Content == The Directive is divided into the following five chapters: * Patentability (Chapter I) * Scope of Protection (Chapter II) * Compulsory cross-licensing (Chapter III) * Deposit, access and re-deposit of biological material (Chapter IV) * Final Provisions (entering into force) (Chapter V) ==Timeline== The original proposal was adopted by the [[European Commission]] in 1988. The procedure for its adoption was slowed down by primarily [[ethics|ethical]] issues regarding the patentability of living matter. The [[European Parliament]] eventually rejected the joint text from the final [[Conciliation]] meeting at 3rd reading on 1 March 1995 so the first directive process did not yield a directive.{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/prelex/detail_dossier_real.cfm?CL=en&DosId=100993 |title=EURLex – 100993 – EN – EUR-Lex |publisher=European Commission |accessdate=24 February 2015}} On 13 December 1995, the Commission adopted a new proposal was nearly identical to the rejected version, was changed again, but the Parliament put aside its ethical concerns on patenting of human genes in on 12 July 1998 in its second reading and adopted the Common Position of the [[Council of the European Union|Council]], so in the second legislative process, the directive was adopted.{{cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/omk/omnsapir.so/calendar?APP=PDF&TYPE=PV1&FILE=19980512EN.pdf&LANGUE=EN |title=Part 1 : Proceedings of the sitting |publisher=European Parliament |accessdate=24 February 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/prelex/detail_dossier_real.cfm?CL=en&DosId=11643 |title=EURLex – 11643 – EN – EUR-Lex |publisher=European Commission |accessdate=24 February 2015}} The drafts person of the Parliament for this second procedure was [[Willi Rothley]] and the vote with the most yes votes was Amendment 9 from the Greens which got 221 against 294 votes out of 532 members voting with 17 abstentions but 314 yes votes would have been required to reach the required an absolute majority to adopt it. On 6 July 1998, a final version was adopted. Its code is 98/44/EC. The [[Kingdom of the Netherlands]] brought Case C-377/98[http://www.curia.europa.eu/en/actu/activites/act01/0125en.htm#ToC1] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819165356/http://www.curia.europa.eu/en/actu/activites/act01/0125en.htm#ToC1 |date=19 August 2007 }} before the [[European Court of Justice]] against the adoption of the directive with six different pleas but the Court granted none of them. Nevertheless, the ECJ decision does not preclude a further test of the validity of the directive on the ground that it is inconsistent with the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS).{{cite web|url=http://www.wto.org/english/tratop_e/trips_e/t_agm0_e.htm |title=intellectual property (TRIPS) – agreement text – contents |publisher=WTO |accessdate=18 August 2013}} Art. 27.1 TRIPS provides that patents are only to be granted with respect to 'inventions'. The directive, however, provides that "biological material which is isolated from its natural environment ... may be the subject of an invention even if it previously occurred in nature." It is clearly arguable that merely isolating a human gene or protein from its natural environment is not an activity that can come within the meaning of the word 'invention'. The Danish Council of Bioethics in its Patenting Human Genes and Stem Cells Report[http://www.etiskraad.dk/sw475.asp] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061010131657/http://www.etiskraad.dk/sw475.asp |date=10 October 2006 }} noted that "In the members' view, it cannot be said with any reasonableness that a sequence or partial sequence of a gene ceases to be part of the human body merely because an identical copy of the sequence is isolated from or produced outside of the human body." TRIPS applies to the European Community as it is a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in its own right and accordingly must ensure "the conformity of its laws, regulations and administrative procedures with obligations as provided" by the WTO.{{cite web|url=http://www.wto.org/english/docs_e/legal_e/04-wto_e.htm |title=legal texts – Marrakesh agreement |publisher=WTO |accessdate=18 August 2013}} On 14 January 2002, the Commission submitted an assessment of the implications for basic genetic engineering research of failure to publish, or late publication of, papers on subjects which could be patentable as required under Article 16(b) of this directive.{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/prelex/detail_dossier_real.cfm?CL=en&DosId=170903 |title=EURLex – 170903 – EN – EUR-Lex |publisher=European Commission |date=14 January 2002 |accessdate=24 February 2015}} ==Campaigning and lobbying== According to [[SmithKline Beecham]] lobbyist Simon Gentry, the company allocated 30 million [[European Currency Unit|ECU]] for a pro-Directive campaign.[http://www.corporateeurope.org/observer1/patents.html ''Industry and the EU Life Patent Directive''], Corporate Europe Observer, Issue 1, May 1998, citing ECOBP, "''The Big Mirage: The Misuse of the Patient with Hereditary Diseases Before the EP's Vote in 1997''" an ECOBP Background Paper, March 1998, page 4 Part of this campaign was direct support of patient charities and organisations. On the day of the July 1997 vote, a number of people in wheelchairs from these groups demonstrated outside the main hall in Strasbourg, chanting the pharmaceutical industry's slogan, "No Patents, No Cure" in an emotional appeal to Parliamentarians to vote for the Directive.{{cite web|last=Simpson |first=Alan |url=http://www.thecornerhouse.org.uk/resource/no-patents-life#index-02-00-00-00 |title=No Patents on Life |publisher=The Corner House |date=1 September 1997 |accessdate=24 February 2015}} == Implementation == As of 15 January 2007, all of the 27 EU member states had implemented the Directive.{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/internal_market/indprop/docs/invent/state-of-play_en.pdf |format=PDF |title=State of Play of the Implementation of Directive 98/44/EC |publisher=European Commission |accessdate=24 February 2015}} == See also == *[[Biological patent]] *[[Patent law of the European Union]] *[[G 2/06]], decision of the Enlarged Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office (EPO) of 25 November 2008, relating to (non-patentability of) inventions involving the use and destruction of human embryos. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://europa.eu/legislation_summaries/internal_market/single_market_for_goods/pharmaceutical_and_cosmetic_products/l26026_en.htm EU Legislation summary] *[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:1998:213:0013:0021:EN:PDF Text of the directive (pdf)] *[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31998L0044:EN:NOT Text of directive with headers (html)] *[http://register.consilium.europa.eu/pdf/en/05/st11/st11341.en05.pdf Report from the Commission to the Council and the European Parliament, Development and implications of patent law in the field of biotechnology and genetic engineering], 2005-07-14 *[http://ec.europa.eu/internal_market/en/indprop/invent/2k-39.htm FAQ] from the Commission Directorate-General for the Internal Market *[http://ec.europa.eu/internal_market/indprop/invent/index_en.htm Reports and other documents concerning European Commission activities in the area of biotechnological inventions] from the Commission Directorate-General for the Internal Market *[http://www.patent.gov.uk/about/ippd/issues/bioinvent.htm Issues] from the [[UK Intellectual Property Office]] *[http://www.ladas.com/Patents/Biotechnology/EPOBiotechInventions/BiologicalInventions.html Some biotechnological inventions] registered at the [[European Patent Organisation|European Patent Office]] (''unofficial site'') *[http://www.murdoch.edu.au/elaw/issues/v11n1/hakki111.html Paper] *Baruch Brody, 2007. "Intellectual Property and Biotechnology: The European Debate,” Kennedy Institute of Ethics Journal 17(2): 69–110. [http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/kennedy_institute_of_ethics_journal/v017/17.2brody.pdf] {{Intellectual property laws of the European Union}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Directive On The Legal Protection Of Biotechnological Inventions}} [[Category:Biological patent law]] [[Category:European Union directives|Legal protection of biotechnological inventions]] [[Category:Patent law of the European Union]] [[Category:1998 in law]] [[Category:1998 in the European Union]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/2605:E000:9149:A600:CC3E:AEF9:B84:F95F|2605:E000:9149:A600:CC3E:AEF9:B84:F95F]] ([[User talk:2605:E000:9149:A600:CC3E:AEF9:B84:F95F|talk]]) to last version by Nat965

revision.text:
'''Electronic services delivery''' or '''ESD''' refers to providing government services through the [[Internet]] or other electronic means. It is related to [[e-services]] and [[e-government]].
==Defining e-service== E-service (or eservice) is a highly generic term usually referring to ‘The provision of services via the Internet (the prefix 'e' standing for ‘electronic’, as it does in many other usages), thus e-Service may also include e-Commerce, although it may also include non-commercial services (online), which is usually provided by the government.’ (Alexei Pavlichev & G. David Garson, 2004: 169-170; Muhammad Rais & Nazariah, 2003: 59, 70-71).
‘An umbrella term for services available on the Internet, e-Service include e-Commerce transaction services for handling online orders, application hosting by application service providers (ASPs) and any processing capability that is obtainable on the Web.’ (Computer Desktop Encyclopedia, 2009)
E-Service or 'electronic service' constitutes the online services available on the Internet, whereby a valid transaction of buying and selling (procurement) is possible, as opposed to the traditional websites, whereby only descriptive information are available, and no online transaction is made possible.' (Jeong, 2007).
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081018194927/http://www.ocw.unu.edu/international-institute-for-software-technology/introduction-to-electronic-government/modules.html/ United Nations E-government project] *[http://www.geomunicipal.com/ GEOMunicipal] - e-services for Local governments]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Electronic services delivery}} [[Category:Open government]] [[Category:Public administration]]

{{Infobox person | name = Farah Khan |image = |image_size = 250px | residence = [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]] | nationality = [[Singapore]] | birth_date = | birth_place = Singapore | employer = | website = | occupation = Entrepreneur. | known_for = High end fashion design and creation | television = | spouse = | children = }} '''Farah Khan''' is a [[Singapore]]an entrepreneur, the founder of the luxury retail fashion [[boutique]] Melium Group and the creative director of the ''Farah Khan'' label. In 2011, [[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] listed her as one of the top 100 memorable women in [[Malaysia]].<ref name="starsing1">{{cite news |title= 100 memorable Malaysian Women - Part 3 |url= http://www.thestar.com.my/story.aspx?file=%2f2011%2f3%2f8%2flifefocus%2f8199071&sec=lifefocus |date= 2011 |newspaper= [[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]}}</ref><ref name="straitti">{{cite news |title= Singapore-born Farah Khan On How She Became A Fashion Mogul And Designer |url= http://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/singapore-born-farah-khan-on-how-she-became-a-fashion-mogul-and-designer |date= |newspaper= The Strait Times (Singapore) }}</ref> In 2006, Khan received the Italian Star of Solidarity Order (The Ordine della Stella della Solidarietà Italiana) from the Italian Ambassador to Malaysia Alessandro Busacca in conjunction with his country’s [[national day]]. This award honours foreign personalities who strengthen ties between [[Italy]] and foreign countries in terms of culture, language, humanitarian actions.<ref name="starsing2">{{cite news |title= Farah Khan awarded the Italian Star |url= http://www.thestar.com.my/story.aspx?file=%2f2007%2f6%2f16%2fcentral%2f17985643&sec=central |date= |newspaper= [[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]}}</ref>
== Personal life == Khan is the daughter, the third of five siblings, of a former diamond merchant and a lady who owned a Shanghainese-style fashion boutique called Le Bijou in Singapore. She learned the art of tailoring from her mother who made fashion dresses. Khan claims that she sees fashion as a form of self-expression and a means to display her creativity.<ref name="star2">{{cite news |title= These women lead the way in Malaysia’s fashion and beauty industry |url= http://www.star2.com/people/2017/03/12/these-women-lead-the-way-in-malaysias-fashion-and-beauty-industry/ |date= March 12, 2017 |newspaper=Star2.com}}</ref>
At 27, Khan divorced her first husband and remarried with Singaporean business tycoon [[Akbar Khan (businessman)|Akbar Khan]] based in [[Kuala Lumpur]]. She adopted the [[Muslim name]] Farah Khan and joined her husband in the Malaysian capital. She stayed home for about a year and decided to resume her activities in the fashion industry.
Khan has three children: a 35-year-old son and a 33-year-old daughter from her first marriage. She also has another son, aged 23, from her second marriage. Khan has since been in a long-term relationship with Greek businessman Dimitri Pantazaras, 58, a real estate developer. She spends time with charity causes for children with special needs. In the past, Khan battled stomach cancer and survived against odds. Now, she enjoys travelling and spending holidays with her family.
== Career == Khan's career is better described through her achievements and creations in the fashion industry.<ref name="harper">{{cite news |title= DATO’ FARAH KHAN: ONE IN A MILLION |url= http://harpersbazaar.my/fashion/dato-farah-khan-one-in-a-million/ |date= 22 June 2015 |newspaper= [[Harper's Bazaar]]}}</ref> Since 1974, she founded 3 luxury boutiques and a group.<ref name="star2"/> Khan is recognized in Malaysia as a style icon among notable designers including [[Jimmy Choo]] and [[Bernard Chandran]].<ref name="top10">{{cite news |title= Famous Malaysian Fashion Designers |url= http://top10malaysia.com/home/index.php/news-and-events/famous-malaysian-fashion-designers |date= |newspaper=Top 10 Malaysia}}</ref><ref name="maldigest">{{cite news |title= 10 Famous Malaysian Fashion Designers |url= http://www.malaysiandigest.com/archived/index.php/15-features/personality/9499-10-famous-malaysian-fashion-designers.html |date= July 20, 2012 |newspaper= Malaysian Digest}}</ref>
=== The Link === In 1974, Khan set up The Link boutique along Orchard Road in Singapore at the [[Mandarin Hotel]]. It's a designer store with luxury Italian and British designer labels including [[Genny]] and [[Jean Muir]]. Unexpectedly, Khan sold the store in 1982 to Singaporean fashion retailer Tina Tan-Leo, married and moved to Malaysia.
=== Melium Group === In 1987, Khan opened Le Salon, a multi-brand boutique which carried notable brand including [[Versace]] and [[Alberta Ferretti]]. Then in 1989, she rebranded Le Salon to Melium Group set up in association with German leather brand [[Aigner]], and [[menswear]] label [[Hugo Boss]]. The Melium Group operates 38 stores in Malaysia and runs Aseana, a luxury multi-brand boutique. The group also owns and operates a chain of 18 dome cafes in Malaysia. Under the leadership of Khan, the Melium Group operates in [[Indonesia]] as lone stores at the W Retreat & Spa in [[Bali]] and Plaza Indonesia, [[Jakarta]].<ref name="star2"/>
=== FARAH KHAN (label) === Under the Melium Group umbrella, Khan launched in 2007, the fashion label FARAH KHAN that integrates [[Southeast Asia]]n beadwork and modern styles.<ref name="asiatat">{{cite news |title= Farah Khan : Dresses that impress |url= http://sg.asiatatler.com/style/fashion/farah-khan-dresses-that-impress |date= |newspaper= Asia Tatler}}</ref> The label retails in several cities worldwide.<ref name="vulcanpost">{{cite news |title= 10 M'sian Fashion Designers Whose Creations Have Graced International Runways |url= https://vulcanpost.com/587145/10-malaysian-fashion-designers/ |date= September 5, 2016 |newspaper= Vulcan Post}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://farahkhan.com/ Farah Khan official website] * [http://www.farahkhanfinejewellery.com/abt_fk_brand/ FARAH KHAN (label)]
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Khan, Farah}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Malaysian businesspeople]] [[Category:Malaysian fashion designers]] [[Category:Malaysian socialites]]

{{Infobox video game |title = Game Tycoon |image = |developer = Beat Games |publisher = Tri Synergy |designer = |engine = |released = {{vgrelease|NA|March 22, 2006}} |genre = [[Business simulation game]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |platforms = [[Windows]] }}
'''''Game Tycoon''''' is a [[business simulation game]] focused on production of video games.<ref>{{Citation |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/htmlpages2/932120.asp|title=Game Tycoon - PC|publisher=gamerankings.com}}</ref> The game has been largely ridiculed, especially for some parts not translated from German to English. <!-- *Reception [[X-Play]] gave the game a 1 out of 5, mentioning that parts of the game are still not translated from the original German. They also said that it was barely a game.-->
== Gameplay == Game play is centered on the full production of video-game making; from production of an engine, concept design, physical design, packaging, licensing deals, market campaigns, and reviews.
The game starts off in 1982 with somewhat limited availability of features. Eventually, more options are made for engines and packaging, etc.
== References == <references/>
[[Category:2006 video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Germany]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Windows-only games]] [[Category:Business simulation games]]
{{simulation-videogame-stub}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2013}} The '''Gershon Efficiency Review''' was a review of efficiency in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] [[public sector]] conducted in 2003-4 by [[Peter Gershon|Sir Peter Gershon]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smithbellerby.co.uk/glossary/page_5.html |title=Gershon Review |first= |last= |work=Smith Bellerby |year=2012 |accessdate=December 15, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090403212557/http://www.smithbellerby.co.uk/glossary/page_5.html |archivedate=April 3, 2009 |df= }}</ref>
[[Gordon Brown]] and Tony Blair, then [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] and [[Prime Minister]] respectively, appointed Peter Gershon, at that time the head of the [[Office of Government Commerce]], to review operations across all [[public services]] and make recommendations regarding expenditure and efficiency. His report recommended making savings for [[Financial Year]] 2005-6, to be achieved through dramatic changes to the organisation of each government department and automating their work patterns, in order to 'release' resources from the public sector budget that was then approximately £520bn. These gross savings of £21.5bn were reported to have been achieved by 2007 and agreed as part of the Comprehensive Spending Review in 2004 and subsequent budget.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.passport-offices.info/index.php?t=Gershon+Review |title=Gershon Review |first= |last= |work=Passport Office |year=2012 |accessdate=December 15, 2012}}</ref>
The effect of these objectives has been for all government departments to agree reductions on their long-term budgets, and then work out how to fulfill these challenging promises without crippling their existing obligations and service.
== Benefits == Certain functions were identified as offering good opportunities for savings through the use of ICT, such as tax collection and benefits payments. Aggregating and reorganising other functions offers the promise of savings in procurement, buildings and facilities. The approach encourages departments to meet the government's desire for 'Joined-up Government' that smooths out the delivery of services, and supports initiatives such as the use of a [[Common Systems Strategy]] as suggested in Sir [[David Varney]]'s Report and the [[Transformational Government strategy]].
== Problems == However, not all government functions present such clear opportunities; those with a large proportion of physical assets or customer-facing staff have great challenges to offer the equivalent level of savings without suffering damage to their level of service.
The timeframe also gives these organisations the challenge of investing in new services at a time when departmental headcount and budgets are being cut. In reality, the 'Gershon reviews' have been applied in waves across organisations.
In many instances the [[Treasury]] has interpreted this release of resources to be a cost saving for reallocation outside to other projects or departments.
Relocations recommended by Gershon have resulted in considerable loss of expertise, for example at the UK's Office For National Statistics, which has been criticized by the Chair of the Treasury Select committee. <ref>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/jan/26/interestrates</ref> <ref>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/jan/08/andrew-tyrie-blasts-out-of-touch-office-for-national-statistics</ref>
==Team members== The team that supported Sir Peter Gershon in this work was drawn from a number of Government departments and consultancy organisations:<ref>{{cite book |last1=Gershon |first1=Sir Peter |title=Releasing resources to the front line. Independent review of public sector efficiency |publisher=HM Treasury |year=2004 |page=59}}</ref> * Simon King, [[HEDRA]] * Anna Longman, [[HM Treasury]] * Gillian Magee, [[PA Consulting Group]] * Sue Moon, Kent and Medway [[NHS Strategic Health Authority]] * Graham Murray, [[IBM]] * John Pendlebury-Green, [[PA Consulting Group]] * Sheila Pringle, [[Deloitte and Touche]] * Neil Reeder, [[HM Treasury]] * Bill Roots, [[Solace Enterprises]] * Nathalie Ross, Nathalie Ross Consulting * Tony Smith, [[IBM]] * Mike Binnington [[Deloitte and Touche]] * James Bromiley [[National Audit Office (United Kingdom)|National Audit Office]] * Alan Collier [[Office of Government Commerce|OGC]] * Paul Connolly [[HEDRA]] * Rob Devlen [[Hewlett Packard]] * Zoe Elliot [[Cabinet Office]] * Nicholas Fox [[IBM]] * Gerry Friell [[HM Treasury]] * Paul Kirby [[Cabinet Office]] * Liz Lawrence [[Cabinet Office]] * John Hood [[PA Consulting]] * Rebecca Khodr [[Cabinet Office]] * Judi Stockwell, [[PA Consulting Group]] * Jenny Swan, [[Ofgem]] * Emily Teller, [[Cabinet Office]] * Graham Turnock, [[HM Treasury]] * Bob Walding, [[Audit Commission (United Kingdom)|Audit Commission]] * Graham Walker, [[Office of the e-Envoy]] * Martin Walker, [[Hewlett Packard]] * Andrew Ward, [[PA Consulting Group]] * Alice Webb, [[PA Consulting Group]] * David Williams, [[Insource Solutions]] * Marian Wilson, [[Inland Revenue]] * Nadia Zahawi, [[HEDRA]]
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/spending_sr04_efficiency.htm Gershon Review] *[http://management.silicon.com/government/0,39024677,39123519,00.htm?r=1 ''Where are they now… Sir Peter Gershon'' ] Silicon.com Friday 27 August 2004 *[http://www.commentonthis.com/varney/ Varney Report] *[http://www.commentonthis.com/tfg/ Transformational Government Annual Report 2006] *[http://www.rce.gov.uk/rce/core/page.do?pageId=10106 Regional Centres of Excellence - Efficiency Agenda]
[[Category:Quality]] [[Category:Local government in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Public sector in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2004 in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2005 in the United Kingdom]]

{{BLP sources|date=August 2018}} '''Gideon Amichay''' ({{lang-he-n|גדעון עמיחי}}; born 1963) is an [[Israel]]i advertising executive, marketer and author. He is the founder and chief creative officer of No, No, No, No, No, Yes, a creative boutique in New York and [[Tel Aviv]]. He also teaches at the [[School of Visual Arts]] in New York city. From May 1994 to November 2011, he acted as the Chief Creative Officer & Joint Managing Partner at Shalmor Avnon Amichay/[[Young & Rubicam|Y&R]], [[Tel Aviv]], Israel.[[File:gideonamichay.jpg|thumb|Gideon Amichay]]
== Biography == Gideon Amichay was born and raised in [[Holon]], [[Israel]]. He served in the [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] as a graphic designer and a reporter in the IDF's weekly newspaper "[[Bamahane]]". In 1990 Amichay graduated with honors his [[visual Communication]] studies at the [[Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design|"Betzalel Art Academy"]] in [[Jerusalem]], and [[School of Visual Arts]] in New York. In 2008, Amichay graduated with honors his [[Master of Business Administration|EMBA]] studies for company leaders at the [[Berlin School of Creative Leadership]].
[[File:Lapland1.jpg|thumb|“Fishing”, a [[cartoon]] by Gideon Amichay, published in ''[[The New Yorker]]'', January 16, 1995]] <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:nonononononoyes.jpg|thumb|Gideon Amichay's first book]] -->
== Career == Amichay began drawing cartoons for television and newspapers at the age of 14. Amichay's cartoons and articles were published in many newspapers in Israel, including "[[Yediot Aharonot]]", "Globes", "[[Ha'aretz]]", "The Marker", "Calcalist" and "[[Ma'ariv]]", where he also started working as a cartoonist and journalist. Later, his cartoons were also published abroad, including in "[[The New Yorker]]" (1995).
In 1990, Amichay started his journey in the world of advertising as a creative director at the "Warshavsky Froehlich Dover/Grey" advertising agency. In May 1994 he joined Rami Shalmor and Shlomi Avnon as a partner and they turned into the "Shalmor Avnon Amichay" agency, where he served as joint CEO and Chief Creative Officer. Later, the agency joined the international Young & Rubicam network.
From July 2011, the company's founders, Rami Shalmor, Shlomi Avnon and Gideon Amichay, became active chairmen. Amichay gave many lectures in Israel, including in [[Tel Aviv University]], [[Interdisciplinary Center|IDC Herzliya]], [[Hebrew University]], Betzalel Art Academy, The Neri Bloomfield School, and [[Shenkar College of Engineering and Design|Shenkar College]].
Some of Amichay's lectures were broadcast live on Israel's [[Channel 2 (Israel)|Channel 2]] website. Amichay was also invited to be a [[keynote]] speaker abroad, including in [[Eurobest]] (2009), New York Festivals (2010), in [[Shanghai]], and in the Cannes Lions Festival (2011).
Amichay is a committee member for the {{Interlanguage link multi|Israeli Cartoon Museum|he|3=המוזיאון הישראלי לקריקטורה ולקומיקס}} and, together with Ze'ev Ravid, they led the museum's branding campaign. Amichay was a member of the Young & Rubicam creative board for 10 years.
On September 11, 2011, Amichay has partnered with [[Aniboom]] and initiated a project to honor the upcoming 10th anniversary of [[September 11 attacks]] by bringing together animators from all over the world. Amichay envisioned that each participant would create a short animation inspired by the title: 9/11. It’s been ten years.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/aniboom911|title=9/11 - It's Been Ten Years|work=YouTube}}</ref> One of the videos was made by Amichay himself.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I1uUE489vd0|title=Gideon Amichay - The Rear Window|date=24 August 2011|work=YouTube}}</ref>
In 2011, Amichay published his first book in [[Hebrew]] - "לא, לא, לא, לא, לא, לא, לא, כן" that translate to: "No, No, No, No, No, No, No, Yes", The [[English language|English]] edition - “No, No, No, No, No, Yes. Insights From a Creative Journey” was published in the US in January 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Yes-Insights-From-Creative-Journey/dp/0991058623/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1391874333&sr=8-1&keywords=gideon+amichay|title=No, No, No, No, No, Yes. Insights From a Creative Journey: Gideon Amichay, Keith Reinhard, Richard Wilde: 9780991058624: Amazon.com: Books|work=amazon.com}}</ref> The book can be found at the [[Museum of Modern Art|MoMA]] store in New York as well as other venues.In 2016 he published his second book in Hebrew - “נו, נו, נו, נו, נו, נו, נו, יס” - A Creative Journey in New York.
In December 2012 Amichay gave a talk as a part of [[TEDx#TEDx|TEDx Jerusalem]] bearing the same name ("No, No, No, No, No, No, No, Yes")<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sZScrNJ2gTQ|title=No, No, No, No, No, Yes: Gideon Amichay at TEDxJerusalem|date=3 January 2013|work=YouTube}}</ref>
In 2013 he founded No, No, No, No, No, Yes, a creative boutique in New York. In 2015 the Tel Aviv office was launched. Among its clients are [[Outbrain]], [[DOGTV]], VW Israel and others. In July 2013 the company created a content project for the Hebrew Wikipedia 10th anniversary, in cooperation with the Hebrew Wikipedia and Channel 2 news – [[Israeli News Company]].<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ULgjM2wHFC4&list=PLuQcXKjU3rwJ-TOL8lyru7oHvoufnWtED&index=1|title=Celebrating Hebrew Wikipedia 10th anniversary with Channel 2 - Roni Daniel|date=7 August 2013|work=YouTube}}</ref> In 2016 the agency created The Cyber Horse for The Blavatnik Interdisciplinary Cyber Research Center (ICRC) - [[Tel Aviv University]]. The Cyber Horse is a piece of work created with thousands of infected computer and cell phone components. It illustrates the increasing use of malware in making cyberspace a hostile environment. It was created in order to prompt national and international awareness of the dangers of cyber-attacks. The project earned impressions around the world such as CBS NEWS,<ref>http://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/pictures-of-the-week-june-18-24-2016/21/</ref> The Times UK, The Economist,<ref>https://www.instagram.com/p/BG53AddNmYY/</ref> The Telegraph,<ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/06/20/pictures-of-the-day-20th-june-2016/a-cyber-horse-made-from-thousands-of-infected-computer-and-cell/</ref> Le Monde, Der Spiegel)
== Awards and achievements ==
In his position of Chief Creative Officer at Shalmor Avnon Amichay, Amichay led the agency to win many awards, including:
*19 Cannes Lions awards, the largest number of [[Cannes Lions]] awards for an Israeli agency (up to 2012). *An internet campaign for Danone Strauss, which achieved a record number of votes- approximately 10,000,000, for a campaign voting for the pictures shown on yogurt cups.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mefik.co.il/page.asp?page_parent=2427|title=קמפיין דנונה שובר שיאים: 9 מיליון הצבעות באתר עד כה|author=Mefik|work=mefik.co.il}}</ref> *Archive magazine granted the main interview to Amichay in a 2011 edition (11-1).<ref>http://www.luerzersarchive.net/interview11-1.asp</ref> *The agency won the One Show Silver Pencil Award for the Israel Aids Task Force "Get Tested Project" and is the only Israeli agency that won it (up to 2011).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oneclub.org/#olb=/_ajax/archive/?action=arc_work%26value=13436|title=The One Club / Home|work=oneclub.org}}</ref> *The UN granted a special award to the agency for the Israel Aids Task Force SDIA project (2010).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/News/Press/docs/2010/note6263.doc.htm|title=New York Festivals, United Nations Department of Public Information Awards|work=un.org}}</ref> *The agency was awarded the title of agency of the year in the Young and Rubicam worldwide agency (from 184 agencies) and won the Jewel Award.<ref>http://enews.yr.com/edition.aspx?pgid=1488</ref> *The agency won 2nd Media Agency of the Year at the Cannes Lions Festival (2009)<ref>http://www.canneslions.com/downloads/winners_pdfs/Cannes_Lions_2009_Special_Awards.pdf</ref> *The agency won the Grand Prix in London International Awards (LIA) (2009) for the radio campaign for the Israel Aids Task Force.<ref>http://www.liaawards.com/press/archive.cfm#</ref> *The agency won the Grand Prix in the New York Festival (1999) for the radio campaign encouraging advertising through the radio.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorkfestivals.com/main.php?p=3,1&wp=info&id=114289 |title=New York Festivals |work=newyorkfestivals.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315044336/http://www.newyorkfestivals.com/main.php?p=3,1&wp=info&id=114289 |archivedate=2012-03-15 |df= }}</ref> *The agency won the Gold [[Clio]] twice, for "Internet Shutdown Project" (2008), and the Israel Aids Task Force's SDIA Project (2010), the agency is the only Israeli agency that won this award (up to 2011).<ref>http://www.clioawards.com/press/index.cfm?year=2008&pressid=209</ref> *The agency won the Grand Prix in the Golden Drum competition, for the Israel [[Aids]] Task Force SDIA project. *During 2008, the Israeli Marketing Association granted Amichay the title of "Marketing man of the month" in Israel for excellence in marketing Israeli advertising worldwide<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.calcalist.co.il/marketing/articles/0,7340,L-3098864,00.html|title=איש השיווק של יולי - גדעון עמיחי|work=כלכליסט - www.calcalist.co.il}}</ref> *Under his leadership, the Agency won "Agency of the year" many times (2000, 2003, 2005, 2006, and 2007). *The agency won 20 Effie Awards including a Platinum (2005) & a Grand Effie(2006). *The first ever Grand Prix at PIAF was awarded to the Get Tested Project.(2011)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.piaf.cz/Press/Releases.aspx |title=PIAF 2015 |work=piaf.cz |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110226061219/http://www.piaf.cz/Press/Releases.aspx |archivedate=2011-02-26 |df= }}</ref>
== Jury member == *Cannes Lions (Direct Lions Jury President)[2012]<ref>http://www.canneslions.com/awards/juror.cfm?jurer_id=15&jury_id=4</ref> *Cresta (Grand Jury President)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cresta-awards.com/Jury_Grand.aspx|title=Cresta International Advertising Awards - Grand Jury|work=cresta-awards.com}}</ref> *AdPrint<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adprint.ro/jury/view/Gideon+Amichay|title=AdPrint - Judging teams|work=adprint.ro}}</ref> *Clio.<ref>http://www.clioawards.com/press/index.cfm?year=2010&pressid=240</ref> *Eurobest. *New York Festival.<ref>http://www.newyorkfestivals.com/main.taf?p=2,11,1</ref> *Creative Heads.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UbB-ljwqiog|title=Gideon Amichay|date=16 April 2010|work=YouTube}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.gideonamichay.com/ Gideon Amichay's blog] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UbB-ljwqiog Gideon Amichay's - at the Creative Heads competition] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2gF8qD7k9uw Gideon Amichay's "speech from the crowd" at Cannes Lions 2012 Ceremony - the Direct Lions Jury President speech.] * [http://mizbala.com/_uploads/images/2008/06/amichay-pdf.pdf Gideon Amichay, The Modern Consumer, an article in the weekly Campaign Magazine] * [http://www.bestadsontv.com/ad/37805/Campaign-Brief-Gideon-Amichay-at-Cannes an interview for BestAdsOnTV.com] during Cannes Festival 2011
{{authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name = Heiser, Rosenfeld, and Strauss Buildings | nrhp_type = | image = Heiser Rosenfeld Strauss MD1.jpg | caption = Heiser, Rosenfeld, and Strauss Buildings, February 2012 | location= 32-42 S. Paca St.
[[Baltimore, Maryland]], [[United States|U.S.]] | coordinates = {{coord|39|17|16|N|76|37|21|W|region:US_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = United States Baltimore#Maryland#USA | built = {{Start date|1886}} | architect = Parker & Thomas; Et al. | architecture = Late Victorian, Beaux Arts, Romanesque | added = March 10, 1980 | area = {{convert|0.5|acre}} | governing_body = Private | refnum = 80001787{{NRISref|version=2010a}} }} '''Heiser, Rosenfeld, and Strauss Buildings''', also known as '''Inner Harbor Lofts I''', is a historic [[loft]] building located at [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]], [[United States]]. It is a complex of three structures. The Heiser Building is a [[Romanesque Revival architecture|Romanesque Revival]] style, six-story brick, stone, and iron structure, eight [[Bay (architecture)|bays]] wide and 14 bays deep, built as a show factory in 1886. The [[Faultless Pajama Company|Rosenfeld Building]] is a six-story, five-bay loft building, with [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux Arts]] styling and built for E. Rosenfeld and Company in 1905. The Strauss Building is a six-story high, six-bay wide, and 11-bay deep loft structure built in 1887 for the Kinny Tobacco Company, [[cigarette]] manufacturers, and later occupied by the Strauss Brothers, clothing manufacturers and became part of the Rosenfeld complex around 1910.{{cite web|url=https://mht.maryland.gov/secure/medusa/PDF/NR_PDFs/NR-596.pdf |title=National Register of Historic Places Registration: Heiser, Rosenfeld, and Strauss Buildings|date=August 1979|accessdate=2016-03-01 |author=Fred B. Shoken|publisher=Maryland Historical Trust}} Heiser, Rosenfeld, and Strauss Buildings was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1980. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{MHT url|id=598|title=Heiser, Rosenfeld, and Strauss Buildings, Baltimore City}}, including photo from 1976, at Maryland Historical Trust {{National Register of Historic Places in Maryland}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Baltimore]] [[Category:Downtown Baltimore]] [[Category:Industrial buildings and structures on the National Register of Historic Places in Baltimore]] [[Category:Industrial buildings completed in 1886]] [[Category:Beaux-Arts architecture in Maryland]] [[Category:Victorian architecture in Maryland]] [[Category:Romanesque Revival architecture in Maryland]] {{BaltimoreCityMD-NRHP-stub}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
'''Intelligent device management''' is a technology used for [[enterprise software]] applications that allow equipment manufacturers to monitor and manage remote equipment, systems and products via the [[Internet]]. Another term for intelligent device management is '''remote device management''' (RDM) while '''strategic service management''' describes the service.
IDM extends IT service management to on-site devices and can support standard service processes, such as [[Incident Management (ITSM)|Incident]], [[ITIL#Problem_management|Problem]], [[Change Management (ITSM)|Change]], [[Configuration Management (ITSM)|Configuration Management]] as defined by [[ITIL]].
This technology is commonly used by ATM, security and [[self-service kiosk]] companies.
== See also == *[[Machine to machine]] *[[Control system]] *[[HVAC control system]] *[[Control engineering]] *[[Lighting control system]] *[[Intelligent building]] *[[Self-service kiosk]]
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080821115455/http://www.machine2enterprise.com/ Machine 2 Enterprise] - Blog on Building Management Systems
[[Category:Business software]] [[Category:Information technology management]]
{{software-type-stub}}

{{Infobox ambassador |name = Isaac Gilinski Sragowicz |image = |imagesize = |alt = |order = |ambassador_from = Colombia |country = Israel |term_start = {{date|2010-01-11}} |term_end = |predecessor = Juan Hurtado Cano |successor = |president = [[Álvaro Uribe Vélez]] |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1934|02|19|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Barranquilla]], [[Atlántico Department|Atlántico]], [[Colombia]] |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = [[Colombian people|Colombian]] |spouse = {{nowrap|Perla Bacal Zweiban (1957-present)}} |children = [[Jaime Gilinski Bacal]]
Rutie Gilinski Bacal
Tania Gilinski Bacal |alma_mater = |religion = [[Jewish]] }} {{Spanish name|Gilinski|Sragowicz}} '''Isaac Gilinski Sragowicz''' ({{lang-he|יצחק גילינסקי}} born 19 February 1934){{cite web|url=http://www.cancilleria.gov.co/wps/wcm/connect/61724b004fc2caf4acbebd754d8431dd/ISAAC+GILINSKI+SRAGOWICZ.pdf?MOD=AJPERES |title=Curriculum Vitae |accessdate=2011-08-22 |publisher=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Colombia)|Colombian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]]}} is a Colombian banker and financier currently serving as [[Ambassador of Colombia to Israel]].{{cite web |publisher=Office of the President of Colombia |date=2009-10-28 |language=Spanish |accessdate=2011-01-08 |title=Isaac Gilinski tomó posesión como Embajador de Colombia en Israel |url=http://web.presidencia.gov.co/sp/2009/octubre/28/04282009.html |trans-title=Isaac Gilinski was sworn in as Ambassador of Colombia to Israel }} ==Ambassadorship== Gilinski was appointed [[Ambassador of Colombia to Israel]] by [[President of Colombia|President]] [[Álvaro Uribe Vélez]] on 28 October 2009 in a ceremony of protocol that took place at the [[Palace of Nariño]]; he later presented his [[Letters of Credence]] in a ceremony of protocol at [[Beit HaNassi]] to the [[President of Israel]], [[Shimon Peres]], on 11 January 2010.{{cite journal|last=Cashman|first=Greer Fay|title=Presentation of ambassadorial credentials becomes a family affair|journal=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=12 January 2010|location=Tel Aviv|issn=0021-597X|oclc=3919101}} Gilinski's brother, Lazar, had also served as Ambassador of Colombia to Israel in the 80's.{{cite web|title=Acto en homenaje al Sr. Lazar Gilinski Z¨L|url=http://www.kklweb.org/vernoticia.php?codigo=841&pag=8|publisher=Keren Kayemet Leisrael|accessdate=12 March 2013|language=Spanish|date=20 May 2010}}{{cite book|title=The Europa Year Book|year=1988|publisher=[[Europa Publications]]|location=London|isbn=9780946653416|page=1461}} ==Personal life== Born Isaac Gilinski Sragowicz on 19 February 1934 in [[Barranquilla]], he is the son of [[Lithuanian people|Lithuanian]] immigrants who settled in that city from [[Israel]] in the 1920s. He is married to Perla Bacal Zweiban since 1957, with whom he had three children: [[Jaime Gilinski Bacal|Jaime]], Rutie, Tania.{{cite journal |journal=[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]] |url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-2351365 |title='Yo nunca pierdo, soy un guerrero': Isaac Gilinski |trans-title="I never lose, I am a fighter": Isaac Gilinski |date=2007-01-07 |first=Luz María |last=Sierra |accessdate=2011-01-07 |language=Spanish }} ==See also== * [[David de La Rosa Pérez]] * [[Antanas Mockus Šivickas]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gilinski Sragowicz, Isaac}} [[Category:1934 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Barranquilla]] [[Category:Colombian people of Lithuanian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Colombian Jews]] [[Category:Colombian chemical engineers]] [[Category:Colombian bankers]] [[Category:Colombian businesspeople]] [[Category:Colombian male singers]] [[Category:University of Valle faculty]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Colombia to Israel]] {{Colombia-politician-stub}}

{{Infobox park | name = Jacksonville Riverwalks | image = File:Jacksonville Landing - Black Raven and Voyager.jpg | image_size = 256 | image_alt = Refer to caption | image_caption = A section of Jacksonville's Riverwalk along the [[St. Johns River]] and [[Jacksonville Landing]] | map = USA Florida | map_width = 208 | location = [[Jacksonville, Florida]] | coordinates = {{coord|30.319525|-81.659901|display=inline}} | area = | established = {{start date|1985}}{{cite web |url=https://www.tampagov.net/sites/default/files/riverwalk/files/Tampa_MP_book.pdf |title=The Tampa Riverwalk Master Plan |author=[[EDAW|EDAW, Inc.]] |date=July 2006 |accessdate=May 4, 2018}} | operator = | designer = | publictransit = | visitation_num = | open = Year round | website = {{URL|http://downtownjacksonville.org/locations/l-98-northbank-riverwalk.aspx|Northbank Riverwalk}}
{{URL|http://downtownjacksonville.org/locations/l-100-southbank-riverwalk.aspx|Southbank Riverwalk}} }} The '''Jacksonville Riverwalks''' are a network of multi-use trails and open space developments along both the north and south banks of the [[St. Johns River]] in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]], [[Florida]]. The roughly {{convert|2|mi|km|adj=on}} [[Downtown Jacksonville|Downtown]] Northbank portion travels alongside the [[Hyatt Regency Jacksonville]], [[Jacksonville Landing]], [[Times-Union Center for the Performing Arts]], [[CSX Transportation Building]], and extends into the [[Brooklyn (Jacksonville)|Brooklyn]] district. The {{convert|1.25|mi|km|adj=on}} Southbank portion of the trail connects local landmarks such as [[Friendship Fountain]], [[Museum of Science and History]] and [[Riverplace Tower]]. ==History== [[Image:JAXRiverwalk1986.jpg|thumb|left|Southbank Riverwalk in 1986.]] The first section of the Riverwalk opened on the Downtown Southbank on November 8, 1985. It was intended as a venue where tourists and local residents alike could view the beauty of the river and the skyline of the city. On a sunny day, the view from the walk includes shimmering water, shiny buildings, sailboats & speedboats.{{cite news|title=Jacksonville Riverwalk exposes Florida City's Good Side|newspaper=Charlotte Observer|date=February 15, 1987}} The {{convert|1.2|mi|km|adj=on}} walk was designed by Perkins & Perkins Architects to be a festive waterfront public space linking [[Friendship Fountain]] and Harbormasters Restaurant (now River City Brewing Co.) with hotels and office buildings east of the [[Main Street Bridge (Jacksonville)|Main Street Bridge]]. Friendship Park Fountain was built in 1965 and became one of the most recognizable landmarks in the city. A graphic system was developed and, included banners, kiosks and signage to provide visitors with clear and legible information, as well as reinforce the warm and lively image of the riverwalk. A few of the project were built but scaled back. The St. Johns Wharf was a planned open-air marketplace to be built over the river adjacent to the Wyndham Hotel. A few shops were built along the riverwalk, but the wharf was never constructed. Four open air pavilions were planned and projected to include concessions and restroom facilities. only two were constructed. The Ship Museum, an attraction to emphasize the historic relationship between the city and the river; projected to include floating ship exhibits, was scaled back to the current [[Jacksonville Maritime Museum]], now closed. Multiple projects did not come to fruition. The Grove, a raised grass seating area shaded by a grove of palm trees; The Pyramid, an outdoor structure with terraced seating area for special events; An Aquarium located south of the maritime museum, facing Friendship Fountain, which would showcase local freshwater and saltwater marine life; A Great Lawn for recreation and relaxation; A sidewalk café under the bridge that would link both sides of riverwalk; A 3,000-seat open-air amphitheater with bandstand and theatrical lighting, built out into the river that would be used for public concerts, ballets, festivals and school graduations. [[Image:Northbank Riverwalk.PNG|thumb|right|225px|Newest section of Northbank Riverwalk]] In January, 2005, a ribbon-cutting ceremony was held to celebrate the opening of the latest extension of the Northbank Riverwalk. Construction took nearly two years for the {{convert|1.5|mi|km|adj=on}}, $8.7 million project. The landscaped brick walkway connects the existing Riverwalk at the CSX building to Riverside Avenue. Its features include historical lighting, water fountains, trash receptacles, bike racks, irrigated landscaping and over 100 benches.[http://www.jaxkids.org/NR/exeres/D3297F35-4267-4813-9622-210FBB98139E.htm?NRMODE=Unpublished City of Jacksonville website: Jan 27, 2005-Mayor Cuts Ribbon to Open Northbank Riverwalk] Nearly 40 feet of Riverwalk was temporarily closed in late 2006 when corrosion caused steel pilings to fail and the supported walkway buckled. The city allocated $1.3 million to inspect the entire Riverwalk and make emergency repairs, and planned a multi-year capital improvement project eventually costing $25 million for upgrades split between both riverwalks. As part of that project, the city began installing 306 pile jackets in and around the area of the 2006 closure at a cost of $1.4 million.{{cite news|last=Kerr|first=Jessie-Lynn|title=Northbank Riverwalk cave-in causes closure|url=http://jacksonville.com/news/metro/2009-06-30/story/northbank_riverwalk_cave-in_causes_closure|accessdate=10 July 2012|newspaper=Florida Times-Union|date=June 30, 2009}} At the January 31, 2008 meeting of the Downtown Development Review Board (DDRB) of the Jacksonville Economic Development Commission (JEDC), plans were tentatively approved for a 128-slip dockage facility to be named, ''The South Shore Marina & Riverwalk at the Aetna Building''. The project would include a new section of southbank riverwalk on the {{convert|13|acre|m2|adj=on}} [[The Aetna Building (Jacksonville)|Aetna Building]] property, which has {{convert|1100|ft|m}} of riverfrontage.[http://www.jaxdailyrecord.com/showstory.php?Story_id=49372 Jax Daily Record: February 4, 2008-Marina brings South Beach look to the Southbank by Max Marbut] Permits from the [[Florida Department of Environmental Protection]] and the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers]] had already been obtained, but financial conditions forced the project to be placed on hold. [[Image:Northbankriverwalk.JPG|thumb|left|225px|New access from Fidelity land swap]] The City of Jacksonville and [[Fidelity National Financial]] executed a land swap in 2008 that added {{convert|1.3|acre|m2}} in exchange for the parcel of land under Riverside Avenue's historic fire station. The city has the option to move the structure before it can be demolished, and funding for that purpose is being discussed.[http://www.metrojacksonville.com/content/view/798/122/ Metro Jacksonville: May 21, 2008-Public Access Improvements for Northbank Riverwalk] The [[Riverside Arts Market (RAM)|''Riverside Arts Market'' (RAM)]] was begun in 2008 beneath the Fuller Warren Bridge around the Northbank Riverwalk. It is open on Saturdays, 10-4 from March to December{{cite news|last=Scanlan|first=Dan|title=Jacksonville's longest-running art festival comes to Mandarin Easter weekend|url=http://jacksonville.com/entertainment/arts/2012-04-05/story/jacksonvilles-longest-running-art-festival-comes-mandarin-easter#ixzz1rud1jLVS|accessdate=13 April 2012|newspaper=Florida Times-Union|date=April 5, 2012}} and features an eclectic mix of vendors offering arts and crafts, food and drink, fruits and vegetables and live entertainment in a family-friendly environment. Eight of the market's vendors have subsequently opened brick & mortar stores or restaurants.{{cite news|last=Patton|first=Charlie|title=Riverside Arts Market back in business for fourth season|url=http://jacksonville.com/entertainment/arts/2012-03-04/story/riverside-arts-market-back-business-fourth-season|accessdate=13 April 2012|newspaper=Florida Times-Union|date=March 12, 2012}} In late June 2009, a 12-foot corner section of concrete walkway on the northbank collapsed due to erosion of the steel bulkhead. Another portion of the riverwalk was closed after bricks became loose when the walkway sank several inches. Repairs to both damaged areas were completed prior to the July 4th celebration and fireworks show. A meeting was held in January, 2010 between [[John Peyton (U.S. politician)|Mayor John Peyton]] and several city councilmen to discuss progress on three major downtown improvement projects, including Southbank Riverwalk replacement. Legislation was filed to fund these three projects with a price tag of $23 million. $11.9 million was allocated to replace the wooden structure with a more durable material with a 40-year life span, and upgrade lighting, railing and trash receptacles.{{cite web|title=Mayor and City Council Members Discuss Implementation of Key Downtown Projects|url=http://www.coj.net/departments/central-operations/public-information/headlines/mayor-and-city-council-members-discuss-implementat.aspx|work=January 8, 2010|publisher=City of Jacksonville|accessdate=10 July 2012}}{{cite news|title=Mayor Pitches Downtown Parks Overhaul|url=http://www.news4jax.com/news/Mayor-Pitches-Downtown-Parks-Overhaul/-/475880/2020776/-/22hr2xz/-/index.html|accessdate=10 July 2012|newspaper=News4Jax|date=January 8, 2010}} On February 9, 2010 the city council passed the three bills without debate, providing final approval for all three projects.{{cite news|last=Mitchell|first=Tia|title=Jacksonville council OKs downtown projects|url=http://jacksonville.com/news/metro/2010-02-09/story/jacksonville_council_oks_downtown_projects|accessdate=11 July 2012|newspaper=Florida Times-Union|date=February 9, 2010}} As of late 2011, the Northbank Riverwalk ran from the [[Fuller Warren Bridge]] to the former Shipyards property, owned by the city of Jacksonville. There are plans to extend it west to Riverside's Memorial Park, and east to [[Metropolitan Park]] across from the stadium. Free parking exists under the Fuller Warren Bridge.{{cite news|last=Littlepage|first=Ron|title=Great Jacksonville Parks: The Northbank Riverwalk|url=http://jacksonville.com/news/florida/2011-11-03/story/great-jacksonville-parks-northbank-riverwalk|accessdate=13 April 2012|newspaper=Florida Times-Union|date=November 3, 2011}} The center of the Northbank Riverwalk is the [[Jacksonville Landing|Landing]]. In 2002, the Jacksonville Track Club partnered with the city in commissioning ''The Runner'', a statue of a sprinting man on the riverwalk.[http://members.virtualtourist.com/m/677a0/ba497/4/ Virtual Tourist--Exploring Jacksonville's Downtown Riverfront] ==Gallery== File:Tupacjax.jpg|Times-Union Center for the Performing Arts, located long the Riverwalk File:BrooklynRiverwalk.jpg|Brooklyn segment of the Riverwalk File:Americancruiselinejax2.jpg| File:Jax FL Chart House Restaurant05.jpg|The Chart House Restaurant located along the Southbank Riverwalk File:BerkmanPlazaJacksonville-Feb2010-b.JPG|Housing alongside the Northbank Riverwalk ==See also== {{Portal|Jacksonville}} * [[Downtown Jacksonville]] * [[Jacksonville Landing]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://apps2.coj.net/parksinternet/parkdetails.asp?parkid=11 Southbank Riverwalk Official website] *[http://apps2.coj.net/parksinternet/parkdetails.asp?parkid=286 Northbank Riverwalk Official website] {{Jacksonville attractions}} [[Category:Tourist attractions in Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:Redeveloped ports and waterfronts in the United States]] [[Category:Parks in Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:Downtown Jacksonville]] [[Category:Northbank, Jacksonville]] [[Category:Southbank, Jacksonville]] [[Category:Brooklyn, Jacksonville]] [[Category:1985 establishments in Florida]]

'''Jan Callewaert''' (born [[Wielsbeke]], 1956) is a [[Belgium|Belgian]] businessman. He is the general manager of [[Option N.V.]] In 2005, he was voted manager of the year in Belgium. He also was the chairman of [[Association football|football]] club [[Oud-Heverlee Leuven]].
==Education== He obtained a Master in commercial sciences and a bachelor in [[philosophy]] at the [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven]]
==Career== * 1980 - 1982: assistant at the [[Vlekho|VLEKHO]] in [[Brussels]]. * 1982 - 1984: system engineer and later product manager at [[Groupe Bull|Bull]]. * 1984 - 1986: [[Ericsson]] telecommunication. * Founded [[Option N.V.|Option International]] in 1986 and starts the production of modems for [[laptop]]s.
==Awards== * 2005: Manager of the year
==Bibliography== * Jan Callewaert, ''Van de hemel naar de hel en weer terug'' (E: From heaven to hell and back again), Lannoo.
==Sources== * [http://vlerickalumni.be/en/events/detail-past.asp?ID=%7BA1A84F61-1BD9-4E83-ADB7-940A8BDFE6AF%7D Lunchcauserie met Jan Callewaert, Option] * [http://antwerpen.gva.be/nieuws-economie/2006/01/11/jan-callewaert-option-is-manager-van-het-jaar-2005.html Jan Callewaert (Option) is Manager van het Jaar 2005]
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}}

{{Infobox person |name = John Biddle |image = John Biddle Filming in 74.jpg |image_size = |alt = |caption = Biddle on location, 1974 |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1925|06|07|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|2008|10|01|1925|06|07|mf=y}} |death_place = [[Middletown, Rhode Island]], [[United States|U.S.]]<ref name="obit"/> |body_discovered = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> |residence = |nationality = |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = |education = |alma_mater = |employer = |occupation = [[yachting]] [[cinematographer]]/[[lecturer]] |years_active = 1956–2002 |home_town = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |opponents = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = |relations = |callsign = |awards = |signature = |signature_alt = |website = |footnotes = |box_width = }}
'''John Scott Biddle''' (1925–2008) was a foremost [[yachting]] [[cinematographer]] and lecturer, establishing a [[filmmaking|film-making]] career that spanned more than forty years. His films captured not only the technical aspects of sailing but also the human story in events as tranquil as a [[Nova Scotia]] cruise and as grand as the [[America's Cup|America's Cup Races]].
==Early life== Biddle was born on June 7, 1925, near [[Philadelphia]], the fourth of five children. His parents, were both from prominent Philadelphia families. His father was Brigadier General Nicholas Biddle (1893–1977), whose great-grandfather was [[Nicholas Biddle (banker)|Nicholas Biddle]], President of the [[Second Bank of the United States]]. His mother was Sarah Lippincott Biddle (1894–1962), whose paternal grandfather Joshua Ballinger Lippincott (1813–1886) founded [[J. B. Lippincott & Co.|J. B. Lippincott Company]], and maternal grandfather [[Joseph Wharton]] (1826–1909) founded the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite news |title= Mrs. Biddle, 68 of Philadelphia: Clubwoman Dies Wife of Insurance Executive |date= July 18, 1962 |newspaper= [[New York Times]] |url= http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50715F83C59137B93CAA8178CD85F468685F9 |accessdate= March 28, 2011 }}</ref> His colorful family included cousins [[Livingston L. Biddle, Jr.]] and [[Anthony Joseph Drexel Biddle, Jr.]]
Biddle’s father served a lifelong term with the [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]], was active in both [[World Wars]], and was a well-noted, [[big-game hunting|big-game hunter]].<ref>{{cite web |title= Biddle Family Papers |work= University of Delaware Library Special collections |url= http://www.lib.udel.edu/ud/spec/findaids/biddle.htm }}</ref> He was commissioned to travel the world and bring back specimens; some of his ‘trophies’ still reside at Philadelphia’s [[Academy of Natural Sciences]]. During Nicholas’ travels, he would film the hunts, then return home and allow young John to experiment with his movie camera and all his unexposed film.{{citation needed |date= March 2011}}
John tinkered further with the camera at his family’s summer home in [[Jamestown, Rhode Island]], where he also mastered the idiosyncrasies of ocean sailing. Focusing on his brothers, sisters and twelve cousins as subjects on and around [[Narragansett Bay]], he refined his choice of angles, composition, containment of action within the frame and editing.<ref name=Shope>{{cite news |title=John Biddle: Film-maker to the sailing world |author= Roger Shope |work= Sailing Magazine |date=July 1982 }}</ref>
==School and military years== Biddle, and his many cousins, attended Meadowbrook School, then went on to [[Kent School]] in Connecticut. He turned 18 in 1943 and served in the infantry during [[World War II]]. A bad tooth sent him to the back of the lines during fighting in [[Belgium]]. There it was noticed that he could play piano and work a movie projector, so he was assigned to entertain the troops. Shortly thereafter, he discovered two thirds of his platoon had been killed in a firefight. His entertaining skills likely had spared his life. They also led to an unlikely occurrence: brother Nicholas Jr., who was fighting in the same region, learned that John was working at the back of the lines and flabbergasted him with a visit.<ref>Biddle, Nicholas, Jr. Flying Through the Years. Parkesburg, Pennsylvania: Treasured Legacies, 2001. pp. 79, 84. Printed for private circulation.</ref> After the war, John attended [[Trinity College (Connecticut)|Trinity College]], then returned overseas to [[Germany]] with the [[First Troop Philadelphia City Cavalry]] during the [[Korean War]].
==Yachting cinematographer== In the 1950s, Biddle spent several years working as an engineer while snapping wedding and baby photos on the side. His father would have liked him to enter the family insurance business, Biddle, Bishop and Smith (now named Biddle & Company), but John saw a different path. After watching a John Jay skiing film, he imagined himself doing the same thing with sailing. The following June he embarked on the 1956 [[Bermuda Race]] aboard cousin Charles Wharton’s 51-foot [[cutter (boat)|cutter]], ''Souvenir'' with his film camera along. He combined that footage with three other pieces he shot that summer, and booked himself into [[yacht clubs]] for his first lecture-show.<ref name=Shope/>
For over four decades, Biddle shot films of [[dinghy]] races, [[Tall Ships]] events and everything in between. Over seventy types of boats were shown in his documentary-style presentations. 16 mm [[Bell and Howell]] in hand, he filmed 130 feet off the deck of [[square rig|square-riggers]] and fifteen feet underwater. He filmed from [[Greenland]] down to the Islands, from [[Greece]] to [[New Zealand]]. He shot ocean races like the [[Fastnet Race]], classic sailing [[regattas]] like the [[Friendship Sloop]] Regatta, [[cruise ship|cruises]], celebrations, native fishboat races, small boat races. To capture viewable images on the rolling, bouncy seas, he used (and later marketed) what he called the Biddlestick – a monopod-like stick which he attached to his movie cameras, allowing him to hold onto deck stays while keeping the camera steady.
In addition to his annual show, Biddle made promotional films for boat manufacturers and sailboat classes, filmed a five-episode TV series for [[Mercury Marine]] called "Let’s Go Boating" narrated by [[Lloyd Bridges]], and occasionally filmed for private clients.<ref name=Bigoney>{{cite news |title= John Biddle: Cinematographer of the Seven Seas |author= Mag Bigoney |work= [[Yachting (magazine)|Yachting Magazine]]|date=December 1972 }}</ref>
[[File:Biddle Lecture.jpg|thumb|Introducing one of his shows, "And away we go to..."]]
==Lecturer== Each year, Biddle would film three to four events in the summer months, edit the mile of film into a 90-minute presentation in the fall, write a script for same, have music pulled for the film and edit the music to fit. In winter, he would begin a five-month tour of the [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[Bermuda]], the [[Caribbean]] (and occasionally [[Europe]] and [[Australia]]) where he would present his films in person as many as 100 times, primarily at [[yacht clubs]]. For many of Biddle's audience, his show presented the only opportunity to see the highlights of the past year's sailing events. One of the great attractions was his ability to catch the amusing and exhilarating aspects of sailing, not only on film, but in his quick-witted, dry-humored delivery peppered with terms like "callapso flapitis", referring to frantic moments on the boat.<ref name=Bigoney/> Biddle was his own [[production company]], performing the tasks of: contact agent, scheduler, [[publicist]], [[copywriter]], photo developer, poster designer, [[accountant]], [[cinematographer]], [[film editor]], [[screenwriter|scriptwriter]], [[music editor]], driver, porter, set-up man and performer.
==Family life== Biddle married Mary McMichael in 1961<ref>{{cite news |title= John Biddle Fiance Of Mary McMichael |newspaper= [[new York Times]] |date= March 15, 1961 |url= http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70A1EFF385912738DDDAC0994DB405B818AF1D3 }}</ref> in Jamestown, Rhode Island and they had two children, Sophie in 1964 and Scott in 1966. Mary assisted John in filming the early [[America's Cup]] races. She had a [[stroke]] shortly after the birth of Scott and died five years later. Following this, Biddle managed to spend time at home with his children while continuing his career on the road and was able to include Sophie and Scott on trips to [[Bermuda]], a cruise to [[Maine]] and trips to various lecture dates. In March 1977, he married Amy McKay van Roden in [[Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania|Bryn Mawr]], Pennsylvania with three stepchildren: Winifred, Peter and Julie.
==Career highlights== Biddle filmed two races multiple times. The [[Bermuda Race]] he sailed 11 times to capture the stories that this pre-eminent, [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]] distance race delivered. Despite the race’s long history and prestige, Biddle is the only [[filmmaker|film-maker]] to have focused on it. He also filmed the international [[yacht racing]] event, the [[America's Cup]], all ten times when [[12-metre class]] boats were used, from 1958 to 1987. For this, he took footage of the [[Sparkman & Stephens]] test tanks, of the spring practices, the summer trials, the [[Newport, Rhode Island]] balls, the dock happenings and the September finals. He was invited to shoot on board the 12-metre yachts by mercurial skippers including [[Ted Turner]], [[Dennis Conner]], [[Ted Hood]] and [[Intrepid (yacht)|Bus Mosbacher]].<ref>{{cite news |title= John Biddle inducted into the America's Cup Hall of Fame |author= Sue Maffei Plowden |newspaper= Jamestown Press |date= May 14, 2009 |url= http://www.jamestownpress.com/news/2009-05-14/News/John_Biddle_inducted_into_the_Americas_Cup_Hall_of.html |accessdate= March 28, 2011}}</ref> The rare invitations were granted because of his [[nautical]] proficiency and ability to get key shots while staying clear of onboard action.
==Final years== After moving to [[Jamestown, Rhode Island|Jamestown]] in 1980, Biddle became active with the Jamestown Community Chorus and directed the town talent show for several years.<ref name="obit"/>
During his career, Biddle created 140 sailing films which he placed into 41 annual [[lecture]] shows from 1956 to 1996. He made over 3,000 presentations to audiences as large as 3,000 people. In the summer of 2008, Biddle was nominated for induction into the [[America's Cup Hall of Fame]] at the [[Herreshoff Marine Museum]] in [[Bristol, Rhode Island]].<ref>{{cite web |title= John Biddle, 2009 Inductee |work= America's Cup Hall of Fame |publisher= [[Herreshoff Marine Museum]] |url= http://www.herreshoff.org/achof/john_biddle.html |accessdate= March 28, 2011 }}</ref> He fell ill with [[cancer]] soon thereafter and died on October 1, 2008 at the age of 83 in [[Middletown, Rhode Island]].<ref name="obit">{{cite news |title= John Scott Biddle, 83 |date= October 9, 2008 |newspaper= The Jamestown Press |url= http://www.jamestownpress.com/news/2008-10-09/obituaries/024.html |accessdate= March 28, 2011 }}</ref> The formal induction ceremony was held in April 2009.<ref>{{cite news |title= America's Cup Hall of Fame 16th Annual Induction: Celebrating John Biddle the 2008 Inductee |work= News release |date= August 26, 2008 |location= Bristol, Rhode Island |url= http://forum.sailingscuttlebutt.com/cgi-bin/gforum.cgi?post=6298 }}</ref> [[Gary Jobson]] said of Biddle’s film-making achievement, “His film archive is one of the most comprehensive and important yachting libraries in existence”.<ref>{{cite web |title= Eight Bells: John Biddle |author= [[Gary Jobson]] |work= Sailing Scuttlebutt web site |date=October 1, 2008 |url= http://forum.sailingscuttlebutt.com/cgi-bin/gforum.cgi?post=6482 |accessdate= March 28, 2011 }}</ref>
