{{Infobox person | name = John Jacob Astor VI | image = John Jacob Astor VI.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date|1912|8|14}} | birth_place = [[New York City, New York]], U.S. | home_town = [[Newport, Rhode Island]], U.S. | residence = Miami Beach, Florida, U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1992|6|26|1912|8|14}} | death_place = [[Miami Beach, Florida]] U.S. | death_cause = | resting_place = [[Trinity Church Cemetery]], New York City, New York, U.S. | occupation = [[International Mercantile Marine Co.|International Mercantile Marine Company]] | known_for = "Titanic Baby" | education = [[St. George's School, Newport|St. George's School]] | alma_mater = [[Harvard University]] | spouse = {{marriage|Ellen Tuck French
|1934|1943|reason=div}}
{{marriage|Gertrude Gretsch
|1944|1954|reason=div}}
{{marriage|Dolores Margaret Fullman
|1954|1955|reason=div}}
{{marriage|Sue Sandford
|1956|1985|reason=her death}} | children = William Backhouse Astor III
Mary Jacqueline Astor | parents = [[John Jacob Astor IV]]
[[Madeleine Astor|Madeleine Talmage Force]] | relatives = See [[Astor family]] }} '''John Jacob "Jakey" Astor VI''' (August 14, 1912 – June 26, 1992) was an American socialite, shipping businessman, and member of the [[Astor family]]. He was dubbed the "''Titanic'' Baby" for his affiliation with the [[RMS Titanic|RMS ''Titanic'']]; Astor was born four months after his father, Colonel [[John Jacob Astor IV]], died in the [[Sinking of the RMS Titanic|sinking of the ''Titanic'']]; his pregnant mother [[Madeleine Astor]] survived the sinking.{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2270&dat=19150603&id=I2EmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=F0sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3991,2953356 | title=Jack Astor, the Titanic Baby | publisher=The Ellensburg Democrat}} Astor was known for his legal battles with the estate of his elder half-brother, [[Vincent Astor]], to inherit a larger portion of their father's $85 million fortune (approximately equivalent to ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|0.085|1912|r=1}}}} billion in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars).{{inflation-fn|US}} He was also known for his many engagements and four marriages to prominent society women. ==Early life== John Jacob Astor VI was born at [[Caroline Astor House|840 Fifth Avenue]] in [[New York City]] on August 14, 1912. He was the son of Colonel [[John Jacob Astor IV|John Jacob "Jack" Astor IV]] (1864–1912) and socialite [[Madeleine Astor|Madeleine Talmage Force]] (1893–1940). Jakey's parents' marriage, on September 9, 1911, had sparked much controversy both because of their 29-year age difference and since Colonel Astor had only previously been divorced from his first wife, socialite [[Ava Lowle Willing]] (1868–1958), one year earlier, on March 5, 1910. The newlyweds were returning home aboard the ''Titanic'' after about three months of honeymooning in [[Kingdom of Egypt|Egypt]] and [[Europe]]. Madeleine was five months pregnant with Jakey when her husband put her in one of the ship's lifeboats. She was rescued eight hours after her husband went down with the ship. After Jack's death, Madeleine raised their son at the Astors' Newport, Rhode Island, mansion, [[Beechwood (Astor mansion)|Beechwood]], as part of the Astor family. She would later remarry to banker William Karl Dick (1888–1953) in June 1916, and boxer [[Enzo Fiermonte]] (1908–1993) in November 1933. Through Dick, she would have two more sons: William Force Dick (1917–1961) and John Henry Dick II (1919–1995).{{cite web|title=WILLIAM DICK DIES; AN INDUSTRIALIST|url=http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/william-dick-dies-an-industrialist.html|work=encyclopedia titanica|publisher=New York Times}} Fiermonte taught her sons boxing. Jakey, who had become close to Dick, highly opposed the union with Fiermonte and repeatedly tried to convince his mother to end the relationship. He and his mother frequently argued over the union. This caused a rift between the two, though they later reconciled within several months of the marriage. When asked if his mother was marrying Fiermonte, he responded "Unfortunately, it's true". Jakey graduated from [[St. George's School, Newport|St. George's School]] in [[Middletown, Rhode Island]] and from [[Harvard University]].{{cite web | url=http://www.titanic-passengers.com/madeleineastor.htm | title=Madeleine Astor | publisher=titanic-passengers.com}} ==Inheritance== Under the terms of Colonel Astor's will, Madeleine received relatively little from her husband's $85 million estate (approximately equivalent to ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|0.085|1912|r=1}}}} billion in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars).{{inflation-fn|US}}{{cite web|title=Astor Bequests Have All Been Paid|url=http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/astor-bequests-have-all-been-paid.html|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=20 April 2012}} This value included his estate in Rhinebeck and his yacht, the ''[[USS Noma (SP-131)|Noma]]''. [[Vincent Astor|William Vincent Astor]] (1891–1959), the Colonel's son from his first marriage, received $69 million (about ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|0.069|1912|r=1}}}} billion in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars), while the Colonel's daughter from his first marriage, [[Ava Alice Muriel Astor]] (1902–1956), received a $10 million trust fund (about ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|10|1912|r=-1}}}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars). The Colonel's 19-year-old widow Madeleine received the annual income from a $5 million trust fund (about ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|5|1912|r=-1}}}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars), sweetened by an annual payment of $500,000 (about ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|0.5|1912|r=0}}}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars), as well as use of his New York mansion 65th & Fifth Avenue, all its furnishings, and his Newport mansion [[Beechwood (mansion)|Beechwood]] and all of its furnishings, the pick of whichever luxury limo she wanted from his collection, and five of his prized horses, provided that she did not remarry. While not listed by name, his father's will mentioned that any surviving child other than his children Vincent and Ava would receive a bequest of $3 million, to be held in trust until the child reached age 21.{{cite news| url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/08/15/100374187.pdf| title=Son for Mrs. Astor; Named for Father| work=[[The New York Times]]| date=August 15, 1912| accessdate=2013-06-17| publisher=NYTimes.com| format=PDF}}{{cite web|title=Astor Estate Goes To Son|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QupgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=u2MNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2415,1723472&dq=madeleine+force+astor&hl=en|publisher=The Evening News|date=7 May 1912}} Jakey inherited the $3 million on his 21st birthday, which by that point had grown to $5 million (about ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|5|1933|r=0}}}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars).{{inflation-fn|US}} When Madeleine died in late March 1940, she left him a diamond solitaire ring worth $50,000 (about ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|50000|1940|r=-4}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars) and a pearl necklace worth $1,525 (about ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|1525|1940|r=-1}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars). Elder half-brother Vincent's contempt for Madeleine led him to believe that Jakey was not even a biological Astor. Having despised his younger half-brother since birth, Vincent left him nothing in his will.{{cite web|title=Part II: Vincent, the Astor Who Gave Away the Money|url=http://www.newyorksocialdiary.com/node/317873/print|publisher=NewYorkSocialDaily|accessdate=6 August 2013}} Jakey felt cheated and resentfully stated Vincent "had the legal, not the moral right to keep all the money".{{cite book|last=Wilson|first=Andrew|title=Shadow of the Titanic: The Extraordinary Stories of Those Who Survived|year=2012|publisher=Simon and Schuster}} After Vincent died childless in early February 1959, Jakey sued Vincent's widow [[Brooke Astor|Roberta Brooke Russell]] (1902—2007) to inherit his money. He was convinced that Vincent was "mentally incompetent" when signing his last will in June 1958 due to alcoholism, though Brooke insisted Vincent was "fully competent". While Vincent was hospitalized, Brooke would often bring him liquor. Jakey accused her of using the liquor to influence the will in her favor. Jakey ended up settling for $250,000 (about ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|0.25|1959|r=1}}}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars). The rest of money remained with the Vincent Astor foundation and Brooke.{{cite book|last=Gordon|first=Meryl|title=Mrs. Astor Regrets: The Hidden Betrayals of a Family Beyond Reproach|year=2008|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt}} ==Personal life== Astor became engaged to Eileen Sherman Gillespie (1915–2008), the elder daughter of Lieutenant Lawrence Lewis Gillespie (1876–1940) and Irene Muriel Augusta Sherman (1887–1972), in early December 1933. Irene's parents were businessman [[William Watts Sherman]] (1842–1912) and Sophia Augusta Brown (1867–1947).{{cite web|last=Van Deusen|first=Mary S.|title=Eileen Sherman Gillespie|url=http://www.iment.com/maida/friends/eileen/index.htm|publisher=iment.com|accessdate=2009}} They planned to marry on February 6, 1934. However, she called off the wedding on January 22, 1934, after a bitter argument. Heartbroken, he went to [[Shanghai]] shortly afterwards to grieve, returning to America in early May 1934. Astor blamed her parents for interfering with the relationship. He once suggested they could potentially reconcile, stating "I was willing to marry her, and if I were to think about it, I might still be willing to marry her."{{cite book|last=Davis|first=Deborah|title=Gilded: How Newport Became America's Richest Resort|year=2009|publisher=John Wiley & Sons}} Eileen's daughter Marguerite "Margy" Slocum later said of him: "She felt that he had grown up lonely... He was a bit eccentric, and she felt he wasn't mature enough to get married."{{cite web|title=John Jermain Slocum|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/98862260|publisher=Find a Grave|date=October 14, 2012}}{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/01/us/01slocum.html | work=New York Times | title=Eileen G. Slocum, 92, Dies| author=Bruce Weber| date=1 August 2008}} A few weeks after returning from Shanghai, he became engaged to Eileen's close friend socialite Ellen Tuck "Tucky" French (1915–1974), the elder daughter of Francis Ormond "Frank" French II (1888–1962) and Eleanor Livingston Burrill (1891–1974).{{cite web| title=Francis Ormond FRENCH/Eleanor Livingston BURRILL| url=http://www.pennock.ws/surnames/fam/fam40565.html| publisher=pennock}} They married on June 30, 1934, at Trinity Church in [[Newport, Rhode Island]].{{cite web|last=Porter|first=Russell B.|title=JOHN JACOB ASTOR WEDS ELLEN FRENCH|url=http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/john-jacob-astor-weds-ellen-french.html|work=Encyclopedia Titanica|publisher=New York Times}} Tucky was a first cousin of Rhode Island Governor [[William Henry Vanderbilt III]] (1901–1981), and had previously been attracted to Jakey while he was engaged to Eileen. Along with Eileen's sister Phyllis, Tucky was scheduled to be a bridesmaid at Jakey and Eileen's wedding. Together, the couple had one son before divorcing in May 1943.{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2206&dat=19561115&id=qq0yAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CuwFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2856,5506589 | title=Gertrude Versus Dolly 'Which Wife's Legal?' Astor Asks N.Y. Court | publisher=The Miami News}} * William Backhouse Astor III (1935–2008), who was an investment banker. He married and later divorced Charlotte Ann Fisk (1936–2008), daughter of Earl Ellsworth Fisk and Florence Leavitt.{{cite web| title=Obituaries: Charlotte A. Fisk| url=http://www.meaningfulfunerals.net/fh/obituaries/obituary.cfm?o_id=277937&fh_id=10485| date=13 October 2008| publisher=meaningfulfunerals.net}} At the time of their son's birth, Jakey was working at the [[International Mercantile Marine Co.]]{{cite news|last=Baber|first=Mark|title=MRS. JOHN J. ASTOR GIVES BIRTH TO SON|url=http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/mrs-john-j-astor-gives-birth-son.html|publisher=NY Times|date=20 July 1935}} Another of Tucky's sisters, Virginia Middleton French (1917–2011),{{cite web|title=William Force Dick + Virginia Middleton French|url=http://www.ourfamtree.org/browse.php/Virginia-Middleton-French/p477144|publisher=Our Family Tree}} would marry William Force Dick, Astor's half-brother through his mother, on December 18, 1941, before her marriage to Philip B. Pool.{{cite web|title=VIRGINIA POOL Obituary|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/nytimes/obituary.aspx?n=virginia-pool&pid=153527551|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=September 9, 2011}} The two had respectively served as matron of honor and usher to Astor and Tucky's wedding. Astor served as an usher and Tucky was matron of honor to Virginia and William's wedding.{{cite web|title=Virginia M. French Has Twelve Attendants At Her Marriage Here to William F. Dick|url=http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/virginia-french-marriage-william-dick.html|publisher=New York Times|date=December 19, 1941}} Virginia and Vincent were appointed as the godparents of William Backhouse Astor III.{{cite news|title=ASTOR INFANT CHRISTENED|url=http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/astor-infant-christened.html|publisher=New York Times|date=January 15, 1936}} On September 18, 1944, in New York City,{{cite news |title=J. J. Astor Marries Gertrude Gretsch. Son of the Late Colonel John Jacob Astor IV Weds Alumna of Finch at Her Home |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1944/09/19/archives/j-j-astor-marries-gertrude-gretsch-son-of-the-late-colonel-john.html |quote=..... of the Late Colonel John Jacob Astor IV Weds Alumna of Finch at Her Home The..... Mr. Astor is the son of the late Col John Jacob Astor IV, who lost his life..... |work=The New York Times |date=19 September 1944 |accessdate=2009-02-16}} he married for the second time to Gertrude Gretsch (1923–1999),{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/20/classified/paid-notice-deaths-coletti-perucca-gertrude-gretsch.html | title=Paid Notice: Deaths COLETTI, PERUCCA, GERTRUDE GRETSCH | publisher=The New York Times | date=20 January 1999}} the daughter of Walter and Gertrude Gretsch.{{cite web|last=Gretsch|first=Fred|title=Gretsch Family Connection to Titanic Passengers|url=http://blog.gretsch.com/tag/john-jacob-astor/|accessdate=6 August 2013}} Their marriage ended in divorce on August 2, 1954, after being separated for four years, though the Mexican divorce was ruled invalid in 1956. An American divorce soon followed.{{cite news |title=Astor Seeking Divorce. John J. Files Suit in Mexico Against Second Wife|url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=84615041&sid=1&Fmt=2&clientId=56233&RQT=309&VName=HNP |publisher=The New York Times |date=July 3, 1954 |accessdate=2009-02-16}} Before their separation and divorce, the couple had a daughter: * Mary Jacqueline "Jackie" Astor (b. 1949),{{cite news|last=Curtis|first=Charlotte|title=Newport Party Resembled Reunion Of John Jacob Astor's Relatives|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=August 22, 1967}} who married John Rozet Drexel IV (b. 1945), a son of John Rozet Drexel III (1919–2007) and Mildred Sophia Noreen Stonor (1922–2012), in 1984. John is a 2x great-grandson of banker [[Anthony Joseph Drexel]] and a grandson of [[Ralph Stonor, 5th Baron Camoys]]. On August 6, 1954, Astor married for the third time to Dolores Margaret "Dolly" Fullman (born c. 1928) in [[Arlington, Virginia]]. For the 26 year old Dolly, it was her second marriage. They separated soon after returning from their honeymoon and divorced.{{cite news| title=Astor's Name Taken from Social Register| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xU1UAAAAIBAJ&sjid=zDoNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5713,6171006&dq=astor+social+register&hl=en| work=[[St. Joseph News-Press]]| date=27 November 1954| page=2| agency=[[United Press International|United Press]]| accessdate=2013-06-17| location=Missouri}}{{cite news |title=Milestones: Married |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,820052,00.html?iid=digg_share |quote=John Jacob Astor VI, 42, whose fortune, inherited from his great-great-grandfather, is estimated at $70 million; and Dolores Margaret "Dolly" Fullman, 26, blonde Miami divorcee; he for the third time, she for the second; in Arlington, Va. |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |publisher=Time.com |date=16 August 1954}} Astor married his fourth, and final wife, Sue Sandford in 1956. They remained married until her death in 1985. Astor died in [[Miami Beach, Florida]], in 1992 at the age of 79. His body was returned to New York for burial with his parents in the [[Trinity Church Cemetery]].{{cite web| title=Myth #3: There are a lot of Astors buried in the churchyard| url=http://www.trinitywallstreet.org/news/blogs/the-archivists-mailbag/myth-3-there-are-a-lot-of-astors-buried-in-the-churchyard| publisher=Trinity Wall Street| date=19 January 2012}} At the time of his death, he was survived by his son, daughter, three grandsons, and younger half-brother.{{cite news|title=John J. Astor 5th, 79; Son of Builder of Hotel|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/06/27/obituaries/john-j-astor-5th-79-son-of-builder-of-hotel.html|accessdate=17 August 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=27 June 1992}} ===Descendants=== {{main|Astor family}} Through his son, Astor was a grandfather to two boys, William Backhouse Astor IV (b. 1959) and Gregory Todd Astor (b. 1966) who portrayed Colonel Astor in ''Titanic the Musical'' in April 2012{{cite web|last=Hallenbeck|first=Brent|title=Born to Play the Role|url=http://www.burlingtonfreepress.com/article/20120202/ENT/120320026/|publisher=[[The Burlington Free Press]]|date=March 20, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131204042233/http://www.burlingtonfreepress.com/article/20120202/ENT/120320026/|archivedate=December 4, 2013|df=}} Gregory married Robin Rhodes, and together, they have three children: Alexandra Ellen "Allie" Astor (b. 1997), Rebecca Charlotte "Becca" Astor (b. 1998), and Stephen William Astor (b. 2002).{{cite news| title=William Backhouse Astor III | work=[[The Burlington Free Press]]| location=[[Vermont]]| date=20 September 2008| publisher=Scroggin(s) Obituaries & News}} Through his daughter, Astor was a grandfather to Nicholas Astor Drexel (b. 1988).{{cite web|title=John R. Drexel III|url=http://www.newportdailynews.com/ee/newportdailynews/?pageToLoad=showObits.php&obit_date=200704&obit_file=0974-drexel.txt|publisher=Newport Daily News|accessdate=April 2007}}{{cite web|last=Gorrow|first=Chelsea|title=Astor family coming to city's birthday party|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2015856475_aporastoriabicentennial1stldwritethru.html|publisher=Seattle Times|accessdate=8 August 2011}} ==In popular culture== Astor's name is shown on one of the page buttons on an apartment building in [[Mel Brooks]]' 2005 [[movie musical]] ''[[The Producers (2005 film)|The Producers]]''. ===Name confusion=== Even though some sources refer to Jakey as John Jacob V, [[John Jacob Astor, 1st Baron Astor of Hever]] (1886–1971) was born first and therefore is actually John Jacob Astor V. Jakie Astor (1918–2000), youngest brother of [[David Astor]], was [[Jakie Astor|John Jacob Astor VII]]; the 3rd Baron Astor of Hever is [[John Astor, 3rd Baron Astor of Hever|John Jacob Astor VIII]]. Jakey is sometimes (incorrectly) referred to as John Jacob III. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * [[Louis Nizer]] (1961/1963), ''[[My Life in Court]]'', reprint, New York: Pyrmamid, Chapter 2, "Divorce", pp. 252–263. {{DEFAULTSORT:Astor, John Jacob Vi}} [[Category:1912 births]] [[Category:1992 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American Episcopalians]] [[Category:Astor family|John Jacob]] [[Category:Livingston family]] [[Category:Schermerhorn family]] [[Category:American socialites]] [[Category:RMS Titanic's crew and passengers]] [[Category:RMS Titanic survivors]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:St. George's School, Newport alumni]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:Burials at Trinity Church Cemetery]]

revision.comment: /* External links */ templated some resources; removed 1 link per [[WP:ELNO]]
revision.text:
The term "'''knowledge commons'''" refers to information, data, and content that is collectively owned and managed by a community of users, particularly over the Internet. What distinguishes a knowledge commons from a [[commons]] of shared physical resources is that digital resources are [[Rivalry (economics)|non-subtractible]]; that is, multiple users can access the same digital resources with no effect on their quantity or quality.<ref name="ostrom">{{cite book |title= Understanding Knowledge as a Commons - From Theory to Practice |url=https://net.educause.edu/ir/library/pdf/EQM07412.pdf|last= Hess |first= Charlotte |author2=Ostrom, Elinor |year= 2007 |publisher= Massachusetts Institute of Technology |location= Cambridge |isbn= 978-0-262-08357-7 |pages= 12–13}}</ref>
== Conceptual background ==
The term 'commons' is derived from the medieval economic system ''[[the commons]]''. Today, the knowledge commons act as a frame of reference for a number of domains, including [[open education|Open Educational]] resources such as the MIT [[OpenCourseware]], free digital media such as Wikipedia, [[Creative commons]]–licensed art, open-source research,<ref>Joshua M. Pearce, "[https://www.academia.edu/1861756/Open_Source_Research_in_Sustainability Open Source Research in Sustainability]", ''Sustainability: the Journal of Record'', '''5'''(4), pp. 238-243, 2012. [https://dx.doi.org/10.1089/sus.2012.9944 DOI] [https://mtu.academia.edu/JoshuaPearce/Papers/1867941/Open_Source_Research_in_Sustainability free and open access]</ref> and open scientific collections such as the [[Public Library of Science]] or the [[Science Commons]], [[Free Software]] and [[Open Design]]. According to research by Charlotte Hess and [[Elinor Ostrom]],<ref name="ostrom"/> the conceptual background of the knowledge commons encompasses two intellectual histories: first, a European tradition of battling the enclosure of the "intangible commons of the mind",<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Boyle |first1=James |year=2003 |title=The Second Enclosure Movement and the Construction of the Public Domain |journal=Law and Contemporary Problems |publisher= |volume=66 |issue=1-2 |pages=33–74 |url=http://www.law.duke.edu/journals/66LCPBoyle |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101123190230/http://www.law.duke.edu/journals/66LCPBoyle/ |archivedate=2010-11-23 |df= }}</ref> threatened by expanding intellectual property rights and privatization of knowledge. Second, a tradition rooted in the United States, which sees the knowledge commons as a shared space allowing for free speech and democratic practices, and which is in the tradition of the town commons movement and commons-based production of scholarly work, [[open science]], open libraries, and collective action.<ref name="ostrom"/>
The production of works in the knowledge commons is often driven by [[collective intelligence]] respectively the wisdom of crowds and is related to knowledge communism as it was defined by [[Robert K. Merton]], according to whom scientists give up [[intellectual property rights]] in exchange for recognition and esteem.
Ferenc Gyuris argues, that it is important to distinguish "information" from "knowledge" in defining the term "knowledge commons". He argues that "knowledge as a shared resource" requires that both information must become accessible and potential recipients must become able and willing to internalize it as 'knowledge'. ''"Therefore, knowledge cannot become a shared resource without a complex set of institutions and practices that give the opportunity to potential recipients to gain the necessary abilities and willingness"''.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Gyuris |first1= Ferenc |year= 2014 |title= Basic education in communist Hungary. A commons approach |journal= International Journal of the Commons |publisher= |volume= 8 |issue= 2 |pages= 531–553 |url= http://www.thecommonsjournal.org/index.php/ijc/article/view/458/401 |doi=10.18352/ijc.458}}</ref>
== Copyleft ==
A main principle of the knowledge commons is that the traditional "[[copyright]]" is being replaced by "[[copyleft]]". Copyleft licenses grant licensees all necessary rights such as right to study, use, change and redistribute—under the condition that all future works building on the license are again kept in the commons. The most popular applications of the 'copyleft' principle are the [[GNU]] Software Licenses (GPL, LGPL and GFDL by Free Software Foundation) and the [[share-alike]] licenses under [[creative commons]].
== See also == * [[Commons]] * [[Digital commons (economics)]] * [[Information Commons]] * [[Noogenesis]] * [[Open Knowledge]] * [[Open Content]] * [[Public ownership]] * [[Open Source]] * [[Open source appropriate technology]] * [[Open Design]] * [[OpenCourseware]] * [[Robert K. Merton]] * [[Commons-based peer production]]
== Notes == <references/>
== External links ==
* {{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H3N9Gb3bKzQ |title=Commons in Action: Knowledge Commons |publisher=[[International Association for the Study of the Commons]] |year=3 September 2014 |via=YouTube}} * {{cite journal |url=http://www.ercim.eu/publication/Ercim_News/enw66/ioannidis.html |title=From Digital Libraries to Knowledge Commons |first=Yannis |last=Ioannidis |date=July 2006 |journal=ERCIM News |issue=66 |publisher=ERCIM}} * {{cite book |url=http://www.idlo.int/publications/TraditionalKnowledge.pdf |title=Imagining a Traditional Knowledge Commons: A community approach to sharing traditional knowledge for non-commercial research |last=Abrell |first=Elan |display-authors=etal |editor-last=Dunlop |editor-first=Scott |date=October 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017012523/https://www.idlo.int/publications/TraditionalKnowledge.pdf |archive-date=2013-10-17}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.knowledgecommons.org/ |title=Open Knowledge Commons |website=KnowledgeCommons.org |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121231084634/http://www.knowledgecommons.org/ |archive-date=2012-12-31}} * [http://biogov.uclouvain.be/iasc/ First Thematic Conference on the Knowledge Commons] held in 2012 on the theme of "Governing Pooled Knowledge Resources: Building Institutions for Sustainable Scientific, Cultural and Genetic Resource Commons" * [http://floksociety.org/ Free/Libre Open Knowledge Society, designing a world for the commons.]: A Free, Libre, Open Knowledge society is about to be built in Ecuador.
{{Open navbox}} {{Property navbox}}
[[Category:Public commons]] [[Category:Open content]] [[Category:Social information processing]] [[Category:Intellectual property law]] [[Category:Economics of intellectual property]] [[Category:Knowledge economy]] [[Category:Free culture movement]]

[[File:Sheep Ship 2.jpg|thumb|Purpose-built sheep carrier]] '''Live export''' is the commercial transport of [[livestock]] across national borders. The trade involves a number of countries with the [[Australian live export industry]] being one of the largest exporters in the global trade. According to the [[Australian Bureau of Statistics]], exports of live sheep rose 21.4% and live calves increased 9.7% between March 2017 and March 2018. During 2017 alone, Australia exported 2.85 million living animals in shipping containers and airplanes.{{cite web|title='This one has heat stress': the shocking reality of live animal exports |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/jul/30/this-one-has-heat-stress-the-shocking-reality-of-live-animal-exports}} The expansion of the trade has been supported by the introduction of purpose-built ships which carry large numbers of animals. The amount of livestock exported from the [[European Union]] grew to nearly 586m kilograms between 2014 and 2017, a 62.5% increase during the time period. There has been strong criticism of the industry on animal rights grounds. [[New Zealand]] has effectively phased out live exports for slaughter purposes since 2007 due to concerns about animals.{{cite web|url=http://www.banliveexport.com/facts/frequently-asked-questions.php|title=Is it true that New Zealand has banned live export?}} __TOC__ ==European Union legislation== The EU introduced new legislation in 2004, which was planned to come into force in 2007. Agriculture Ministers from individual states who make up the Council however, have deferred decisions on a package of reforms, including journey times, until 2011. They have adopted some reforms that offer more training and certification for drivers by 2009.[http://ciwf.org.uk/what_we_do/live_transport/european_campaign.aspx Compassion in World Farming - The Campaign in Europe] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120083045/http://www.ciwf.org.uk/what_we_do/live_transport/european_campaign.aspx |date=2008-11-20 }} The legislation was also written with the aim of covering better loading and unloading facilities. ==United Kingdom== Between 15 July 2002 and January 2004, around 200,000 lambs and sheep were exported for slaughter or further fattening abroad, mainly to France and Italy.[http://www.ciwf.org.uk/publications/reports/live_exports_2000.pdf CIWF Report 2000] The [[Animal and Plant Health Agency]] (APHA) is responsible for conducting inspections of animals at the point of loading and at ports. [[Trading Standards]] also has powers to inspect animals during transport, and is responsible for carrying out any prosecutions under the regulations. The Port of [[Ramsgate]] temporarily halted live transport after an incident in 2012, when 40 sheep were euthanised after being badly injured during transit. The decision was overturned by the High Court on the grounds that the port could not ban live animal exports on the grounds of freedom of movement with the EU and UK legislation. After his appointment as Secretary of State for the Environment, Farming and Rural Affairs, [[Michael Gove]] indicated in July 2017 that [[Brexit]] would offer the opportunity to ban live animal export for slaughter.[http://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/CBP-8031 Live Animal Exports within the European Union 4 Jul 2017] ==Australia== {{Main article|Australian live export industry}} Australia is one of the world's largest exporters of sheep and cattle. According to [[Meat and Livestock Australia]], 2.44 million sheep were exported to markets in Asia and the Middle East in 2012,[http://www.mla.com.au/Prices-and-markets/Trends-and-analysis/Sheepmeat-and-lamb/Forecasts/MLA-sheep-industry-projections-2013/11-live-sheep-exports MLA sheep industry projections - live sheep exports] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130513193601/http://www.mla.com.au/Prices-and-markets/Trends-and-analysis/Sheepmeat-and-lamb/Forecasts/MLA-sheep-industry-projections-2013/11-live-sheep-exports |date=2013-05-13 }} reduced from 4.2 million in 2008.[http://www.livecorp.com.au/sheep-statistics LiveCorp - Sheep Statistics] The total number of cattle exported in 2012 was 617, 301, down 11% from the previous year. Indonesia accounted for 45% of total live cattle exports from Australia in 2012. Total cattle exports to Indonesia reduced by 33% from 2011.[http://www.mla.com.au/Prices-and-markets/Trends-and-analysis/Beef/Live-exports Meat and Livestock Australia - Live Exports] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511203652/http://www.mla.com.au/Prices-and-markets/Trends-and-analysis/Beef/Live-exports |date=2013-05-11 }} The reduction in cattle exports to Indonesia in 2012 was partly due to the newly imposed ESCAS (Exporter Supply Chain Assurance Scheme) from 2011, and partly due to Indonesia's move to become self-sufficient in beef production[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/jakarta-fires-new-shots-in-cattle-war/story-fn59niix-1226477655995 The Australian "Jakarta fires new shots in cattle war" 20 September 2012] Most of the livestock are for human consumption but there is also an active trade in breeding stock, including dairy cattle. The [[Department of Agriculture and Water Resources]] controls the Australian Standards for the Export of Livestock. The standards were amended in April 2011 (version 2.3).[http://www.daff.gov.au/animal-plant-health/welfare/export-trade/livestock-export-standards Australian Standards for the Export of Livestock (Version 2.3) April 2011] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130426170037/http://www.daff.gov.au/animal-plant-health/welfare/export-trade/livestock-export-standards |date=2013-04-26 }} The Department also introduced ESCAS (Exporter Supply Chain Assurance Scheme), in 2011 — a system requiring exporters to provide evidence of compliance with internationally agreed animal welfare standards, and to demonstrate traceability and control through the supply chain.[http://www.daff.gov.au/biosecurity/export/live-animals/livestock/escas#overview Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (Australia) Overview of Exporter Supply Chain Assurance System (ESCAS)] According to the Department, ESCAS was developed in response to evidence of cruelty to Australian cattle in Indonesia, and then extended to all livestock exports for the purpose of slaughter.[http://www.daff.gov.au/biosecurity/export/live-animals/livestock/escas#general Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (Australia) General information about ESCAS arrangements] [[#In Australian live export|See Animal Welfare section]]. [[AQIS]] ([[Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service]]) manages quarantine controls to minimise the risk of exotic pests and diseases entering the country. [[AQIS]] also provides import and export inspection and certification to help retain Australia's highly favourable animal, plant and human health status and wide access to overseas export markets. Other key markets include Israel, Malaysia, Japan, Mexico and China.[http://www.mla.com.au/NR/rdonlyres/ED5DA007-A196-4283-B731-FB9B8F4EE204/0/FastfactsBeef2006.pdf MLA markets for Australian live exports] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060921025117/http://www.mla.com.au/NR/rdonlyres/ED5DA007-A196-4283-B731-FB9B8F4EE204/0/FastfactsBeef2006.pdf |date=2006-09-21 }} The major markets for [[Australian sheep]] are Kuwait and Jordan. Other key markets are Bahrain, the UAE, Oman and Qatar. Australia's main market competitors are from China, South America and North Africa. ==New Zealand== In 2005, New Zealand exported NZ$217 million worth of live animals, mainly for breeding purposes. Exports included cattle, sheep, horses, deer, goats and day-old chicks. Because New Zealand is free from most exotic diseases most livestock shipments are for breeding or finishing purposes. Cattle are not exported for slaughter and the last export of sheep for slaughter was in 2003. In November 2007, the New Zealand Government introduced the new Customs Exports Prohibition (Livestock for Slaughter) Order. Although not a blanket ban, the new legal requirement restricts live animal exports for slaughter unless the risks to animals and New Zealand's trade reputation can be adequately managed. There has been no export of live animals for slaughter purposes since that date.{{cite web|url=http://www.banliveexport.com/facts/frequently-asked-questions.php|title=Is it true that New Zealand has banned live export? |publisher=[[Animals Australia]] |work=Ban Live Export}} ==Animal welfare== Live exports have been subject to scrutiny by animal welfare groups around the world. === United Kingdom === In the United Kingdom, animal welfare group [[Compassion in World Farming]] has named live exports of sheep and cattle “cruel and unnecessary”.[http://www.ciwf.org.uk/what_we_do/live_transport/live_exports_from_the_uk_must_stop.aspx CIWF - Live Exports From the UK Must Stop] Most UK live animal exports currently ship out of the Port of Ramsgate. In June 2011 a Ramsgate Town Councillor, Ian Driver, spoke out in opposition to live exports.[http://www.ciwf.org.uk/news/transport_of_live_animals/great_turnout_for_ban_live_export_meeting_in_ramsgate.aspx CIWF - Media Release] On September 12, 2012, 46 sheep were euthanised after injuries inflicted due to transportation faults at the Port of Ramsgate. A temporary suspension on live exports from the Port was called by the Thanet Council.[http://action.ciwf.org.uk/ea-action/action?ea.client.id=119&ea.campaign.id=16369&ea.tracking.id=1174f49c CIWF - Urgent: The End of UK Live Exports?] === New Zealand === New Zealand has partaken in no live animal exports for slaughter since 2003, after 4000 sheep died on a ship bound for [[Saudi Arabia]]. In 2012, the President of the [[Federated Farmers of New Zealand]] was quoted as saying:
{{cquote|The worry we had is the repetitional risk of a very small number of sheep being transported live to other parts of the world was just too great against the very large processed export industry we have with sheep meat.{{cite news| title = NZ live sheep ban due to continued risk| publisher = ABC Rural| url = http://www.abc.net.au/rural/news/content/201211/s3629051.htm | date =2012-09-11 |accessdate = 2013-11-04}}}}
[[Animal welfare groups in New Zealand]] continue to call for a ban on live export of animals for breeding purposes. [[SAFE (organisation)|SAFE]] has stated that live exports pose “potential for serious suffering."{{cite news |title = New zealand dairy cows to be exported to china |publisher = SAFE |url = http://safe.org.nz/Campaigns/Ban-Live-Sheep-Exports/ |date = January 2013 |accessdate = 2013-11-04 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130617101224/http://safe.org.nz/Campaigns/Ban-Live-Sheep-Exports/ |archivedate = 2013-06-17 |df = }} === Australia=== Australia's live export industry has experienced significant scrutiny by animal welfare groups since 2003. The RSPCA is opposed to live export.{{cite web |url=http://www.rspca.org.au/campaigns/live-export |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-09-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140923104024/http://www.rspca.org.au/campaigns/live-export |archivedate=2014-09-23 |df= }} Over 550,000 animals are reported to have died en route during live export journeys between 2000-2012.[http://www.daff.gov.au/animal-plant-health/welfare/export-trade/mortalities Livestock Mortalities for Export by Sea - Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130426170041/http://www.daff.gov.au/animal-plant-health/welfare/export-trade/mortalities |date=2013-04-26 }} A 2006 Freedom of Information report revealed sheep died on route due to several factors including heat stress, septicaemia and acute pneumonia.[http://liveexport-indefensible.com/foi_reports.php Damning Live Export Reports Obtained Through Freedom of Information] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130410005233/http://liveexport-indefensible.com/foi_reports.php |date=2013-04-10 }} Dr Lynn Simpson, a former on-board vet for the live export industry, made a submission to the Department of Agriculture in March 2013 condemning animal welfare conditions on live export ships.[http://www.vale.org.au/uploads/1/0/4/3/10438895/vale_press_release_130312.pdf VALE - Media Release | date =2013-12-03] A group of former live export vets - Veterinarians Against Live Export (VALE) has formed to oppose the trade.http://www.vale.org.au/ Prominent former live export veterinarians who have spoken out against the conditions on ships include Dr Lloyd Reeve Johnson, who expressed his concern about the conflict of interest involved in live export companies paying for animal welfare advice,http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/vet-worried-about-dodgy-inspections-of-live-exports/story-fn59niix-1226093400993 Dr Tony Hill, who was allegedly pressured to report 105 mortalities when in fact 2000 sheep had died,http://www.vale.org.au/in-depth.html and Dr Kerkenezov, who has urged an end to an industry he calls "cruel."http://www.ruralweekly.com.au/news/end-cruel-trade-vet-best-practice-in-australia/2365034/ In March 2011, [[Animals Australia]] investigators collected footage which showed Australian cattle being slaughtered at 11 abattoirs in Indonesia with practices that infringed upon [[OIE]] standards for animal welfare.[http://www.banliveexport.com/videos/indonesia-report.php Indonesia 2011 - Investigation Report | date =2011-11-30] [[Animals Australia]] and [[RSPCA Australia]] jointly complained to the federal [[Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (Australia)|Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry]], calling for a ban on live exports.[http://www.banliveexport.com/ Ban Live Exports] In response to the footage, live exports to Indonesia were suspended by the Australian Minister for Agriculture from June 7, 2011 until July 6, 2011. The suspension was lifted with the new Exporter Supply Chain Assurance System in place, outlining mandatory compliance for all importing markets of Australian live animals for slaughter, with international standards for animal welfare.[http://www.maff.gov.au/media_office/media_releases/media_releases/2011/july/government-lifts-live-cattle-export-suspension Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry - Media Release | date =2011-06-07] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130421045313/http://www.maff.gov.au/media_office/media_releases/media_releases/2011/july/government-lifts-live-cattle-export-suspension |date=2013-04-21 }} The ESCAS regulatory framework is applicable across all importing markets as of December 31, 2012.[http://www.daff.gov.au/aqis/export/live-animals/livestock/escas Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Exporter Supply Chain Assurance System (ESCAS)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130427063659/http://www.daff.gov.au/aqis/export/live-animals/livestock/escas |date=2013-04-27 }} The footage was the subject of a separate investigation conducted by [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] program, [[Four Corners (Australian TV program)|Four Corners]], shown on 30 May 2011.{{cite news| title = A Bloody Business| publisher = ABC| url = http://www.abc.net.au/4corners/content/2011/s3228880.htm | date =2013-05-30 |accessdate = 2013-11-04}} The report entitled “A Bloody Business” was the winner of a [[Logie Award]] for “Most Outstanding Public Affairs Report” as well as the 2011 [[Gold Walkley]] Award. In November 2012, another widely reported investigation by [[Animals Australia]] brought attention to the slaughter of 22,000 Australian sheep in an ESCAS-approved feedlot in [[Pakistan]], after weeks at sea upon the initial consignment being rejected by [[Bahrain]] due to claimed fears of disease. The video footage of the cull, obtained by Animals Australia “shows absolute chaos with animals being dragged, beaten, having their throats sawn at with blunt knives and thrown into mass graves -- some of them still alive hours later."[http://www.animalsaustralia.org/media/press_releases.php?release=184 Animals Australia - Media Release | date =2012-11-06] Animals Australia's Campaign Director, Lyn White, stated of the incident:
{{cquote|Exporters cannot deny responsibility - they put live animals on ships - knowing the scale of risks and factors outside their control. They cannot then say, 'it's not our fault' when the inevitable happens and something goes terribly wrong.}}
On 6 May 2013 a report aired on Australia's ''ABC 7.30'', revealing footage of cruelty to Australian cattle in at least one Egyptian abattoir.{{cite news| title = Cattle cruelty footage suspends trade, sparks live export debate | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) ''7.30'' | url = http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2013/s3753039.htm | date =2013-05-06 |accessdate = 2013-05-10}} The footage, provided to the Australian Department of Agriculture by animal protection group Animals Australia, led to a suspension of live trade to Egypt.{{cite news| title = 'Cruelty' stops live exports to Egypt | publisher = The Age | url = http://www.theage.com.au/national/cruelty-stops-live-exports-to-egypt-20130504-2j07k.html | date =2013-05-05 |accessdate = 2013-05-10}} Australian Agriculture Minister Joe Ludwig described the footage as "sickening", and the Australian Live Exporters' Council chief executive, Alison Penfold, said she was "distraught and disgusted".{{cite news| title = Live export row dogs Gillard | publisher = Sydney Morning Herald | url = http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/political-news/live-export-row-dogs-gillard-20130504-2izz1.html | date =2013-05-05 |accessdate = 2013-05-10}} In May 2013, evidence was provided to the Department of Agriculture showing what is alleged to be Australian goats being roughly handled and sold outside of approved facilities in Malaysia. The footage also allegedly showed breaches of required animal welfare standards during slaughter of Australian cattle.{{cite news| title = More animal cruelty claims in Malaysia | publisher = WA Today | url = http://www.watoday.com.au/opinion/political-news/more-animal-cruelty-claims-in-malaysia-20130508-2j7zx.html | date =2013-05-09 |accessdate = 2013-05-13}} The Department confirmed it had reviewed the footage and launched an investigation.{{cite news| title = Investigators sent to Malaysia over goat abuse allegations | publisher = ABC Online | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-05-09/malaysia-goats/4678872l | date =2013-05-09 |accessdate = 2013-05-13}} [[Animals Australia]] report to have conducted a total of 30 separate investigations into the live export industry between May 2003 and April 2014.[http://www.banliveexport.com/investigations/ Animals Australia - Live Export Investigations] ==== Research into Australian live export ==== In 2009, the [[World Animal Protection]] live export campaign commissioned economic think tank ACIL Tasman to undertake economic research [http://www.worldanimalprotection.org.au/our-work/animals-in-farming/live-export Let's end the cruelty of live export], [[World Animal Protection]]. Accessed 18 June 2014. into the live export trade. This research found that there are potential value adding opportunities being lost in Australia due to trade distortions in the live export trade. The report analysed the economics and policy settings of the live sheep export trade from Western Australia and demonstrated that a sheep processed domestically is worth 20% more to the Australian economy than one exported live. In October 2012, [[World Animal Protection]] published a further piece of research into the live export trade. This research found that if a cattle processing facility was built in the Northern Territory or North-Western Australia, in conjunction with live export, there would potentially be an increase of 245% or more in gross earnings for Australian cattle producers, more than 1,300 jobs for unemployed Australians and gross regional product growth of $204 million per annum. In August 2011, two bills were presented to [[Australian Parliament]] calling for an end to live exports on animal welfare grounds, by Independent Senator [[Nick Xenophon]] and the [[Australian Greens]] Party. Both bills were rejected by the House of Representatives.{{cite news| title = Major parties reject bills to ban live exports | publisher = ABC Rural| url = http://www.abc.net.au/rural/news/content/201108/s3296349.htm | date =2011-08-18 |accessdate = 2013-11-04}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== * [http://www.agriculture.gov.au/animal/welfare/export-trade Australian Department of Agriculture Live animal export trade] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121228202000/http://www.beefcentral.com/p/news/article/2444 November 2012 Independent Poll of Australian public attitude to live export by Essential Media] * [http://www.mla.com.au/TopicHierarchy/IndustryPrograms/LivestockExports/Live+export+reports.htm Hassall & Associates Australia: Live Export Industry: Value, Outlook and Contribution to the Economy] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060505031822/http://www.mla.com.au/TopicHierarchy/IndustryPrograms/LivestockExports/Default.htm Meat & Livestock Australia] {{DEFAULTSORT:Live Export}} [[Category:Animal welfare]] [[Category:Intensive farming]] [[Category:Livestock]] [[Category:Meat industry]] [[Category:Export]]

Alter: template type, isbn. Add: year, jstor, journal, pages, issue, volume. Removed parameters. Formatted [[WP:ENDASH|dashes]]. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
The '''Makridakis Competitions''' (also known as the '''M Competitions''' or '''M-Competitions''') are a series of open competitions organized by teams led by forecasting researcher [[Spyros Makridakis]] and intended to evaluate and compare the accuracy of different forecasting methods.<ref name=m3m>{{cite journal|title = The M-3 Competition: results, conclusions, and implications|last = Makridakis|first = Spyros|authorlink = Spyros Makridakis|last2 = Hibon|first2 = Michele|date = October–December 2000|accessdate = April 19, 2014|journal = [[International Journal of Forecasting]]|volume = 16|issue = 4|pages = 451–476|doi=10.1016/S0169-2070(00)00057-1|url = http://www.forecastingprinciples.com/files/pdf/Makridakia-The%20M3%20Competition.pdf}}</ref><ref name=m3-1>{{cite journal|title = The M3 competition: Statistical tests of the results|doi = 10.1016/j.ijforecast.2004.10.003|last = Koning|first = Alex J.|last2 = Frances|first2 = Philip Hans|last3 = Hibon|first3 = Michele|last4 = Stekler|first4 = H. O.|date = July–September 2005|journal = [[International Journal of Forecasting]]|volume = 21|issue = 3|pages = 397–409}}</ref><ref name=m3-2>{{cite journal|title = Another look at measures of forecast accuracy|last = Hyndman|first = Rob J.|last2 = Koehler|first2 = Anne B.|volume = 22|issue = 4|date = October–December 2006|journal = [[International Journal of Forecasting]]}}</ref><ref name=m3-data>{{cite web|url=http://forecasters.org/resources/time-series-data/m3-competition/|title = M3-competition (full data)|accessdate = April 19, 2014|publisher = [[International Institute of Forecasters]]}}</ref>
==Competitions==
===Summary===
{| class="sortable" border="1" ! No. !! Informal name for competition !! Year of publication of results !! Number of time series used !! Number of methods tested !! Other features |- | 1 || M Competition or M-Competition<ref name=m3m/><ref name=m/> || 1982 || 1001 (used a subsample of 111 for the methods where it was too difficult to run all 1001) || 15 (plus 9 variations) || Not real-time |- | 2 || M-2 Competition or M2-Competition<ref name=m3m/><ref name=m2/> || 1993 || 29 (23 from collaborating companies, 6 from macroeconomic indicators) || 16 (including 5 human forecasters and 11 automatic trend-based methods) plus 2 combined forecasts and 1 overall average || Real-time, many collaborating organizations, competition announced in advance |- | 3 || M-3 Competition or M3-Competition<ref name=m3m/> || 2000 || 3003 || 24 || |- | 4 || M-4 Competition or M4 Competition || Initial Results June 2018 || 100,000 || All major ML and statistical methods have been tested || Prizes for the winners |}
===First competition in 1982===
The first Makridakis Competition, held in 1982, and known in the forecasting literature as the '''M-Competition''', used 1001 time series and 15 forecasting methods (with another nine variations of those methods included).<ref name=m3m/><ref name=m>{{cite journal|title = The accuracy of extrapolation (time series) methods: results of a forecasting competition|journal = Journal of Forecasting|volume = 1|issue = 2|date = April–June 1982|pages = 111–153|author = Spyros Makridakis|doi = 10.1002/for.3980010202|display-authors=etal}}</ref> According to a later paper by the authors, the following were the main conclusions of the M-Competition:<ref name=m3m/>
# Statistically sophisticated or complex methods do not necessarily provide more accurate forecasts than simpler ones. # The relative ranking of the performance of the various methods varies according to the accuracy measure being used. # The accuracy when various methods are combined outperforms, on average, the individual methods being combined and does very well in comparison to other methods. # The accuracy of the various methods depends on the length of the forecasting horizon involved.
The findings of the study have been verified and replicated through the use of new methods by other researchers.<ref>{{cite journal|title = Forecasting demand for special services|last = Geurts|first = M. D.|last2 = Kelly|first2 = J. P.|year = 1986|publisher = [[International Journal of Forecasting]]|volume = 2|pages = 261–272}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title = Combining forecasts: A review and annotated bibliography|journal = [[International Journal of Forecasting]]|volume = 5|issue = 4|year = 1989|pages = 559–583|last = Clemen|first = Robert T.|url=http://faculty.fuqua.duke.edu/~clemen/bio/Published%20Papers/13.CombiningReview-Clemen-IJOF-89.pdf|doi=10.1016/0169-2070(89)90012-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.insead.edu/facultyresearch/research/doc.cfm?did=46648|title = Generalising about univariate forecasting methods: further empirical evidence|last = Fildes|first = R.|last2 = Hibon|first2 = Michele|last3 = Makridakis|first3 = Spyros|authorlink3 = Spyros Makridakis|last4 = Meade|first4 = N.|year = 1998|journal = [[International Journal of Forecasting]]|volume = 14|issue = 3|pages = 339–358|doi=10.1016/s0169-2070(98)00009-0}}</ref>
This is what [[Rob J. Hyndman]], in his blog about "A brief history of time series forecasting competitions", had to say about the first M Competition: “… anyone could submit forecasts, making this the first true forecasting competition as far as I am aware.”[https://robjhyndman.com/hyndsight/forecasting-competitions/]
Newbold (1983) was critical of the M-competition, and argued against the general idea of using a single competition to attempt to settle the complex issue.<ref name=newbold>{{cite journal|title = The competition to end all competitions|last = Newbold|first = Paul|year = 1983|publisher = [[Journal of Forecasting]]|volume = 2|pages = 276–279}}</ref>
====Before the first competition, the Makridakis–Hibon Study====
Before the first M-Competition, Makridakis and Hibon<ref name=nm>{{cite journal|title = Accuracy of Forecasting: An Empirical Investigation|publisher = [[Journal of the Royal Statistical Society]]|volume = 142|date = 1979|pages = 97–145|jstor=2345077|author = Spyros Makridakis and Michele Hibon}}</ref> published in the Journal of the Royal Statistical Society (JRSS) an article showing that simple methods perform well in comparison to the more complex and statistically sophisticated ones. Statisticians at that time criticized the results claiming that they were not possible. Their criticism motivated the subsequent M, M2 and M3 Competitions that prove beyond the slightest doubt those of the Makridakis and Hibon Study.
===Second competition, published in 1993===
The second competition, called the M-2 Competition or M2-Competition, was conducted on a grander scale. A call to participate was published in the ''[[International Journal of Forecasting]]'', announcements were made in the [[International Symposium of Forecasting]], and a written invitation was sent to all known experts on the various time series methods. The M2-Competition was organized in collaboration with four companies and included six macroeconomic series, and was conducted on a real-time basis. Data was from the United States.<ref name=m3m/> The results of the competition were published in a 1993 paper.<ref name=m2>{{cite journal|title = The M-2 Competition: a real-time judgmentally based forecasting study|journal = International Journal of Forecasting|author = Spyros Makridakis|date = April 1993|volume = 9|pages = 5–22|doi = 10.1016/0169-2070(93)90044-N|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The results were claimed to be statistically identical to those of the M-Competition.<ref name=m3m/>
The M2-Competition used much fewer time series than the original M-competition. Whereas the original M-competition had used 1001 time series, the M2-Competition used only 29, including 23 from the four collaborating companies and 6 macroeconomic series.<ref name=m2/> Data from the companies was obfuscated through the use of a constant multiplier in order to preserve proprietary privacy.<ref name=m2/> The purpose of the M2-Competition was to simulate real-world forecasting better in the following respects:<ref name=m2/>
* Allow forecasters to combine their trend-based forecasting method with personal judgment. * Allow forecasters to ask additional questions requesting data from the companies involved in order to make better forecasts. * Allow forecasters to learn from one forecasting exercise and revise their forecasts for the next forecasting exercise based on the feedback.
The competition was organized as follows:<ref name=m2/> * The first batch of data was sent to participating forecasters in summer 1987. * Forecasters had the option of contacting the companies involved via an intermediary in order to gather additional information they considered relevant to making forecasts. * In October 1987, forecasters were sent updated data. * Forecasters were required to send in their forecasts by the end of November 1987. * A year later, forecasters were sent an analysis of their forecasts and asked to submit their next forecast in November 1988. * The final analysis and evaluation of the forecasts was done starting April 1991 when the actual, final values of the data including December 1990 were known to the collaborating companies.
In addition to the published results, many of the participants wrote short articles describing their experience participating in the competition and their reflections on what the competition demonstrated. Chris Chatfield praised the design of the competition, but said that despite the organizers' best efforts, he felt that forecasters still did not have enough access to the companies from the inside as he felt people would have in real-world forecasting.<ref>{{cite journal|title = A personal view of the M2-competition|last = Chatfield|first = Chris|journal = [[International Journal of Forecasting]]|volume = 9|issue = 1|date = April 1993|pages = 23–24|doi = 10.1016/0169-2070(93)90045-O}}</ref> Fildes and Makridakis (1995) argue that despite the evidence produced by these competitions, the implications continued to be ignored by theoretical statisticians.<ref>{{cite journal|title = The impact of empirical accuracy studies on time series analysis and forecasting|last = Fildes|first = R.|last2 = Makridakis|first2 = Spyros|authorlink2 = Spyros Makridakis|journal = [[International Statistical Review]]|year = 1995|volume = 63|issue = 3|pages = 289–308|url = http://flora.insead.edu/fichiersti_wp/Inseadwp1993/93-29.pdf|doi=10.2307/1403481|jstor = 1403481}}</ref>
===Third competition, published in 2000===
The third competition, called the M-3 Competition or M3-Competition, was intended to both replicate ''and'' extend the features of the M-competition and M2-Competition, through the inclusion of more methods and researchers (particularly researchers in the area of [[neural network]]s) and more [[time series]].<ref name=m3m/> A total of 3003 time series was used. The paper documenting the results of the competition was published in the ''[[International Journal of Forecasting]]''<ref name=m3m/> in 2000 and the raw data was also made available on the [[International Institute of Forecasters]] website.<ref name=m3-data/> According to the authors, the conclusions from the M3-Competition were similar to those from the earlier competitions.<ref name=m3m/>
The time series included yearly, quarterly, monthly, daily, and other time series. In order to ensure that enough data was available to develop an accurate forecasting model, minimum thresholds were set for the number of observations: 14 for yearly series, 16 for quarterly series, 48 for monthly series, and 60 for other series.<ref name=m3m/>
Time series were in the following domains: micro, industry, macro, finance, demographic, and other.<ref name=m3m/><ref name=m3-data/> Below is the number of time series based on the time interval and the domain:<ref name=m3m/><ref name=m3-data/>
{| class="sortable" border="1" ! Time interval between successive observations !! Micro !! Industry !! Macro !! Finance !! Demographic !! Other !! Total |- | Yearly || 146 || 102 || 83 || 58 || 245 || 11 || 645 |- | Quarterly || 204 ||83 || 336 || 76 || 57 || 0 || 756 |- | Monthly || 474 || 334 || 312 || 145 || 111 || 52 || 1428 |- | Other || 4 || 0 || 0 || 29 || 0 || 141 || 174 |- ! Total || 828 || 519 || 731 || 308 || 413 || 204 || 3003 |}
The five measures used to evaluate the accuracy of different forecasts were: [[symmetric mean absolute percentage error]] (also known as symmetric MAPE), average ranking, median symmetric absolute percentage error (also known as median symmetric APE), percentage better, and median RAE.<ref name=m3m/>
A number of other papers have been published with different analyses of the data set from the M3-Competition.<ref name=m3-1/><ref name=m3-2/> According to [[Rob J. Hyndman]], Editor-in-Chief of the [[International Journal of Forecasting]] (IJF), “The M3 data have continued to be used since 2000 for testing new time series forecasting methods. In fact, unless a proposed forecasting method is competitive against the original M3 participating methods, it is difficult to get published in the IJF.”
===Fourth competition, started in Jan 1 2018, ended in May 31 2018.===
The M-Competitions have attracted great interest in both the academic literature and among practitioners, providing objective evidence of the most appropriate way of forecasting various variables of interest. The fourth competition, M4, was announced in November 2017[https://www.unic.ac.cy/news/announcing-m4-makridakis-4-forecasting-competition/]. The competition started in Jan 1 2018 and ended in May 31 2018. Initial results were published in the [International Journal of Forecasting] on June 21, 2018. The paper can be downloaded at the [ScienceDirect website[https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0169207018300785].
The M4 extended and replicated the results of the previous three competitions, using an extended and diverse set of time series to identify the most accurate forecasting method(s) for different types of predictions. It aimed to get answers on how to improve forecasting accuracy and identify the most appropriate methods for each case. To get precise and compelling answers, the M4 Competition utilized 100,000 real-life series, and incorporates all major forecasting methods, including those based on Artificial Intelligence (Machine Learning, ML), as well as traditional statistical ones.
In his blog, [[Rob J. Hyndman]] said about M4: “The “M” competitions organized by Spyros Makridakis have had an enormous influence on the field of forecasting. They focused attention on what models produced good forecasts, rather than on the mathematical properties of those models. For that, Spyros deserves congratulations for changing the landscape of forecasting research through this series of competitions."[https://robjhyndman.com/hyndsight/m4comp/]
Below is the number of time series based on the time interval and the domain:
{| class="sortable" border="1" ! Time interval between successive observations !! Micro !! Industry !! Macro !! Finance !! Demographic !! Other !! Total |- | Yearly || 6538 || 3716 || 3903 || 6519 || 1088 || 1236 || 23000 |- | Quarterly || 6020 || 4637 || 5315 || 5305 || 1858 || 865 || 24000 |- | Monthly || 10975 || 10017 || 10016 || 10987 || 5728 || 277 || 48000 |- | Weekly || 112 || 6 || 41 || 164 || 24 || 12 || 359 |- | Daily || 1476 || 422 || 127 || 1559 || 10 || 633 || 4227 |- | Hourly || 0 || 0 || 0 || 0 || 0 || 414 || 414 |- ! Total || 25121 || 18798 || 19402 || 24534 || 8708 || 3437 || 100000 |}
In order to ensure that enough data are available to develop an accurate forecasting model, minimum thresholds were set for the number of observations: 13 for yearly, 16 for quarterly, 42 for monthly, 80 for weekly, 93 for daily and 700 for hourly series.
One of its major objectives was to compare the accuracy of ML methods versus that of statistical ones and empirically verify the claims of the superior performance of ML methods.
'''Below is a short description of the M4 Competition and its major findings and Conclusion:'''
The M4 Competition ended on May 31, 2018 and in addition to point forecasts, it included specifying Prediction Intervals (PI) too. M4 was an Open one, with its most important objective (the same with that of the previous three M Competitions): “to learn to improve forecasting accuracy and advance the field as much as possible”. This is in contrast to other ones, as those organized by Kaggle, where there is actually a “horse race” aimed at identifying the most accurate forecasting method(s) without attempting to discover the reasons involved in order to be able to improve forecasting performance in the future.
'''The five major findings and the conclusion of M4:'''
Below we outline what we consider to be the five major findings of the M4 Competition and advance a logical conclusion from these findings.
# The combination of methods was the king of the M4. Out of the 17 most accurate methods, 12 were “combinations” of mostly statistical approaches. # The biggest surprise, however, was a “hybrid” approach utilizing both Statistical and ML features. This method, produced the most accurate forecasts as well as the most precise PIs and was submitted by Slawek Smyl, Data Scientist at Uber Technologies. According to sMAPE, it was close to 10% (a huge improvement) more accurate than the Combination (Comb) benchmark of the Competition (see below). It is noted that in the M3 Competition (Makridakis & Hibon, 2000) the best method was 4% more accurate than the same Combination. # The second most accurate method was a combination of seven statistical methods and one ML one, with the weights for the averaging being calculated by a ML algorithm, trained to minimize forecasting error through holdout tests. This method was jointly submitted by Spain’s University of A Coruña and Australia’s Monash University. # The first and the second most accurate methods also achieved an amazing success in specifying correctly the 95% PIs. These are the first methods we know that have done so and do not underestimate uncertainty considerably. # The six pure ML methods submitted in the M4 performed poorly, none of them being more accurate than Comb and only one being more accurate than Naïve2. These results are in agreement with those of a recent study we published in PLOS ONE (Makridakis, et al., 2018).
The conclusion from the above findings is that the accuracy of individual statistical or ML methods is low and that hybrid approaches and combination of methods is the way forward in order to improve forecasting accuracy and make forecasting more valuable.
The five Machine Learning (ML) methods submitted in the M4 performed poorly, none of them being more accurate than the statistical benchmark and only one being more accurate than Naïve 2, a finding consistent with a paper published in PLOS ONE at the end of March 2018 [http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0194889].
'''References'''
* Makridakis, S., Hibon, M. (1979). Accuracy of Forecasting: An Empirical Investigation. Journal of the Royal Statistical Society. Series A (General), 142(2), 97-145 * Makridakis, S., Spiliotis, E. & Assimakopoulos, V. (2018). Statistical and Machine Learning forecasting methods: Concerns and ways forward. PLOS ONE, 13 (3), 1-26 * Makridakis, S., Spiliotis, E. & Assimakopoulos, V. (2018). The M4 Competition: Results, findings, conclusion and way forward. International Journal of Forecasting, Forthcoming.
More information on the M4 Competition is available on the M4 website - http:/www.m4.unic.ac.cy – and a Special Issue covering all aspects of the M4, the winning methods and comment will be published in the [International Journal of Forecasting] in 2019.
==Offshoots==
===NN3-Competition===
Although the organizers of the M3-Competition did contact researchers in the area of [[artificial neural network]]s to seek their participation in the competition, only one researcher participated, and that researcher's forecasts fared poorly. The reluctance of most ANN researchers to participate at the time was due to the computationally intensive nature of ANN-based forecasting and the huge time series used for the competition.<ref name=m3m/> In 2005, Crone, Nikolopoulos and Hibon organized the NN-3 Competition, using 111 of the time series from the M3-Competition (not the same data, because it was shifted in time, but the same sources). The NN-3 Competition found that the best ANN-based forecasts performed comparably with the best known forecasting methods, but were far more computationally intensive. It was also noted that many ANN-based techniques fared considerably worse than simple forecasting methods, despite greater ''theoretical'' potential for good performance.<ref name=n3>{{cite web|url = http://forecasters.org/pdfs/IIF-SAS-Report-Apr2008.pdf|title = Automatic Modelling and Forecasting with Artificial Neural Networks– A forecasting competition evaluation|last = Crone|first = Sven F.|last2 = Nikolopoulos|first2 = Konstantinos|last3 = Hibon| first3 = Michele| date = 2005–06 <!-- (published online April 2008) --> | accessdate = April 23, 2014}}</ref>
==Reception==
===In books for mass audiences===
[[Nassim Nicholas Taleb]], in his book ''[[The Black Swan (2007 book)|The Black Swan]]'', references the Makridakis Competitions as follows: "The most interesting test of how academic methods fare in the real world was provided by Spyros Makridakis, who spent part of his career managing competitions between forecasters who practice a "scientific method" called econometrics -- an approach that combines economic theory with statistical measurements. Simply put, he made people forecast ''in real life'' and then he judged their accuracy. This led to a series of "M-Competitions" he ran, with assistance from Michele Hibon, of which M3 was the third and most recent one, completed in 1999. Makridakis and Hibon reached the sad conclusion that "statistically sophisticated and complex methods do not necessarily provide more accurate forecasts than simpler ones.""<ref>{{cite book|title = Fooled by Randomness|isbn = 978-0-8129-7521-5|author = Nassim Nicholas Taleb|year = 2005}}, Page 154, available for online viewing at [https://books.google.com/books?id=gWW4SkJjM08C&pg=PA154&lpg=PA154&dq=tetlock+makridakis&source=bl&ots=v_AQFYPHkt&sig=5Pd5x5rxiZrFaBjhrhBSPz1RiE0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=pzRlU5XYI4vJoATBlQE&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=tetlock%20makridakis&f=false Google Books]</ref>
In the book ''Everything is Obvious'', Duncan Watts cites the work of Makridakis and Hibon as showing that "simple models are about as good as complex models in forecasting economic time series."<ref>{{cite book|title = Everything is Obvious|author = Duncan Watts|isbn = 978-0307951793|year = 2011}}, Page 315</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Mary French Rockefeller | image = Laurance S. Rockefeller NYWTS.jpg | alt = | caption = [[Laurance Rockefeller|Laurance]] and Mary French Rockefeller in 1965 | birth_name = Mary Billings French | birth_date = May 1, 1910 | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|1997|04|17|1910|05|01}} | death_place = [[New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center]] | resting_place= Rockefeller Family Cemetery
[[Sleepy Hollow, New York]] | nationality = American | other_names = | occupation = Philanthropist | years_active = | boards = [[YWCA]] National Board (1955-1973) | alma_mater = [[Vassar College]] (1931) | parents = John French
[[Mary Billings French|Mary Billings]] | spouse = [[Laurance Rockefeller]] | children = [[Laura Rockefeller Chasin]]
[[Marion Rockefeller Weber]]
[[Lucy Rockefeller Waletzky]]
[[Laurance Rockefeller Jr.|Laurance S. Rockefeller Jr.]] | known_for = Member of the [[Rockefeller family]];
Member of the Billings family;
Philanthropy }} '''Mary French Rockefeller''' (May 1, 1910 – April 17, 1997) was an heiress, socialite, philanthropist, and a member of the extensive [[Rockefeller family]]. She was married to [[Laurance Rockefeller]], son of [[John D. Rockefeller Jr.|John Davison Rockefeller Jr.]] and [[Abby Aldrich Rockefeller]]. She was the mother of [[Laura Rockefeller Chasin]], [[Marion Rockefeller Weber]], [[Lucy Rockefeller Waletzky]], and [[Laurance Spelman Rockefeller Jr.]] ==Early life== Mary Billings French was born to John French (b. December 4, 1863) and [[Mary Billings French|Mary Montagu Billings French]] (1869–1951), daughter of financier [[Frederick Billings]]. Her mother was an heiress while her father was a lawyer, and the couple married in 1907. John was the son of Warren Converse French and Sarah Ann Steele.{{cite book|last1=Winks|first1=Robin W.|title=Frederick Billings: A Life|date=1998|publisher=University of California Press | isbn =978-0-52021497-2|page=148}}{{cite book|last1=Cutter|first1=William Richard|title = New England Families, Genealogical and Memorial: A Record of the Achievements of Her People in the Making of Commonwealths and the Founding of a Nation | volume = 2|date= 1913| publisher= Lewis historical publishing |page=643|accessdate= 6 January 2015}} Mary's mother (the elder Mary) was a society figure and maintained an apartment with her sister on [[Madison Avenue]] in [[New York City]] before she married.{{cite book|title= Social Register, New York|date=1894|publisher=Social Register Association | page = 6|accessdate=6 January 2015}} Mary (the younger) had two siblings, being her older brother John (1909–1984) and her younger sister Elizabeth, who went by "Liz" (1912–1976).{{cite web| title= Cultural Landscape Report For the Mansion Grounds | format = [[Portable document format|PDF]] | url= http://www.nps.gov/parkhistory/online_books/mabi/mansion_grounds_clr1.pdf | website = National Park Service – U.S. Department of the Interior | accessdate= 7 January 2015}} John had been a roommate of [[Nelson Rockefeller]] while both attended [[Dartmouth College]]. The French children were born into "wealth and privilege", though Mary tried to live an unostentatious lifestyle as an adult. Through her mother, the younger Mary was a tenth generation descendant of [[Simon Willard (first generation)|Major Simon Willard]], a Massachusetts historical figure.{{cite book | title = Register of the National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New York|date=1913|publisher=National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New York|pages =256–8|accessdate=6 January 2015}} ==Personal life== Mary met Laurance S. Rockefeller in 1927. On August 15, 1934, Mary married Laurance at the [[First Congregational Church of Woodstock, Vermont]], located on Elm Street. The ceremony was officiated by Reverend Herbert Hines and was attended by approximately 300 guests, followed by a reception at "[[Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park|The Hills]]", Mary's estate at the Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller compound.{{cite web|title=Laurance S. Rockefeller|url=http://aapra.org/pugsley-bios/laurance-s-rockefeller|website=American Academy for Park & Recreation Administration|accessdate=7 January 2015}}{{cite web|title=Laurance S. Rockefeller, 1910-2004|url=http://www.rockarch.org/bio/laurance.php|website=Rockefeller Family & Associates|accessdate=7 January 2015}}{{cite news|title=Miss Mary French Marries Rockefeller Kin|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/50901874/|accessdate=7 January 2015|publisher=Pottstown Mercury|date=16 Aug 1934}} Together Mary and Laurance had: *[[Laura Rockefeller Chasin]] (born 1936) *[[Marion Rockefeller Weber]] (born 1938) *[[Lucy Rockefeller Waletzky]] (born 1941) *[[Laurance Spelman Rockefeller Jr.|Laurance "Larry" Spelman Rockefeller Jr.]] (born 1944) On April 17, 1997, she fell in her apartment in Manhattan and died later the same day at the [[New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center]]. Mary was 86 years old at the time of her death, and according to a Rockefeller family spokesman, she was in "failing health" for several years before her death.{{cite news|last1=Nemy|first1=Enid|title=Mary Rockefeller, Women's Advocate, Dies at 86|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/19/nyregion/mary-rockefeller-women-s-advocate-dies-at-86.html|accessdate=7 January 2015|publisher=New York Times|date=19 Apr 1997}} ===Philanthropy=== {{Main|Laurance Rockefeller#Conservation and death|l1=Philanthropy of Mary and Laurance Rockefeller}} Mary worked closely with her husband on a number of philanthropic projects, mostly focused on conservationism and donation of their money, estates and time. At the age of 41, Mary inherited what is now known as the [[Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park]] from her parents when her mother died in 1951, who had inherited it from her father Frederick. The estate included a mansion, dairy farm, and extensive grounds. In 1992, Mary and Laurance donated the property to the state and it was made into a National Historic Park. [[Lady Bird Johnson]] dedicated the house in a special ceremony.{{cite book|last1=Duffy|first1=John J.|title=The Vermont Encyclopedia|date=2003|publisher=UPNE|isbn=9781584650867|page=251}} Mary was an ardent supporter of the [[Young Women's Christian Association]] (YWCA), carrying on the tradition from her mother who was also involved with the organization. In 1951 she joined the YWCA National Board, then was vice-chairman and then chairman of the YWCA's international division from 1955 to 1973. From 1958 to 1964, she was chairman of the YWCA's World Service Council, followed by being elected to the YWCA Board of Trustees in 1988. Together with her husband, Mary flew over 50,000 miles for YWCA activities around the world.{{cite news|title=Women's Rights Advocate Mary Rockefeller, 86|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1997-04-20/news/9704200361_1_ywca-laurance-s-rockefeller-mary-french-rockefeller|accessdate=7 January 2015|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=23 Apr 1997}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Rockefeller family}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rockefeller, Mary French}} [[Category:1910 births]] [[Category:1997 deaths]] [[Category:American conservationists]] [[Category:Philanthropists from New York (state)]] [[Category:People from Manhattan]] [[Category:Vassar College alumni]] [[Category:Rockefeller family]] [[Category:Wildlife Conservation Society people]] [[Category:Activists from New York (state)]]
