{{Infobox person | name = Matthew Astor Wilks | image = HettyGreen001a.jpg | caption = ''Photograph of Wilk's mother-in-law, Wilks, and his wife, on his wedding day, 1909.'' | birth_date = {{birth date|1844|03|03}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1926|07|09|1844|03|03}} | death_place = New York City, New York, U.S. | parents = Matthew Wilks
Eliza Astor Langdon | spouse = {{marriage|[[Harriet Sylvia Ann Howland Green Wilks|Sylvia Ann Howland Green]]
|1909|1926|reason=his death}} | children = | relatives = ''See'' [[Astor family]] }} '''Matthew Astor Wilks''' (March 3, 1844 – July 9, 1926) was an American clubman who was prominent in New York society during the [[Gilded Age]].{{cite book |last1=Flynn |first1=John T. |title=Men of Wealth |date=1941 |publisher=Ludwig von Mises Institute |isbn=9781610163293 |page=245 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6H1IS8CjYgMC&pg=PA245 |accessdate=10 July 2018 |language=en}} ==Early life== Wilks was born in New York City on March 3, 1844. He was the one of seven children born to Matthew Wilks (1816–1899){{cite news |title=Matthew Wilks |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1899/06/21/118938739.pdf |accessdate=10 July 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 21, 1899}} and Eliza Astor ([[née]] Langdon) Wilks (1818–1896).{{cite news |title=WILKS |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1896/06/06/503864122.pdf |accessdate=10 July 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 6, 1896}} His siblings included Elizabeth Wilks; Alice Eugenia Wilks, who married William Napier Keefer; Katherine Langdon Wilks; and Eugene Langdon Wilks, who married Marquerite R. Briquet. He spent part of his year in [[Galt, Ontario]] in Canada, where his father had a 1,000 acre estate known as Cruickston Park and mansion designed by [[Detlef Lienau]].{{cite book |last1=Redshaw |first1=Rachel Morgan |title=The Past of Cruickston Park: Scandalous Marriages, the Rich Families of New York and the Unsinkable Titanic |publisher=North Dumfries Municipal Heritage Committee |page=16 |url=http://www.ayrnews.ca/uploads/files/Historical%20Stories/Page%2016%20Cruickston%20Park%20Farm.pdf |accessdate=10 July 2018}} Through his mother, Wilks was great-grandson of America's first [[millionaire]] [[John Jacob Astor]], the fur trader and real estate magnet. Among his first cousins were [[DeLancey Astor Kane]], [[Woodbury Kane]], [[S. Nicholson Kane]], and [[John Jacob Astor IV]].{{cite news|title=COL. DE LANCEY KANE DIES OF PNEUMONIA; Noted Horseman and Astor's Great-Grandson Initiated Coaching in America. LONG A SOCIAL LEADER Graduate of West Point Who Inherited $10,000,000 Served in the Cavalry in Our Army.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1915/04/05/archives/col-de-lancey-kane-dies-of-pneumonia-noted-horseman-and-astors.html|accessdate=2 March 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=5 April 1915}} His father, an English gentleman,{{cite book |last1=O'Connor |first1=Harvey |title=The Astors |date=1941 |publisher=A. A. Knopf |page=314 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KToxAAAAMAAJ |accessdate=10 July 2018 |language=en}} was the son of a reverend and was born in London. ==Career== [[File:New York Stock Exchange and Wilks Bldg. LCCN00650326.jpg|thumb|right|The [[New York Stock Exchange]] (left) and the Wilks Building (right), 1921.]] Wilks, who inherited several million dollars from his family, began buying up property in [[lower Manhattan]] in 1876.{{cite news |last1=Miller |first1=Tom |title=The Lost Wilks Building - Wall and Broad Streets |url=https://daytoninmanhattan.blogspot.com/2016/11/the-lost-wilks-building-wall-and-broad.html |accessdate=10 July 2018 |work=Daytonian in Manhattan |date=6 November 2016}} He torn down the various mixed buildings and commissioned architect [[Charles W. Clinton]] to build a ten-story [[Renaissance Revival architecture|Italian Renaissance revival]] building, known as the Wilks Building, from 1889 to 1890 at 15 Wall Street in New York City. The building, located at the corner of [[Wall Street]] and [[Broad Street (Manhattan)|Broad Street]], was torn down in 1923 in order for it's adjourning neighbor, the [[New York Stock Exchange]],{{cite book |last1=Gabrielan |first1=Randall |title=New York City's Financial District in Vintage Postcards |date=2000 |publisher=[[Arcadia Publishing]] |isbn=9780738500683 |page=30 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YQ1A-Hz3ml4C&pg=PA30 |accessdate=10 July 2018 |language=en}} to expand into what became known as the [[New York Stock Exchange|New York Stock Exchange annex]], designed by [[Trowbridge & Livingston]]. ===Society life=== In 1892, Wilks was included in [[Ward McAllister]]'s [[Ward McAllister#"The Four Hundred"|"Four Hundred"]], purported to be an index of New York's best families, published in ''[[The New York Times]]''.{{cite news|last1=McAllister|first1=Ward|title=THE ONLY FOUR HUNDRED {{!}} WARD M'ALLISTER GIVES OUT THE OFFICIAL LIST. HERE ARE THE NAMES, DON'T YOU KNOW, ON THE AUTHORITY OF THEIR GREAT LEADER, YOU UNDER- STAND, AND THEREFORE GENUINE, YOU SEE.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1892/02/16/108210917.pdf|accessdate=26 March 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=16 February 1892|language=en}} Conveniently, 400 was the number of people that could fit into [[Mrs. Astor]]'s ballroom.{{cite book|last1=Keister|first1=Lisa A.|title=Getting Rich: America's New Rich and How They Got That Way|date=2005|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=9780521536677|page=36|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5dAtJf1hmAUC&pg=PA36|accessdate=20 October 2017|language=en}} Upon [[Caroline Schermerhorn Astor]]'s death in 1908, Wilks was one of the pallbearers at her funeral.{{cite book |last1=Wallach |first1=Janet |title=The Richest Woman in America: Hetty Green in the Gilded Age |date=2013 |publisher=Anchor Books |isbn=9780307474575 |page=276 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oKvaLKx8rEgC&pg=PA276 |accessdate=10 July 2018 |language=en}} Wilks, who was considered "a man of independent fortune" was a member of the [[University Club of New York]], the [[Metropolitan Club]], the Badminton Club, the Turf and Field Club, the Fencers Club, the [[Knickerbocker Club]], the [[New York Yacht Club]] and the Automobile Club of America. He was considered one of the "society 'swells'" along with [[Lispenard Stewart]] and [[Elisha Dyer III|Elisha Dyer]].{{cite book |last1=Homberger |first1=Eric |title=Mrs. Astor's New York: Money and Social Power in a Gilded Age |date=2004 |publisher=[[Yale University Press]] |isbn=0300105150 |page=154 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=13jwkUPvYGcC&pg=PA154 |accessdate=10 July 2018 |language=en}} Wilks and his wife were fond of the Opera and had a box at the [[Metropolitan Opera House (39th Street)|Metropolitan Opera House]],{{cite news |title=FEWER NEWCOMERS IN OPERA PARTERRE Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Astor Wilks Among Those in Golden Horseshoe. OPENING IS NEXT MONDAY Musical Foundation Has Leased Box Owned by Frederic A. Juilliard. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1922/11/06/99095630.pdf |accessdate=10 July 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 6, 1922}} and had a home in [[Newport, Rhode Island]].{{cite news |title=MRS. HETTY GREEN AGAIN IN SOCIETY Son of the Richest Woman in the World Denies That She Is Ill. GOES TO NEWPORT SOON Mother of Mrs. Matthew Astor Wilks May Continue Her Social Campgain -- Has Made Many New Friends |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1910/04/06/105077319.pdf |accessdate=10 July 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 6, 1910}} ==Personal life== On February 23, 1909, the then 63 year old Wilks was married to 38 year old [[Harriet Sylvia Ann Howland Green Wilks|Sylvia Ann Howland Green]] at [[St. Peter's Episcopal Church (Morristown, New Jersey)|St. Peter's Episcopal Church]] in [[Morristown, New Jersey]].{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Green Grist |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,931609,00.html |quote=A surprise witness at the first session was tall, sharp-nosed, bespectacled Mrs. Hetty Sylvia Ann Howland Green Wilks, 66, whose right to her brother's fortune by terms of a will drawn nine years before his marriage has been challenged by Colonel Green's widow, redheaded Mabel E. Harlow Green, 66. |publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' |date= May 3, 1937 |accessdate=2008-06-08 }} She was the only daughter of financier [[Hetty Green|Hetty Howland Robinson]], known as "the world's richest woman," and Edward Henry Green. Sylvia was the sister of businessman [[Edward Howland Robinson Green]] and the grandniece of [[Sylvia Ann Howland]].{{cite news |title=The Woman Who Loved Money |url=http://www.newyorksocialdiary.com/social-history/2007/the-woman-who-loved-money |accessdate=10 July 2018 |work=[[New York Social Diary]] |date=21 August 2007 |language=en}} Wilks died on July 9, 1926 at his home, 7 [[81st Street (Manhattan)|West 81st Street]] in New York City.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Matthew A. Wilks Dies. J.J. Astor Descendant. Son-in-Law of the Late Hetty Green Was a Member of Many Clubs. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1926/08/04/98498544.pdf |quote= |publisher=''[[New York Times]]'' |date=August 4, 1926|accessdate=2008-06-09 }} He was buried at [[Immanuel Episcopal Church (Bellows Falls, Vermont)|Immanuel Cemetery]] in [[Bellows Falls, Vermont]].{{cite news |title=MATTHEW A. WILKS'S WILL.; Mrs. Hetty Green's Son-In-Law Left Estate to Widow. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1926/09/21/98511288.pdf |accessdate=10 July 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 21, 1926 |language=en}} His widow, who was then living at [[998 Fifth Avenue]],{{cite news |last1=Netburn |first1=Deborah |title=Astor’s 998 Fifth Home Gets $16 Million Nibble; Buyers Kept on Ice |url=https://observer.com/2000/08/astors-998-fifth-home-gets-16-million-nibble-buyers-kept-on-ice/ |accessdate=10 July 2018 |work=[[The Observer]] |date=7 August 2000}} died on February 5, 1951 leaving an estate of $94,965,229 (approximately ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|95000000|1951|r=-3}}}} today).{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=MRS. HETTY WILKS DEAD AT AGE OF 80. Daughter Of Hetty Green, Noted For Financial Manipulations, Wed Descendant Of Astor "Accustomed To Economy" Active Until Last Year. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1951/02/06/86969616.pdf |quote=Mrs. Hetty Sylvia Ann Howland Green Wilks of 988 Fifth Avenue, widow of Matthew Astor Wilks, and daughter of Hetty Green, the famous woman financier, died yesterday in the New York Hospital at the age of 80. |publisher=''[[New York Times]]'' |date=February 6, 1951|accessdate=2008-06-09 }}{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Hetty Green's Daughter Leaves $94,965,229 |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/424588961.html?dids=424588961:424588961&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&date=Sep+27%2C+1952&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=Hetty+Green's+Daughter+Leaves+%2494%2C965%2C229&pqatl=google |quote=The estate of Mrs. Hetty Sylvia Howland Green Wilks, who died Feb. 5, 1951, totaled $94,965,229 gross and $90,845,301 net, according to an estate tax appraisal filed yesterday. |publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' |date=September 27, 1952 |accessdate=2008-06-08 }}{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Hetty Green's Only Daughter, 80, Dies |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/447446752.html?dids=447446752:447446752&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&date=Feb+07%2C+1951&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=HETTY+GREEN'S+ONLY+DAUGHTER%2C+80%2C+DIES&pqatl=google |quote=Mrs. Matthew Astor Wilks, 80, only daughter of the wealthy Hetty Green and, in her own right, one of the world's richest women, died last night in [[New York Hospital]].|publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' |date=February 7, 1951 |accessdate=2008-06-08 }}{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Wilks Estate Is Put At 95 Millions, Third Of It In One Checking Account; Mrs. Wilks' Assets Put At 95 Millions |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1952/03/20/archives/wilks-estate-is-put-at-95-millions-third-of-it-in-one-checking.html |quote=Mrs. Hetty Sylvia Howland Green Wilks, daughter of the late Hetty Green, noted woman financier at the turn of the century, left an estate of approximately $95,000,000 according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. She died Feb. 5, 1951. |publisher=''[[New York Times]]'' |date=March 20, 1952|accessdate=2008-06-09 }} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{findagrave|159031558}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wilks, Matthew Astor}} [[Category:1844 births]] [[Category:1926 deaths]] [[Category:Astor family]] [[Category:Philanthropists from New York (state)]] [[Category:People included in New York Society's Four Hundred]]

'''Milo Duçi''' (1870–1933) was an [[Albanians|Albanian]] publisher, playwright, and entrepreneur. Born in [[Korçë]] (then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]]), he lived for most of his life in [[Egypt]].{{citation|pages=125–126|author=Robert Elsie|series=Historical Dictionaries of Europe| volume=75|title =Historical Dictionary of Albania|edition=2|publisher=The Scarecrow Press, Inc.|isbn=978-0-8108-6188-6 }} Together with his uncle [[Loni Logori]] he succeeded as an entrepreneur and distinguished activist of the [[Albanians in Egypt|Albanian community in Egypt]]. Duçi, son of a powerful [[Cotton|cotton merchant]] from Korçë,{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nTKaAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA84&lpg= |page=84| author=Isa Blumi|title=Ottoman Refugees, 1878-1939: Migration in a Post-Imperial World|publisher=Bloomsbury Academic| year=2013 | location=London | isbn=9781472515360 |oclc=830369887 }} settled in Egypt at the age of 23{{citation| url=http://www.albeu.com/opinion/shqiptaret-e-egjiptit-dhe-veprimtaria-atdhetare-e-tyre/1538/| language=Albanian|title=Shqiptarët e egjiptit dhe veprimtaria atdhetare e tyre|trans-title=Albanians of Egypt and their patriotic activity|author=Uran Asllani|publisher=Gazeta Metropol| date=2006-06-05| quote=
Po në atë vit, Thoma Avrami dhe Milo Duçi, botuan gazetën e dytë shqiptare, me titull «Besa- besë».
Atdhetari tjetër Milo Duçi, rilindas i kolonisë së Egjiptit, shkrimtar, publicist, linguist, kishte lindur me 1870 dhe shumë i ri, 23 vjeçar u vendos në Egjipt...
Më vonë në vitet 1925-1926, ai botoi të përjavëshmen « Bisedimet ».}} and became a merchant himself. He was one of the founders of "Vëllazëria" (Brotherhood) society, established in 1910 in [[Cairo]], and the [[Beni Suef]] branch of it with the support of the [[Khedive]] office. Duçi also started and directed several press organs of the Albanian diaspora in Egypt, mostly short-lived. These included the magazines ''Toska'' (The [[Tosks|Tosk]]) during 1901–02, ''Besa-Besë'' (Pledge for a pledge) during 1904–05 together with [[Thoma Avrami]], ''Besa'' ([[Besa (Albanian culture)|Besa]]) of 1905 which lasted for 6 issues and was printed by Al-Tawfik in Cairo,{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h2-sAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA129&lpg=PA129&dq= | pages=131–132| author=Isa Blumi|title=Foundations of Modernity: Human Agency and the Imperial State|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|year=2012|series= Routledge studies in modern history|number=9|isbn=9780415884648 |oclc=607983304 }} and newspapers ''Shqipëria'' (Albania) from October 1906 to February 1907, a daily of Cairo with the last two issues coming out in [[Maghagha]], and the weekly ''Bisedimet'' (The discussions) of 1925–26 with 60 issues in total, which would be the last Albanian-language newspaper in Egypt.{{cite book|last=Skendi|first=Stavro|title=The Albanian national awakening|year=1967|location=Princeton|publisher=Princeton University Press|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?hl=en&lr=&id=8QPWCgAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PR15&dq= |isbn=9781400847761|pages=152–153.|ref=harv}} He wrote several articles regarding the necessity for a unified literary [[Albanian language]] and the cultural-literary development of the Albanian society. In 1922 he established the [[publishing company]] ''Shtëpia botonjëse shqiptare/Société Albanaise d'édition'' (Albanian Publishing House).{{citation| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NatgAQAAQBAJ&pg=PT236&lpg= | title=Reinstating the Ottomans: Alternative Balkan Modernities, 1800-1912| author=Isa Blumi|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|location=New York| year=2011|isbn=9780230110182 |oclc=669751242}} He also left his footprint as a playwright; some of his [[comedy|comedies]] were ''E Thëna'' (The saying), ''Gjaku'' (The blood), ''I biri i Begut'' ([[Bey]]'s son). He also wrote short stories and poetry in the local press in Egypt.{{citation| language= Albanian| url=http://www.gazetadita.al/kush-ishte-milo-duci/|title=Kush ishte Milo Duçi?|trans-title=Who was Milo Duçi?| publisher=Gazeta Dita| date=2015-05-26}} In addition to the Albanian patriotic activity, Duçi was a successful entrepreneur. His family emerged as an important player in the economic development of Egypt's Delta region directed by [[Earl of Cromer|Lord Cromer]]'s office. By 1901, he started working with his well-connected uncle Loni Logori on projects that explicitly tied the commercial interest of the [[UK|British]] administration and the local landowners. Beside British, he openly solicited [[Austro-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian]] support, despite of the distrust that many [[Eastern Orthodox]] south-Albanians had for the Austrian Geo-politics. ''Toska'''s initial failure did not dissuade the Austrian authorities to support him; in 1902 they sent him 120 [[Austro-Hungarian krone|krone]] for the subscription, ordering the newspaper to be shipped to [[Vienna]] from where it would get distributed to [[Ottoman Albania]].
Through his uncle, Duçi would also get in touch with the Albanian [[émigré]] in [[Bucharest]], [[Italy]], [[Istanbul]], and [[Brussels]]. The French consul in [[Shkodër]] reported that Duçi collaborated with a defrocked [[Roman Catholicism in Albania|Catholic]] priest named Gaspar Jakova Merturi who secured funds from a claimant for the Albanian throne, Prince [[Albert Ghica]] of [[Romania]]. He also collaborated closely with the [[Arberesh]] journalist [[Anselmo Lorecchio]], editor of ''[[La Nazione Albanese]]''. ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Duci, Milo}} [[Category:1870 births]] [[Category:1933 deaths]] [[Category:Activists of the Albanian National Awakening]] [[Category:Albanian expatriates in Egypt]] [[Category:Albanian dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:Albanian publishers (people)]] [[Category:Albanian businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Korçë]] [[Category:People from Manastir Vilayet]] [[Category:19th-century Albanian people]] [[Category:20th-century Albanian people]] [[Category:Eastern Orthodox Christians from Albania]]

revision.comment: fix link to Samira Khashoggi (minor change)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Mohamed Fayed | image = Mohamed Al-Fayed.jpg | image_size = | caption = Fayed in 2011 | native_name = {{lang|ar|محمد أنور شاكر عبد السيد الفايد}} | birth_name = Mohamed Fayed | birth_place = {{birth date and age|df=29|1929|1|27}}
[[Bakos]], [[Alexandria]], [[Kingdom of Egypt|Egypt]] | nationality = [[Egyptian nationality law|Egyptian]]{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/mohamed-al-fayed/ |title=Mohamed Al Fayed |publisher=Forbes.com |date= |accessdate=8 January 2017}} | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = Businessman
Owner of [[Hôtel Ritz Paris]]
Owner of [[75 Rockefeller Plaza]] | networth = [[United States dollar|US$]]1.6 billion (2018) | spouse = {{marriage|[[Samira Taufiq]]
|1954|1956|end=}}
{{marriage|Heini Wathén
|1985}} | children = 5, including [[Dodi Fayed|Dodi]], [[Omar Fayed|Omar]] | website = | footnotes = | signature = }} '''Mohamed Al-Fayed''' ({{IPAc-en|æ|l|f|aɪ|ˈ|ɛ|d}}; {{lang-arz|محمد أنور شاكر عبد السيد الفايد}} {{IPA-arz|mahamad el fajed|}}; born Mohamed Fayed on 27 January 1929) is an [[Egypt]]ian business magnate. Fayed's business interests include ownership of [[Hôtel Ritz Paris]] and formerly [[Harrods Department Store]], [[Knightsbridge]]. Al-Fayed sold his ownership of [[Fulham F.C.]] to [[Shahid Khan]] in 2013. Fayed had a son, [[Dodi Fayed|Dodi]], from his first marriage to [[Samira Khashoggi|Samira Khashoggi]] from 1954 to 1956. Dodi [[Death of Diana, Princess of Wales|died in a car crash in Paris with Diana, Princess of Wales]] on 31 August 1997. Fayed later remarried to Finnish [[socialite]] and former model Heini Wathén in 1985, with whom he has four children: Jasmine, Karim, Camilla, and [[Omar Fayed|Omar]]. In 2013, Fayed's wealth was estimated at [[US$]]1.4 billion, making him the 1,031st-richest person in the world in 2013.{{cite news|last= |first= |title=The World's Millionaires|url=https://www.forbes.com/billionaires/list/||publisher=Forbes| accessdate=18 August 2013}} ==Early life== He was born '''Mohamed Fayed''' on 27 January 1929, in [[Bakos]], [[Alexandria]], [[Kingdom of Egypt|Egypt]],[[Who's Who]] 2008: London, [[A & C Black]], 2008 {{ISBN|978-0-7136-8555-8}} the eldest son of an Egyptian primary school teacher.{{cite news|title=Mohamed Al Fayed — the outsider with a taste for confrontation|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/business/moversshakers/article2506457.ece|accessdate=9 November 2015|newspaper=The Times|date=10 May 2010}} Fayed has five siblings: Ali, Ashraf, Salah, Soaad, and Safia.{{fact|date=April 2018}} Ali and Salah have been his business colleagues.{{cite news|last=Wild|first=Abigail|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12518304.Beset_by_secrets_and_lies_Profile__Mohamed_al_Fayed_A_high_profile_bid_to_become_a_British_citizen_and_the_death_of_his_son__Dodi__have_thrust_the_Egyptian_tycoon_into_the_spotlight__but_who_is_the_real_Mohamed_al_Fayed__By_Abigail_Wild/|title=Beset by secrets and lies Profile: Mohamed al Fayed|work=Sunday Herald|location=Glasgow|date=10 January 2004|accessdate=22 April 2018}} He was married for two years, from 1954 to 1956, to [[Samira Khashoggi]]. Fayed worked for his wife's brother, Saudi Arabian arms dealer and businessman [[Adnan Khashoggi]].{{cite news|last=Vallely|first=Paul|title=Mohamed al-Fayed: The outsider|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/mohamed-alfayed-the-outsider-396133.html|accessdate=26 February 2013|newspaper=The Independent|date=6 October 2007}} Some time in the early 1970s, he began using "Al-Fayed" rather than "Fayed". His brothers Ali and Salah began to follow suit at the time of their acquisition of the [[House of Fraser]] in the 1980s, though by the late 1980s, both had reverted to calling themselves simply "Fayed".{{harvnb|Brooke Aldous|1988a|p=619}} Some have assumed that Fayed's addition of "Al-" to his name was to imply aristocratic origins, like "de" in French or "von" in German, though ''Al-'' does not have the same social connotations in Arabic.{{cite news|title=Mohamed al-Fayed: The outsider|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/mohamed-al-fayed-the-outsider-396133.html|accessdate=6 March 2016|work=[[The Independent]]|date=5 October 2007}} This assumption led to ''[[Private Eye (magazine)|Private Eye]]'' nicknaming him the "Phoney Pharaoh".{{cite web|title=£1.5bn change in store at Harrods|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/retailandconsumer/7697397/1.5bn-change-in-store-at-Harrods.html|author=Richard Tyler and Robert Mendick|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=19 June 2013}} ==United Kingdom== [[File:DSC00797 - Copy.jpg|thumb|left|Wax sculpture of Mohammed Al-Fayed, Madame Tussauds, London, July 2009]] ===Early business dealings=== Fayed and his brothers founded a shipping company in Egypt before moving its headquarters to Genoa, Italy with additional offices in [[London]]. Around 1964 Fayed entered a close relationship with Haitian leader [[François Duvalier]], known as 'Papa Doc' Duvalier, and became interested in the construction of a Fayed-Duvalier oil refinery in [[Haiti]]. He also associated with the geologist [[George de Mohrenschildt]]. Fayed terminated his stay in Haiti six months later when a sample of "crude oil" provided by Haitian associates proved to be low-grade molasses.{{cite book|author=Alex Tunzelmann|title=[[Red Heat. Conspiracy, Murder, and the Cold War in the Caribbean]]|publisher=Henry Holt and Co., 2011|page=330f|isbn=978-0-8050-9067-3}} It was then that Fayed moved to [[England]] where he lived in [[central London]].{{Cite news |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/mohamed-al-fayed-the-outsider-with-a-taste-for-confrontation-n9tsq2qp8z0 |title=Mohamed Al Fayed — the outsider with a taste for confrontation |last=Lindsay |first=Robert |date=10 May 2010 |work=The Times |access-date=25 January 2018 |language=en |issn=0140-0460}} {{Registration required}} In the mid 1960s, Fayed met the ruler of Dubai, Sheikh [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]] who entrusted Fayed with helping transform [[Dubai]], where he set up IMS (International Marine Services) in 1968.{{cite book|last=Salihovic|first=Elnur|title=Major Players in the Muslim Business World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aSa1DAAAQBAJ&pg=PA117|accessdate=26 January 2018|date=5 October 2015|publisher=[[Universal Publishers (United States)|Universal Publishers]]|isbn=9781627340526|pages=117–118}} Fayed introduced British companies like the [[Costain Group]] (of which he became a director and 30 percent [[shareholder]]), [[Bernard Sunley & Sons]] and [[Taylor Woodrow]] to the Emirate to carry out the required construction work.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/09/08/business/harrod-s-new-owner-mohamed-al-fayed-a-quiet-acquisitor-is-caught-in-a-cross-fire.html |title=Harrod's New Owner: Mohamed Al-Fayed; a Quiet Acquisitor Is Caught in a Cross Fire |last=Feder |first=Barnaby J. |date=8 September 1985 |work=The New York Times |access-date=25 January 2018 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}} He also became a financial adviser to the then [[Sultan of Brunei]] [[Omar Ali Saifuddien III]], in 1966. He briefly joined the board of the mining conglomerate [[Lonrho]] in 1975 but left after a disagreement. In 1979, Fayed bought [[Hôtel Ritz Paris|The Ritz]] hotel in [[Paris]], [[France]] for US$30 million."The Ritz Paris" ''Mark Boxer'', ''Thames and Hudson'' 1991. In 1984, Fayed and his brothers purchased a 30 percent stake in [[House of Fraser]], a group that included the famous London store [[Harrods]], from [[Tiny Rowland|Roland 'Tiny' Rowland]], the head of Lonrho. In 1985, he and his brothers bought the remaining 70 percent of House of Fraser for £615m. Rowland claimed the Fayed brothers had lied about their background and wealth and put pressure on the government to investigate them. A [[Department of Trade and Industry (United Kingdom)|Department of Trade and Industry]] (DTI) inquiry into the Fayeds was launched. The DTI's subsequent report was critical, but no action was taken against the Fayeds, and while many believed the contents of the report, others felt it was politically motivated."The Guardian" ''Finance: DTI inquiries under attack'', by ''Lisa Buckingham'', 5 June 1997. In 1998, Rowland accused Fayed of stealing papers and jewels from his Harrods [[safe deposit box]]. Fayed was arrested, but the charges were dropped.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/136111.stm|title= Harrods Box Charges Dropped|publisher=BBC| date=20 July 1998}} Rowland died in 1998. Fayed settled the dispute with a payment to his widow; he also sued the [[Metropolitan Police]] for false arrest in 2002, but lost the case.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2002/aug/14/jamiewilson?INTCMP=SRCH|title=Fayed loses High Court Action Against Met|newspaper=The Guardian|date=13 August 2002|first=Jamie|last=Wilson}} In 1994, House of Fraser went public, but Fayed retained private ownership of Harrods. He relaunched the humour publication ''[[Punch magazine|Punch]]'' in 1996 but it folded again in 2002. Al Fayed unsuccessfully applied for [[British citizenship]] twice – once in 1994 and once in 1999.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/55867.stm|title=Al Fayed: A Unique Story of Rags to Riches|publisher=BBC|date=12 February 1998}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/law-report-minister-acted-unfairly-towards-the-fayeds-1353132.html|newspaper=The Independent|title=Law Report|date=19 November 1996}} It was suggested that the feud with Rowland contributed to Fayed's being refused British citizenship the first time.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7248639.stm BBC News] Retrieved 18 February 2008 ===Cash-for-questions=== In 1994, in what became known as the [[cash-for-questions affair]], Fayed revealed the names of MPs he had paid to ask questions in parliament on his behalf, but who had failed to declare their fees. It saw the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] MPs [[Neil Hamilton (politician)|Neil Hamilton]] and [[Tim Smith (UK politician)|Tim Smith]] leave the government in disgrace, and a Committee on Standards in Public Life established to prevent such corruption occurring again. Fayed also revealed that the cabinet minister [[Jonathan Aitken]] had stayed for free at the [[Hôtel Ritz Paris|Ritz Hotel in Paris]] at the same time as a group of Saudi arms dealers leading to Aitken's subsequent unsuccessful libel case and imprisonment for perjury.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/196466.stm|title=UK Politics: Talking Politics, Neil Hamilton – A chronology|publisher=BBC|date=19 October 1998}} During this period, from 1988 to February 1998, Al-Fayed's spokesman was [[Michael Cole (public relations)|Michael Cole]], a former BBC journalist,Steve Boggan [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/conspiracies-abound-as-cole-quits-toughest-job-in-pr-1145917.html "Conspiracies abound as Cole quits `toughest job in PR '"], ''The Independent'', 21 February 1998 although Cole's PR work for Al-Fayed did not cease in 1998. Hamilton lost a subsequent libel action against Al-Fayed in December 1999Matt Wells, et al [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/1999/dec/22/hamiltonvalfayed.conservatives "A greedy, corrupt liar"], ''The Guardian'', 22 December 1999 and a subsequent appeal against the verdict in December 2000.[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/dec/21/hamiltonvalfayed "Neil Hamilton loses libel appeal"], theguardian.com. 21 December 2000 The former MP has always denied that he was paid by Al-Fayed for asking questions in parliament. Hamilton's libel action related to a [[Channel 4]] ''[[Dispatches (TV series)|Dispatches]]'' documentary broadcast on 16 January 1997[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm199798/cmselect/cmstnprv/030ii/sp0157.htm "Appendix 33 – continued: Appendix 1 Channel 4 and Fourth Estate Press Releases"], Select Committee on Standards and Privileges First Report, House of Commons, January 1997 in which Al-Fayed made claims that the MP had received up to £110,000 in cash and received other gratuities for asking parliamentary questions.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/573630.stm "Hamilton loses libel case"], BBC News, 21 December 1999 Hamilton's basis for his appeal was that the original verdict was invalid because Al-Fayed had paid £10,000 for documents stolen from the dustbins of Hamilton's legal representatives by [[Benjamin Pell]],Steven Moss [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/dec/12/hamiltonvalfayed.stevenmorris "Fayed 'paid for stolen papers'"], ''The Guardian'', 12 December 2000 also known as 'Benjy the Binman'. In 2003, Fayed moved from [[Surrey]], UK to [[Switzerland]], alleging a breach in an agreement with [[Inland Revenue]]. In 2005, he moved back to [[United Kingdom|Britain]], saying that he "regards Britain as home". He moored a yacht in [[Monaco]] called the ''[[Sokar (yacht)|Sokar]]'' prior to selling it in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://holiday.monacoeye.com/monaco_yacht_show.php|title=Monaco Yacht Show |publisher=Holiday|accessdate=22 August 2010}} ===Sale of Harrods=== After previously denying that Harrods was for sale, Harrods was sold to [[Qatar Investment Authority|Qatar Holdings]], the [[sovereign wealth fund]] of the emirate of [[Qatar]], on 10 May 2010. A fortnight previously, Fayed had stated that "People approach us from Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Qatar. Fair enough. But I put two fingers up to them. It is not for sale. This is not Marks and Spencer or Sainsbury's. It is a special place that gives people pleasure. There is only one Mecca."{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/qatar-the-tiny-gulf-state-that-bought-the-world-1970551.html |title=Qatar, the tiny gulf state that bought the world|newspaper=The Independent|date=11 May 2010|accessdate=22 August 2010}} Harrods was sold for £1.5 billion. Fayed later revealed in an interview that he decided to sell Harrods following the difficulty in getting his [[dividend]] approved by the trustee of the Harrods pension fund. Fayed said "I'm here every day, I can't take my profit because I have to take a permission of those bloody idiots. I say is this right? Is this logic? Somebody like me? I run a business and I need to take bloody fucking trustee's permission to take my profit".{{cite web|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23838358-a-four-letter-farewell-from-mohammed-fayed.do|title=Mohammed Fayed: Why I Sold Harrods|publisher=London Evening Standard|date=26 May 2010|accessdate=22 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100701144627/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23838358-a-four-letter-farewell-from-mohammed-fayed.do|archivedate=1 July 2010|df=dmy-all}} Fayed was appointed honorary chairman of Harrods, a position he was scheduled to hold for at least six months. ===Scotland=== In 1972, Fayed purchased the Balnagown estate in [[Easter Ross]], Northern [[Scotland]]. From an initial twelve acres, Al-Fayed has since built the estate up to sixty-five thousand acres.{{Cite news|date=4 July 2005|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/alfayed-to-fill-highland-estate-with-jetset-homes-497551.html|title=Al-Fayed to fill Highland estate with jet-set homes|newspaper=The Independent|location=London|first=Paul|last=Kelbie}} Al-Fayed has invested more than £20 million in the estate, restored the 14th century pink [[Balnagown Castle]], and created a tourist accommodation business. The Highlands of Scotland tourist board awarded Al-Fayed the "Freedom of the Highlands" in 2002, in recognition of his "outstanding contribution and commitment to the highlands." As an Egyptian with links to Scotland, Al-Fayed was intrigued enough to fund a 2008 reprint of the 15th-century chronicle ''[[Scotichronicon]]'' by [[Walter Bower]]. The ''Scotichronicon'' describes how Scota, a sister of the Egyptian Pharaoh [[Tutankhamen]], fled her family and landed in Scotland, bringing with her the [[Stone of Scone]]. According to the chronicle, Scotland was later named in her honour. The tale is disputed by modern historians.{{Cite news|date=19 May 2008|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/article3965279.ece|title=Al Fayed, a Princess and another theory the establishment denies|newspaper=The Times|location=London|first=Mike|last=Wade}} Al-Fayed later declared that "The Scots are originally Egyptians and that's the truth."{{Cite news|date=25 October 2009|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/scotland/article6889088.ece|title=Forget Salmond: Make me your ruler|newspaper=The Times|location=London|first=Marc|last=Horne}} In 2009, Al-Fayed revealed that he was a supporter of [[Scottish independence]] from the United Kingdom, announcing to the Scots that "It's time for you to waken up and detach yourselves from the English and their terrible politicians...whatever help is needed for Scotland to regain its independence, I will provide it...when you Scots regain your freedom, I am ready to be your president." ===Charity=== Fayed set up the Al Fayed Charitable Foundation in 1987 aiming to help children with life-limiting conditions and children living in poverty. The charity works mainly with charities and hospices for disabled and neglected children in the UK, Thailand and Mongolia.{{Cite web|url=http://www.the-acf.com/who-we-are.aspx|title=Who we are - The AlFayed Charitable Foundation - ACF|website=www.the-acf.com|access-date=11 October 2017}} Some of the charities with which it works include Francis House Hospice in Manchester, Great Ormond Street Hospital and ChildLine. In 1998, Al Fayed bought [[Princess Diana]]'s old boarding school in Kent and helped found the New School at West Heath for traumatised children there.{{cite web|url=http://www.thirdsector.co.uk/news/620770/charitable-side-Mohamed-Al-Fayed/?HAYILC=RELATED |title=The charitable side of ... Mohamed Al Fayed|publisher=The third sector|accessdate=28 June 2013}} In 2011, Mohamed Al-Fayed's daughter Camilla, who has worked as an ambassador for the charity for eight years,{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/heiress-camilla-al-fayed-liverpool-3010791 |title=Heiress Camilla Al Fayed on why Liverpool babies’ hospice Zoe’s Place is an inspiration|publisher=Liverpool Echo|accessdate=28 June 2013}} opened the newly refurbished Zoe’s Place baby hospice in West Derby, Liverpool.{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/liverpool-news/regional-news/2011/09/09/camilla-al-fayed-opens-newly-refurbished-zoe-s-place-baby-hospice-in-west-derby-99623-29389925/ |title=Camilla Al Fayed opens newly refurbished Zoe’s Place baby hospice in West Derby |publisher=Liverpool Daily Post|accessdate=28 June 2013}} ===Fulham F.C.=== {{Main|Fulham F.C.#1997–2001: Al Fayed takeover}} Al-Fayed bought the [[Freehold (law)|freehold]] of West London professional football club [[Fulham F.C.]] for £6.25 million in 1997.{{Cite news|date=7 February 2003|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/2395783/Fulham-pushed-out-Hill.html|title=Fulham pushed out Hill|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|location=London|first=Mihir|last=Bose}} The club was purchased via Bill Muddyman's Muddyman Group. His long-term aim was that Fulham would become a [[FA Premier League]] side within five years. In 2001, Fulham took the First Division (now [[Football League Championship]]) under manager [[Jean Tigana]], winning 100 points and scoring over 100 goals in the season. This meant that Al-Fayed had achieved his objective of Fulham becoming a Premier League club a year ahead of schedule. By 2002, Fulham were competing in European football, winning the [[Intertoto Cup]] and challenging in the [[UEFA Cup]]. Fulham reached the final of the [[2009–10 UEFA Europa League]] and continued to play in the Premier League throughout Al-Fayed's tenure as owner (which ended in 2013). Fulham temporarily left [[Craven Cottage]] while it was being upgraded to meet modern safety standards. There were fears that Fulham would not return to the Cottage after it was revealed that Al-Fayed had sold the first right to build on the ground to a property development firm.{{cite news|title=Fulham's future hangs in balance|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/f/fulham/3084328.stm|work=BBC Sport|date=15 September 2003}} Fulham lost a legal case against former manager Tigana in 2004 after Al-Fayed had wrongly alleged that Tigana had overpaid more than £7m for new players and had negotiated transfers in secret.{{cite news|title=Fulham lose Tigana court battle|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/f/fulham/4005735.stm|newspaper=BBC|date=12 November 2004}} In 2009, Al-Fayed said that he was in favour of a wage cap for footballers, and criticised the management of [[The Football Association]] and [[Premier League]] as "run by donkeys who don't understand business, who are dazzled by money."{{Cite news|date=29 April 2009|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/funny_old_game/8024421.stm|title=Sport quotes of the week|work=BBC Sport|first=Chris|last=Charles}} A statue of the American entertainer [[Michael Jackson]] was unveiled by Al-Fayed in April 2011 at Craven Cottage In 1999 Jackson had attended a league game against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] at the stadium. Following criticisms of the statue, Al-Fayed said "If some stupid fans don't understand and appreciate such a gift this guy gave to the world they can go to hell. I don't want them to be fans."{{Cite news|date=3 April 2011 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-12950708|title=Michael Jackson Fulham FC statue defended by Al Fayed|publisher=BBC News}} The statue was removed by the club's new owners in 2013; Al-Fayed blamed the club's subsequent relegation from the Premier League on the 'bad luck' brought by its removal. Al-Fayed then donated the statue to the National Football Museum.{{Cite news|date=6 May 2014 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27302594|title=Michael Jackson statue moves to National Football Museum|publisher=BBC News}} Under Al-Fayed Fulham F.C. was owned by Mafco Holdings, based in the [[tax haven]] of [[Bermuda]]. Mafco Holdings is owned by Al-Fayed and his family. By 2011, Al-Fayed had loaned Fulham F.C. £187 million in interest free loans.{{Cite news|date=19 May 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/may/19/premier-league-finances-black-hole?INTCMP=SRCH|title=Record income but record losses for Premier League|newspaper=The Guardian|location=London|first=David|last=Conn}} In July 2013, it was announced that Al-Fayed had sold the club to Pakistani American businessman [[Shahid Khan]], who owns the [[National Football League|NFL]]'s [[Jacksonville Jaguars]].{{cite news|title=Al-Fayed sells Fulham to Shahid Khan|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23297785|publisher=BBC Sport|date=12 July 2013}} == Dodi's death == {{Further|Death of Diana, Princess of Wales|Death of Diana, Princess of Wales conspiracy theories}} ===Romance with Diana, Princess of Wales=== [[Diana, Princess of Wales|Lady Diana Spencer]] was born in 1961, and married the [[Line of succession to the British throne|heir to the British throne]], [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], in 1981, becoming the Princess of Wales. Diana was an international celebrity and a frequent visitor to Harrods in the 1980s. Al-Fayed and Dodi first met Diana and Charles when they were introduced at a [[polo]] tournament in July 1986, that had been sponsored by Harrods.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-740497.html|title=Diana's Life on Display: Sometimes Storybook, Sometimes Soap Opera |author=David van Drehle |publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' |date=31 August 1997 |accessdate=11 October 2013}} ([[HighBeam Research]] subscription required) Diana and Charles divorced in 1996. Diana was hosted by Al-Fayed in the south of France in the summer of 1997, with her two sons, the Princes [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|William]] and [[Prince Harry|Harry]].{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-13112834.html|title=Coroner at Diana inquest dismisses all the conspiracy theories over fatal car crash Mohamed al-Fayed expresses surprise over the tone and content of remarks he says should be left to the jury to consider |author=Stephen McGinty |publisher=''[[The Scotsman]]'' |date=3 October 2007 |accessdate=11 October 2013}} ([[HighBeam Research]] subscription required) For the holiday, Fayed bought a 195 ft yacht, the ''Jonikal'' (later renamed the ''[[Sokar (yacht)|Sokar]]'').{{cite web|date=19 May 2010 |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/features/2008/05/dunne200805|title=Two Ladies, Two Yachts, and a Billionaire|newspaper=''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)]]''|location=New York|author=[[Dominick Dunne]]|accessdate=11 October 2013}} Dodi and Diana later began a private cruise on the ''Jonikal'' and [[paparazzi]] photographs of the couple in an embrace were published. Diana's friend, the journalist Richard Kay, confirmed that Diana was involved in "her first serious romance" since her divorce.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-4409051.html|title=Di and Dodi's short summer |publisher=''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' |date=7 September 1997 |accessdate=11 October 2013}} ([[HighBeam Research]] subscription required) Dodi and Diana went on a second private cruise on the ''Jonikal'' in the third week of August, and returned from Sardinia to Paris on 30 August. The couple privately dined at the Ritz later that day, after the behaviour of the press caused them to cancel a restaurant reservation, they then planned to spend the night at Dodi's apartment near the [[Arc de Triomphe]].{{Cite news|date=14 December 2006|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/6219252.stm|title=Diana and Dodi: Their final hours|work=BBC News Online}} In an attempt to deceive the paparazzi, a decoy car left the front of the hotel, while Diana and Dodi departed at speed in a [[Mercedes-Benz W140]] driven by chauffeur [[Henri Paul]] from the rear of the hotel. Five minutes later, the car crashed in the [[Pont de l'Alma]] tunnel, killing Paul and Dodi. Diana died later in hospital. Fayed arrived in Paris the next day and viewed Dodi's body, which was returned to Britain for an [[Islamic funeral]].{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-64636402.html|title=Fayed Is Buried After Quiet Islamic Tribute |publisher=''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'' |date=1 September 1997 |accessdate=11 October 2013}} ([[HighBeam Research]] subscription required) ===Conspiracy theories=== From February 1998, Al-Fayed maintained that the crash was a result of a conspiracy,{{Cite news|date=12 February 1998|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/55800.stm|title=Diana crash was a conspiracy – Al Fayed|work=BBC News Online}} and later contended that the crash was orchestrated by [[Secret Intelligence Service|MI6]] on the instructions of [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh]].{{Cite news|date=19 February 1998|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/55800.stm|title=Point-by-point: Al Fayed's claims|work=BBC News Online}} His claims that the crash was a result of a conspiracy were dismissed by a French judicial investigation, but Fayed appealed against this verdict. A libel action was brought against Al-Fayed by Neil Hamilton (see above). During the questioning of one day of the hearing, which referred to Al-Fayed's conspiracy theories, writer Martyn Gregory and a journalist from [[ITN]] counted 70 instances of Al-Fayed saying "I don't know" or "I can't remember" to questions relating to the tragedy.Martyn Gregory "How Fayed is Paying For His Diana Lies", ''The Spectator'', 8 January 2000 The British [[Operation Paget]], a [[Metropolitan police]] inquiry that concluded in 2006, also found no evidence of a conspiracy.{{Cite news|date=14 December 2006|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/6179275.stm|title=Diana death a 'tragic accident'|work=BBC News Online}} To Operation Paget, Al-Fayed made 175 "conspiracy claims".Martyn Gregory [https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/commentators/martyn-gregory-alfayed-cant-rewrite-the-death-of-diana-394391.html "Al-Fayed can't rewrite the death of Diana"], ''The Independent'', 7 October 2007 An inquest headed by [[Scott Baker (judge)|Lord Justice Scott Baker]] into the deaths of Diana and Dodi began at the [[Royal Courts of Justice]], London, on 2 October 2007 and lasted for six months. It was a continuation of the original inquest that had begun in 2004.{{cite web |url=http://www.scottbaker-inquests.gov.uk/faq/index.htm |archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20080521144222/http://www.scottbaker-inquests.gov.uk/faq/index.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 May 2008 |title=Inquests into the deaths of Diana, Princess of Wales and Mr Dodi Al Fayed: FAQs |accessdate=4 June 2010 |year=2008 |work=Coroner's Inquests into the Deaths of Diana, Princess of Wales and Mr Dodi Al Fayed |publisher=Judicial Communications Office}} At the Scott Baker inquest Fayed accused the [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Duke of Edinburgh]], the [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince of Wales]], [[Lady Sarah McCorquodale]], her sister, and numerous others, of plotting to kill the Princess of Wales.Stephen Bates [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/feb/19/diana.monarchy "They're all guilty? 'Definitely.' Fayed gets his day in court"], ''The Guardian'', 19 February 2008 Their motive, he claimed, was that they could not tolerate the idea of the Princess marrying a Muslim.Angela Balakrishnan [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/apr/07/diana.monarchy1 "Pregnancy rumours, MI6 plots and Henri Paul"], theguardian.com, 7 April 2008 Al-Fayed first claimed that the Princess was pregnant to the ''[[Daily Express]]'' in May 2001, and that he was the only person who had been told of this news. Witnesses at the inquest who said the Princess was not pregnant, and could not have been, were part of the conspiracy according to Al-Fayed.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7250002.stm "Diana murdered, Al Fayed claims"], BBC News, 18 February 2008 Fayed's testimony at the inquest was roundly condemned in the press as being farcical. Members of the British Government's [[Intelligence and Security Committee]] accused Fayed of turning the inquest into a 'circus' and called for it to be ended maturely.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7256665.stm|work=BBC News|title=Coroner warning in Diana inquest|date=21 February 2008| accessdate=13 May 2010}} Lawyers representing Al-Fayed later accepted at the inquest that there was no direct evidence that either the Duke of Edinburgh or MI6 had been involved in any murder conspiracy involving Diana or Dodi.{{Cite news|date=7 April 2008|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7326311.stm|title=Fayed conspiracy claim collapses|work=BBC News Online}} A few days before Al-Fayed's appearance, John Macnamara, a former senior detective at Scotland Yard and Al-Fayed's investigator for five years from 1997, was forced to admit on 14 February 2008 that he had no evidence to suggest foul play, except for the assertions Al-Fayed had made to him.Stephen Bates [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/feb/15/monarchy "Diana conspiracy theory unravels as Fayed's investigator tells of lies and lack of evidence"], ''The Guardian'', 15 February 2008 His admissions also related to the lack of evidence for Al-Fayed's claims about the alleged pregnancy of the Princess and the couple's supposed engagement. The jury verdict, given on 7 April 2008, was that Diana and Dodi had been "[[unlawful killing|unlawfully killed]]" through the [[Gross negligence|grossly negligent]] driving of chauffeur [[Henri Paul]],{{cite web| url=http://www.scottbaker-inquests.gov.uk/hearing_transcripts/verdict.htm | archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20080521144222/http://www.scottbaker-inquests.gov.uk/hearing_transcripts/verdict.htm | dead-url=yes | archive-date=21 May 2008 |title=Hearing transcripts: 7 April 2008 – Verdict of the jury|publisher=Judicial Communications Office|accessdate=15 August 2010}} who was [[Alcohol intoxication|intoxicated]], and the pursuing vehicles.{{Cite news | title=Diana jury blames paparazzi and Henri Paul for her 'unlawful killing' | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1584160/Diana-jury-blames-paparazzi-and-Henri-Paul-for-her-unlawful-killing.html | accessdate=12 October 2013 | work=Daily Telegraph | date=7 April 2008}} Lawyers for Al-Fayed also accepted that there was no evidence to support the assertion that Diana was illegally embalmed in order to cover up a pregnancy, a "pregnancy" that they accepted, could not be established by any medical evidence. They also accepted that there was no evidence to support the assertion the French emergency and medical services had played any role in a conspiracy to harm Diana. Following the Baker inquest, Al-Fayed said that he was abandoning his campaign to prove that Diana and Dodi were murdered in a conspiracy, and said that he would accept the verdict of the jury.{{Cite news|date=8 April 2008|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7337789.stm|title=Al Fayed abandons Diana campaign|work=BBC News Online}} Al-Fayed financially supported ''[[Unlawful Killing (film)|Unlawful Killing]]'' (2011), a documentary film accused of presenting his version of events.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/cannes-film-festival/8513112/Unlawful-Killing-film-about-the-death-of-Diana-likens-Prince-Philip-to-Fred-West.html |title=Unlawful Killing: film about the death of Diana likens Prince Philip to Fred West|accessdate=11 May 2011|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|location=London |first=Anita|last=Singh|date=13 May 2011}} The film was not formally released as a result of legal problems.Ben Child [https://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/jul/05/princess-diana-documentary-unlawful-killing "Princess Diana documentary Unlawful Killing is shelved"], ''The Guardian'' (London), 5 July 2012 == Business interests == [[File:75 Rockefeller Plaza by David Shankbone.jpg|thumb|right|upright|75 Rockefeller Plaza]] Al-Fayed's business interests include: * [[Hôtel Ritz Paris]] * [[Balnagowan Castle]] & Estates * [[HJW Geospatial]] * [[Turnbull & Asser]] * [[75 Rockefeller Plaza]] – built in 1947, originally the Esso Building, later the Time Warner Building; is owned by Al-Fayed{{cite web|url=http://therealdeal.com/blog/2012/01/25/75-rockefeller-plaza-needs-tenants-manager-in-2014/|title=75 Rockefeller Plaza - Time Warner Lease - Mohamed Al-Fayed|date=25 January 2012|work=The Real Deal New York}} and managed and leased by [[RXR Realty]]{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-01-14/rxr-said-to-buy-99-year-leasehold-at-75-rockefeller-plaza|title=RXR Said to Buy 99-Year Leasehold at 75 Rockefeller Plaza|author=David M Levitt|date=15 January 2013|work=Bloomberg.com}} Al-Fayed's major business purchases have included: * Ritz Hotel Paris (1979, {{£|10 million}}) * House of Fraser Group, including [[Harrods]] (1985, £615 million; sold 2010, £1.5 billion).{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8669657.stm|title=Mohammed Fayed sells Harrods store to Qatar Holdings|date=8 May 2010 |work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=BBC|accessdate=8 May 2010}} * [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] (1997, £30 million; sold 2013{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23297785|title=Fulham: Mohamed Al Fayed sells club to Shahid Khan|publisher=BBC Sport|date=12 July 2013|accessdate=12 July 2013}}). * After the death of [[Wallis Simpson]], Fayed took over the lease of the [[Villa Windsor]] in Paris, the former home of the Duchess of Windsor and her husband, the Duke of Windsor, previously [[Edward VIII]].{{Cite journal|date=1 January 1990|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20116503,00.html|title=Egypt's Al Fayed Restores the House Fit for a Former King |newspaper=[[People (American magazine)|People]]}} ==Sexual harassment allegations== Al-Fayed has been accused by multiple women of [[sexual harassment]] and assault.{{Cite news |date=24 October 1998|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/1998/oct/24/hamiltonvalfayed|title=Crossing swords with Mohamed|work=The Guardian|location=London|first=Henry|last=Porter}}{{Cite news|last=Boggan|first=Steve|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/al-fayed-accused-harrods-boss-rejects-charges-of-lechery-and-bugging-1289749.html|title=Al Fayed Accused: Harrods boss rejects charges of lechery and bugging|work=The Independent|location=London |date=20 December 1997}} Young women applying for employment at Harrods were often submitted to [[HIV test]]s and gynaecological examinations.{{cite book|last=Bower|first=Tom |title=Fayed: The Unauthorized Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ygLDIAAACAAJ|year=1998|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-0-333-74554-0|page=271–72}} These women were then selected to spend the weekend with Al-Fayed in Paris. In her profile of Al-Fayed for ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', [[Maureen Orth]] described how according to former employees "Fayed regularly walked the store on the lookout for young, attractive women to work in his office. Those who rebuffed him would often be subjected to crude, humiliating comments about their appearance or dress...A dozen ex-employees I spoke with said that Fayed would chase secretaries around the office and sometimes try to stuff money down women's blouses".{{Cite news |url=https://maureenorth.com/2010/09/holy-war-at-harrods-mohamed-al-fayed/|title=Holy War at Harrods|work=Vanity Fair|date=1 September 1995}} In 1994, Hermina Da Silva quit her job as a nanny at Al-Fayed's home in [[Oxted]]. Da Silva had prepared accusations that she was sexually harassed by Al-Fayed, and she was subsequently arrested by detectives and held overnight in cells following a complaint of theft by an employee of Al-Fayeds. She was later released without charge after officers concluded she had not stolen anything. Al-Fayed eventually settled with her out of court, and she was awarded £12,000. Al-Fayed was interviewed under caution by the [[Metropolitan Police]] after an allegation of sexual assault against a 15-year-old schoolgirl in October 2008. The case was dropped by the [[Crown Prosecution Service]], after they found that there was no realistic chance of conviction due to conflicting statements.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/7894870.stm|title=No Sex Charges for Harrods Owner|work=BBC News|date=17 February 2009}} In December 1997, the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] current affairs programme, ''The Big Story'' broadcast testimonies from a number of former Harrods employees who spoke of how women were routinely sexually harassed by Al-Fayed. A December 2017 episode of Channel 4's ''[[Dispatches (TV series)|Dispatches]]'' programme alleged that Al-Fayed had sexually harassed three Harrods employees, and attempted to "groom" them. One of the women was aged 17 at the time. Cheska Hill-Wood, now in her 40s, waived her right to anonymity to be interviewed for the programme.{{cite news|last=Mendick|first=Robert|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/12/08/mohamed-al-fayed-accused-harassing-17-year-old-harrods-employee/|title=Mohamed Al-Fayed accused of harassing 17-year-old Harrods' employee|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=8 December 2017|accessdate=5 March 2018}} The programme alleged al-Fayed targeted young employees over a 13 year period.{{cite news|last=Brown|first=David|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/mohamed-al-fayed-accused-of-sexually-harassing-young-staff-688twtk2v|title=Mohamed Al Fayed accused of sexually harassing young staff|work=The Times|date=8 December 2017|accessdate=5 March 2018}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== *{{cite book|author1=Henry Brooke|author2=Hugh Graham Cazalet Aldous|title=House of Fraser Holdings Plc: Investigation Under Section 432 (2) of the Companies ACT 1985: Report|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vZGrAQAACAAJ|accessdate=19 June 2013|date=1 January 1988|publisher=H.M. Stationery Office|isbn=978-0-11-514652-7}} == External links == {{Portal|Egypt|Biography}} {{Wikiquote}} {{Commons category}} * {{Official website|http://www.alfayed.com}} * {{YouTube|KXfpTxFjCWk|Interview with Al Jazeera (English) Riz Khan}} * [http://www.the-acf.com/ Al-Fayed Charitable Foundation] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fayed, Mohamed}} [[Category:1929 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Scottish billionaires]] [[Category:Conspiracy theorists]] [[Category:Egyptian billionaires]] [[Category:Egyptian businesspeople]] [[Category:Egyptian emigrants to England]] [[Category:Egyptian Muslims]] [[Category:Egyptian football chairmen and investors]] [[Category:Egyptian expatriates in England]] [[Category:Egyptian expatriates in Monaco]] [[Category:Fulham F.C. directors and chairmen]] [[Category:Hoteliers]] [[Category:House of Fraser]] [[Category:People from Alexandria]] [[Category:Harrods]] [[Category:Egyptian emigrants to Switzerland]]

revision.comment: link, fix gender (unless there's some tabloid scoop I missed)
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = [[Countess]] | name = Noemi Marone Cinzano | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1957}} | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|Month DD, YYYY|Month DD, YYYY}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = Italian | other_names = | occupation = Businessperson | known_for = |spouse= Hans Vinding-Diers | children = 2 | relatives = [[Francesco Marone Cinzano]] (brother) }}
[[Countess]] '''Noemi Marone Cinzano''' (born 1957) is an Italian<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wineportfolio.com/c/?tag=italian-countess-noemi-marone-cinzano |title=Wine of the Week - Bodega Noema 'A Lisa' 2009 |date=July 29, 2011 |publisher=Wine Portfolio }}</ref> businessperson. A wine personality, she is known for owning many well established vineyards and Cinzano Glass.<ref name="BR"/> Her flagship wine is considered to be Noemía de Patagonia.
==Biography==
Cinzano is the daughter of the late [[Alberto Marone Cinzano]], and the elder sister of [[Francesco Marone Cinzano]], who owns [[Col d’Orcia]].<ref name="Capalbo1998">{{cite book|last=Capalbo|first=Carla|title=A Food Lover's Companion to Tuscany|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CJYTak3ViHAC|accessdate=5 May 2013|date=1 March 1998|publisher=Chronicle Books|isbn=978-0-8118-1209-2|page=288}}</ref> She has two children.<ref name="Decanter 1">{{cite news|newspaper=[[Decanter (magazine)|Decanter]] |title=Tenuta di Argiano sold |date=February 11, 2013 |last=Waldin |first=Monty |url=http://www.decanter.com/news/wine-news/530849/tenuta-di-argiano-sold }}</ref> Cinzano arrived in [[Brazil]] at the age of 17.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.argiano.net/en/azienda_contessa.htm |title=Countess Noemi Marone Cinzano |publisher=Argiano |accessdate=May 4, 2013 }}</ref>
She has assisted the organization of numerous wine exhibitions throughout the world.<ref name="BR">{{cite book|title=Beverage Review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YvlIAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=5 May 2013|year=1981|publisher=Pacific Publications|page=39}}</ref>
==Vineyards and wineries==
Cinzano took over her father's [[vermouth]] business after his death in 1990, and in 1992 she bought the [[Tenuta di Argiano]], a 16th-century 120 acre (50ha) vineyard, in a {{Convert|100|ha}} estate; produced 337,000 bottles of wine which included 109,000 [[Brunello di Montalcino]] wine. Exporting to the [[United States]], [[United Kingdom]], Brazil, [[Denmark]] and [[Japan]], Tenuta di Argiano is one of the top ten largest producers, by volume, of Brunnello Montalcino and [[Rosso di Montalcino]] wine.<ref name="Decanter 1"/><ref name="Wine Spectator">{{cite news|url=http://www.winespectator.com/webfeature/show/id/48032 |newspaper=Wine Spectator |title=Montalcino's Argiano Has New Owners |date=February 11, 2013 |last=Sanderson |first=Bruce }}</ref><ref name=wine>{{Cite news|url=http://www.winenews.it/news/30077/argiano-una-delle-pi-antiche-tenute-di-montalcino-con-oltre-100-ettari-di-terreno-53-a-vigneto-e-la-splendida-villa-rinascimentale-venduta-da-noemi-marone-cinzano-stando-ai-rumors-affare-da-40-50-milioni-di-euro-e-compratori-brasiliani|title=Argiano, Una Delle Più Antiche Tenute Di Montalcino, Con Oltre 100 Ettari Di Terreno (53 A Vigneto), E La Splendida Villa Rinascimentale, Venduta Da Noemi Marone Cinzano. Stando Ai Rumors, Affare Da 40-50 Milioni Di Euro E Compratori Brasiliani|language=Italian|accessdate=21 May 2013|publisher=Website of Winenews }}</ref> Solengo was produced in the vineyards of her much respected Brunello estate which is set around her villa, the [[Tuscany (wine)|Tuscany]] Tenuta di Argiano (built in the 1570s) built in Renaissance architectural style.<ref name=wine/><ref>{{cite book|title=The Wine Spectator|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4ftJAAAAYAAJ|year=1998|publisher=Wine Group|page=114}}</ref>
During Cinzano's ownership, Tenuta di Argiano was one of the Brunello di Montalcino estates that was investigated during the ''[[Brunellopoli]]'' scandal for suspicion of [[wine fraud|adulterating]] the wines with other [[grape varieties]] which, under ''[[Denominazione di Origine Controllata e Garantita]]'' (DOCG) regulations are supposed to be made from 100% [[Sangiovese]]. In 2008, the suspected [[vintage]]s were impounded by government officials and eventually Tenuta di Argiano declassified the wines, selling them as "[[Super Tuscans]]" under the ''[[Indicazione Geografica Tipica]]'' (IGT) designation instead of as Brunello di Montalcinos.<ref name="Wine Spectator"/> In February 2013 Cinzano sold the Tenuta di Argiano estate to an undisclosed "group of international investors" for reportedly near 50 million euros. Production of the estate is said to be around 120,000 bottles.<ref name="Decanter 1"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wine-searcher.com/m/2013/02/montalcino-accused-of-selling-out-to-foreign-investors |title=Montalcino Accused of Selling Out To Foreign Investors |last=Gobb |first=Rebecca |date=February 13, 2013 }}</ref>
Together with her partner and winemaking consultant, [[Hans Vinding-Diers]], she co-founded the Noemía de Patagonia in 2002, in [[Argentina (wine)|Argentina]]. This Bodega Noemìa de Patagonia’s project had been established in 1998 by subsuming an [[old vine]] [[Malbec]] vineyard in the [[Río Negro (Argentina)|Rio Negro]] Valley that was planted in the 1930s and 1950s.<ref name="Decanter 1"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.winesur.com/news/it-is-crucial-that-argentinas-producers-keep-making-serious-wines|title=It is crucial that Argentina’s producers keep making serious wines|accessdate=21 May 2013|publisher=Winesur.com}}</ref> The vines are [[grafting|ungrafted]] and planted on their [[rootstock]] in the [[Patagonian Desert]] which has little risk of developing [[phylloxera]]. All of Bodega Noemìa de Patagonia’s vineyard properties are [[Biodynamic wine|farmed biodynamically]].<ref name="Opus">J. Gordon (ed) ''Opus Vino'' pgs 155-156, DK Publishing New York 2010, {{ISBN|978-0-7566-6751-1}}</ref> Noemía is considered to be her flagship wine and has been included in the book ''1001 Wines: You Must Try Before You Die 2011''.<ref>{{cite book|title=1001 Wines: You Must Try Before You Die 2011|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FQdqHCmnEekC&pg=PT1043|accessdate=5 May 2013|date=5 February 2012|publisher=Octopus|isbn=978-1-84403-720-9|page=1043}}</ref>
==See also==

'''Peter Cook''' is executive vice president and chief communications officer of the [[American Bankers Association]]. Previously he was press secretary to U.S. Defense Secretary [[Ashton Carter]] and the [[Assistant to the Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs]], replacing Maura Sullivan in that role. He previously served as Washington Anchor for [[Bloomberg Television]].
Cook joined Bloomberg Television in October 2003. As Washington Anchor and Correspondent, he co-anchors Bloomberg’s morning programming and reports on the intersection of business and government.<ref>http://thehill.com/capital-living/media-sketch/20965-peter-cook-bloombergs-early-riser</ref> In recent months{{when|date=December 2011}}, Cook has covered every angle of the financial crisis, regularly breaking news on the government's unprecedented response. He has interviewed key Washington players including Treasury Secretary [[Tim Geithner]], former Secretary [[Henry Paulson]], White House economic adviser [[Larry Summers]], Senate Banking Committee Chairman [[Chris Dodd]] and Senate Minority Leader [[Mitch McConnel]]l plus business leaders such as [[JPMorgan Chase]] CEO [[Jamie Dimon]].
Before his shift to the morning, Peter hosted Bloomberg's "Money & Politics" program and spearheaded BLOOMBERG TELEVISION'S coverage of the Presidential race. He anchored the network's primary season and election night coverage, interviewing the major candidates including [[Barack Obama]] and [[John McCain]]. Peter routinely covers the Fed, Treasury, White House and Congress. Previously he did extensive reporting on the Gulf Coast's recovery from [[Hurricane Katrina]] and traveled to Beijing with Secretary Paulson for a closer look at the economic relationship between the U.S. and China.
Prior to Bloomberg, Peter worked as a producer and reporter for NBC News and MSNBC in Washington. He was assigned to the Pentagon during the Iraq invasion. Prior to that, he helped launch EnergyNewsLive.com. He served as News Director and Washington Bureau Chief for the web-based energy news service, leading ENL's coverage of the California power crisis and the Enron collapse. Peter also spent ten years in local news as an anchor and reporter, witnessing everything from Western wildfires to death row executions. His reporting earned him awards at every stop. Peter was born and raised in Washington and is the son of a print journalist.<ref>http://thehill.com/capital-living/media-sketch/20965-peter-cook-bloombergs-early-riser</ref> He is a graduate of Duke University and Northwestern University’s Medill School of Journalism. Peter and his wife have two boys.
==Personal life== Cook was born and raised in Washington, D.C. He attended St. Albans School before graduating from [[St. George's School, Newport|St. George's School]] in Rhode Island, and graduated from [[Duke University]] and [[Northwestern University]]'s Medill School of Journalism. He and his wife have two sons. His son [[George Cook the Social Chair]] has followed in his footsteps by attending Duke University. George needs a date to Christmas Karaoke. Christmas Karaoke is December 7. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/media-sketch/peter-cook-bloombergs-early-riser-2009-03-23.html|title=Peter Cook: Bloomberg's early riser |last=Rothstein |first=Betsy |work=The Hill |accessdate=2009-07-30}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
==Career== Cook started his career in broadcast journalism as an intern for [[Nightline (US news program)|Nightline]] and at Duke, where he hosted his own game show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/media-sketch/peter-cook-bloombergs-early-riser-2009-03-23.html|title=Peter Cook: Bloomberg's early riser |last=Rothstein |first=Betsy |work=The Hill |accessdate=2009-07-30}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
Before going national, Peter spent ten years in local news as an anchor and reporter, witnessing everything from Western wildfires to death row executions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/media-sketch/peter-cook-bloombergs-early-riser-2009-03-23.html|title=Peter Cook: Bloomberg's early riser |last=Rothstein |first=Betsy |work=The Hill |accessdate=2009-07-30}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
In 2000, he helped launch ''EnergyNewsLive.com''. He served as News Director and Washington Bureau Chief for the web-based energy news service, leading ENL's coverage of the California power crisis and the Enron collapse.
Peter started working as a producer and reporter for [[NBC News]] and [[MSNBC]] in March 2003 in Washington, D.C. He was assigned to the Pentagon during the Iraq invasion.
==Bloomberg== Peter joined Bloomberg Television in October 2003. Before his shift in the morning, Peter hosted Bloomberg's ''Money & Politics'' program and spearheaded Bloomberg's coverage of the Presidential race.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=77563|title=''The American Presidency Project'': Interview with Peter Cook of Bloomberg's 'Money and Politics |last=Woolley |first=John T |work=The University of California at Santa Barbara |accessdate=2009-07-30}}</ref>
He anchored the network's primary season and election night coverage, interviewing the major candidates including Barack Obama and John McCain. Peter routinely covers the Fed, Treasury, White House and Congress. Previously he did extensive reporting on the Gulf Coast's recovery from Hurricane Katrina and traveled to Beijing with Secretary Paulson for a closer look at the economic relationship between the U.S. and China.
In 2009, Peter covered every angle of the financial crisis, regularly breaking news on the government's unprecedented response. He interviewed key Washington players including Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/media-sketch/peter-cook-bloombergs-early-riser-2009-03-23.html|title=Peter Cook: Bloomberg's early riser |last=Rothstein |first=Betsy |work=The Hill |accessdate=2009-07-30}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> White House economic adviser Larry Summers, Senate Banking Committee Chairman Chris Dodd and Senate Minority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]] as well as business leaders such as JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon.
==Awards== Cook was a North Carolina AP "Best Spot News Coverage" Award Winner for his coverage of Hurricane Dennis, as well as a Virginia AP "Best Continuing Coverage of a News Story" for his coverage of a high-profile murder case.
He has also been named the Idaho All Media Rookie of the Year.
==External links== *[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=a7jZG8o.X5x8 Bloomberg News - ''Shelby Says Bernanke Didn't Bring Leadership to Fed: Video'' 12.17.09] *[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=adhpFXun0kXI Bloomberg News - ''Cantwell Says `We Should Go Back to Glass-Steagall' Act: Video'' 12.16.09] *[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=asqTqedTgisA Bloomberg News - ''Feinberg Says Pay Plan Goal Is to Make Firms Repay U.S.: Video'' 12.11.09] *[http://www.mediabistro.com/fishbowlDC/television/peter_cook_the_fishbowldc_interview__114264.asp/ Media Bistro - ''FishbowlDC Interview: Peter Cook'' 04.16.09] *[http://thehill.com/media-sketch/peter-cook-bloombergs-early-riser-2009-03-23.html/ "Peter Cook: Bloomberg's Early Riser," ''The Hill'', 03/23/09] *[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601070&sid=a5TnDT0ayPRI&refer=politics Bloomberg News - ''Giuliani Says He'd Consider Adding Troops in Iraq for Success '' 6.13.07] *{{C-SPAN|petercook02}}

In [[economics]] and [[engineering]], the '''price–performance ratio''' refers to a product's ability to deliver performance, of any sort, for its price. Generally speaking, products with a lower price/performance ratio are more desirable, excluding other factors.
Price–performance is often written as '''cost–performance''' or '''cost–benefit'''. Even though this term would seem to be a straightforward ratio, when price performance is improved, better, or increased, it actually refers to the performance divided by the price, in other words exactly the opposite ratio (i.e. an inverse ratio) to rank a product as having an increased price/performance.
==Examples==
===Consumer and medical products=== According to futurist [[Raymond Kurzweil]], products start out as highly ineffective and highly expensive.<ref name="raykurzweil"/>
Gradually, products become more effective and cheaper until they are highly effective and almost free to buy.<ref name="raykurzweil"/> Some of the products that have followed this example include [[HIV/AIDS|AIDS]] medications (which are now affordable to the majority of AIDS sufferers{{which|date=September 2014}}), [[Speech synthesis|text-to-speech]] programs, and [[digital camera]]s.<ref name="raykurzweil">{{cite book |last = Kurzweil |first = Raymond |authorlink = Raymond Kurzweil |title = The Singularity is Near |publisher = [[Penguin Books]] |year = 2005 |isbn = 0-14-303788-9}} </ref> However, products that rely primarily on paper (e.g., newspapers and toilet paper) and/or fossil fuels (e.g., electricity in most countries and petroleum gasoline for automobiles) have only increased in price.
This directly contradicts the trend of electronic gadgets like [[netbook]]s, [[desktop computer]]s, and [[laptop]] computers that also have been decreasing in price. However, the prevailing [[inflation rate]] of a country or province/state may negate the plummeting costs of software, AIDS medications, and/or digital cameras in certain regions along with certain governmental policies. This has the effect of keeping costs high in certain areas while they are dramatically reduced in others.
In theory, this means that the rich people have earlier access to highly inefficient technologies, medical treatments, and [[Therapy|therapies]] (that are prototypical in nature) while the poor get access to these same products when they become more efficient and easier to manufacture several years down the road.<ref name="raykurzweil"/>
===Business world=== During the latter 1990s, the cost–performance ratios of the larger [[Mainframe computer|mainframe]] systems fell tremendously in comparison to a number of smaller [[microcomputer]]s handling the same load. As a result, many of the older computer companies were shut down and people were [[unemployment|put out of work]]. However, most of them were able to be re-hired at the newer corporations after undergoing a series of re-training involving the newer technologies.
In the business world, there is usually a value associated with a typical cost–performance ratio analysis. This value can either be positive, neutral, or negative depending on the amount of money spent versus the results achieved by the spending of the available [[Financial capital|capital]]. A cost-performance ratio with a positive value (i.e. greater than 1) indicates that costs are running under budget.<ref name="wideman">{{cite web | url = http://www.maxwideman.com/pmglossary/PMG_C11.htm#Cost%20Performance%20Indicator | title = Cost–performance ratio indicator | publisher = Max Wideman| date = | accessdate = 2010-08-26}}</ref> A negative value (i.e. less than 1) indicates that costs are running over budget.<ref name="wideman"/> However, a neutral cost-performance ratio (between 1.0 and 1.9) could suggest a certain degree of stagnation in the budget. [[Business trip]]s can also be factored into the cost–performance ratio because spending $50 to do a journey spanning {{convert|100|mi|km}} in two hours is a better cost–performance ratio than spending $105 to do the journey in one hour.
===Computer technology=== The term tends to be used quite a bit when comparing computer hardware. During the latter 1990s, the price–performance ratios of midrange and large [[Mainframe computer|mainframe]] systems fell tremendously in comparison to a number of smaller [[microcomputer]]s handling the same load. Many companies were forced out of the industry as this happened, including [[Digital Equipment Corporation|DEC]], [[Data General]] and many [[multiprocessor]] vendors such as [[Sequent Computer Systems]] and [[Pyramid Technology]].
== See also == *[[Benefit–cost ratio]]
